reviewText: Pirates of the Carribean 2 - Dead Man's Chest was just as enjoyable as the original movie!  Johnny Depp returns to the role only he could have created, Capt. Jack Sparrow.  The heavy eyeliner and slurred speech make Capt. Jack what he is - entertaining!This chapter begins as Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley) are interrupted mid-wedding and arrested for helping Jack Sparrow escape (shown in the first movie).  Will makes a deal to win his and his bride-to-be's freedom by finding Jack Sparrow and retrieving his compass (which has powers revealed later in the movie).Will's father, Bootstrap Bill (Stellan Skarsgard), is one of the undead pirates whose soul is owned by Davy Jones (Bill Nighy).  He appears, along with those screwball pirates Pintel and Ragetti (Lee Arenberg and MacKenzie Crook) to assist Jack, Will and Elizabeth in their quest for the compass, and the Dead Man's Chest.There are many action/stunt scenes, the best of which involves a sword fight and a rolling, runaway wheel.  Impressive, to say the least!  It also keeps its humorous antics alive from the first movie.I recommend this movie highly - although the ending begs for the 3rd movie to answer some questions (I usually hate that!)  It is as fun, entertaining and action packed as the first!-1smileycat :-)
summary: Just as entertaining as the first!

reviewText: Sequels seldom live up to the originals, but 'Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest,' is even more spectacular than the first film.  The inventiveness of this film makes the original seem repetitive in comparison.  Wisely, they keep all of the key players with Gore Verbinski and Jerry Bruckheimer still at the directing and producing helms.  There are more twists and turns for the dueling and battle scenes in '...Dead Man's Treasure,' surprisingly enough, and it seldom gets boring.The story has just the right amount of contents for an engaging plot.  It isn't too simple or predictable, nor is it too complicated.  We start where we left off.  On this voyage Elizabeth (Keira Knightly) and Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) are about to be executed for treason for allowing and abetting Captain Jack (Johnny Depp) Sparrow's escape.  We find a new villain authority in Lord Beckett who negotiates for them to obtain a remarkable compass from Capt. Jack in exchange for their lives. Embarking on the sea, the three must face Davy Jones and his hideous crew as well as a foreboding and mysterious sea monster.  Captain Jack and Will barter their souls to get what they want. To end their quest and problems, they must find and obtain a key to Davy Jones' hidden treasure and then possess the treasure itself.  Their sojourn is propelled and haulted by many difficulties along the way.  Each diversion is often unique and always compelling.There are so many surprises throughout the movie.  The dialogue is even funnier than the original, and the original cast is still in fine form.  Keira Knightly is terrific as the beautiful and brazen mistress, and Johnny Depp meets his script and raises it twenty fold with his thoroughly entertaining performance.  Orlando Bloom is certainly an apt player in the lover's triangle, and everyone else is certainly effective.  Davy Jones, his crew, and the monster are certainly creepy enough to keep our interest.  One minor criticism is due:  Near the end it tends to drag on a bit, but at least their intention was to get us to pause and reflect on the state of matters awhile.  'Pirates of the Caribbean:  Dead Man's Chest' is thoroughly entertaining and takes us to places we have never gone before--or at least it transports us in ways we've never gone before.  Also, as good as the original was, it seemed to get tiresome in places with all the adventure of pirates who could fight but never die. Furthermore, the script and the expansive camera angles of this sequel give viewers many reasons to be happy to flock to the theatres to see this swashbuckling extravaganza!

reviewText: It reminds me of Empire Strikes Back in a good way.First off, this is the second day I went to see the movie. Tried it Friday with my 5 year old nephew but he was too skittish to watch more than 15-20 minutes. Be warned this movie can be very intense and starts in a dark way.So after having to leave early, I went back Saturday to see it again without kids. Much better experience. The movie is loaded with action and subterfuge with sprinkles of humor. Perhaps there's a bit less heart as the lover's are thrown wrinkles rather than ladders to fulfilling their quest to be together. There doesn't seem to be a clear hero story here, but more a setup for the mystery that pins the entire series together.If you like being intriqued and can patiently wait for next year's finale, then you'll like this movie. I loved all the split loyalties and secret plots. Alas I am a Harry Potter fan so I've learned to be patient for resolution.Few tips for you: watch the first movie again before you see this. It'll help familiarize yourself with the characters. And just like the first movie, stick around until the last credit rolls. You'll be rewarded, I promise.
summary: Reminds me of Empire Strikes Back

reviewText: I loved the first movie and felt this one really deepened the story.  This is not a sequel.  This is the second act of an action-packed play that even manages to bring in some heartfelt emotion that was somewhat lacking in the first movie.  Johnny Depp's performance in this series will be one of the performances that goes down in history and will be mentioned in all acting books given to potential newcomers to the acting field.Some complain the story is needlessly complicated and it goes on and on only to end too abruptly.  I found the complicated storyline challenging and found it easy to stay with the whole time.  I didn't get lost.  There is quite a bit of character development in this one too, which some could see as going on and on.  Orlando Bloom and Keira Knightley both have more to do and their characters become more interesting and real because of it.  Instead of two kids being led around by the infamous Captain Jack Sparrow, it's established they are a trio of heroes that depend on one another whether they like it or not.Truly an engaging story.
summary: Near perfect cinema without being pretentious

reviewText: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest does the right thing as a sequel: It maintains the same carefree spirit of the original and creates an even more fitting story to the whole Pirates lore. After narrowly escaping the gallows--with the help of his friends Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley)--and reclaiming his cursed Black Pearl, it still seems Captain Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) has a few more fish to fry. More specifically the barnacle-encrusted undead on board the ghostly Flying Dutchman, lead by Mr. Octopus Face himself, Davy Jones (Bill Nighy). Jack apparently owes a blood debt to the inky captain and if he can't find a way out of it--namely locating the secret contents of Jones' famed locker--Sparrow will be doomed to eternal damnation and servitude in the afterlife (insert Jack Sparrow's face of disgust here). Making matters worse, Sparrow's problems manage to interfere with the wedding plans of Will and Elizabeth, who are forced to join Jack on yet another one of his misadventures.Depp's Oscar-nominated performance as Captain Jack is still a marvel in slovenly pirate behavior, with his slurred speech, swaying swagger and slack, waving arms. But whether channeling famed Rolling Stones' guitarist Keith Richards or not, it's the duality of the character that continues to intrigue us. He is a lusty, fearless man with a deeply defiant and somewhat sneaky streak but whose delicate features, long, dread locked hair, Kohl-rimmed eyes and almost girly mannerisms give him a subtly effeminate air that belies his macho antics. This time around, young Brits Knightley and Bloom have a little more to do, with Elizabeth's growing attraction to Jack and Will's reunion with his father, Bill "Bootstrap" Turner (Stellan Skarsgard), who's soul is stuck on the Flying Dutchman. And Nighy (Love Actually) once again makes his mark as an effective villain, infusing his rather quirky acting ticks--the laconic delivery, the laid-back attitude--which shines through all the special effects make-up. Let's just say, Nighy certainly rivals Depp in the arrogant rock star stance, even if he has tentacles for a face.The other thing Dead Man's Chest does right is make things bigger and better. From a hair-raising sword fight on top of a spinning water wheel to the way Davy Jones and his crew look--all water logged and crustacean-like--the film's production value is simply amazing. Returning producer Jerry Bruckheimer and director Gore Verbinski make sure the action sequences, the sets, the costumes, the make-up and the special effects give the audience a familiarity to the original while also taking them on a whole new adventure. And if you are a fan of the Disney park attraction (the one at Disneyland, not Disney World), the elements that got missed in the first one--the creepy bayou, the beating heart in the treasure chest--are in this sequel. Dead Man's Chest does lag a bit from time to time, especially in heating up the Jack, Elizabeth and Will love triangle. But that's OK. We enjoy watching their banter, as much as we do the rest of it. And for those who'll want more adventure after the movie ends, Dead Man's Chest gives us a promise the third installment will be just as much pirate fun.9/10
summary: more than holds you up by your "bootstraps"

reviewText: The first Pirates of the Caribbean film was a very pleasant surprise; who could ever think that a film loosely based on a theme park ride could be so fun and lucrative?  Pretty much all previous and subsequent ride-based films (the only ones I can think of are Country Bears and Haunted Mansion) were flops, but Pirates surprised everyone by having a cool story, great characters, eye-popping effects, and amazing acting.  With a huge box office gross, sequels were inevitable, but despite the fact that I loved the first film, the prospect of a sequel didn't sit quite well with me.  Furthermore, Disney greenlit two sequels to be shot back-to-back, and the last franchise that did that was The Matrix, and we all remember how those sequels turned out (in my opinion, the Back to the Future films are the only ones to master the usage of back-to-back sequels).  However, as the movie's release date drew nearer, I found myself getting more and more excited, and this excitement was helped by the generally positive critical reviews.  Well, I'll admit that this review will be generally positive (though I feel it deserves a low 4 star rating, closer to a 3.5 than an actual 4), but that doesn't mean that the film is without its flaws.The film begins on the wedding day of William Turner (Orlando Bloom) and Elizabeth Swann (Kiera Knightley), but it is interrupted by their arrest.  After helping Capt. Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) escape at the end of the first film, the British government has finally caught up with them, and presents Elizabeth's father, the governor of Port Royal, Weatherby Swann (Jonathan Pryce), with warrants for their arrest as well as the arrest of former Commodore James Norrington (Jack Davenport), who resigned from the Royal Navy between the end of the first film and beginning of this one.  The representitive of the Crown, Lord Beckett (Tom Hollander), who is also a high-ranking member of the East India Trading Company, offers a deal to Will; if Will can retrieve Jack Sparrow's "broken" compass, he can help Will and Elizabeth out (or can he?).Meanwhile, Jack is still captaining the Black Pearl along with a few of the crew members from Curse of the Black Pearl and some new recruits.  Early on, Jack and his crew get stranded on an island when the mysterious appearance of someone causes Jack to fear the open sea.  As it turns out, Jack owes his soul to Davy Jones (Bill Nighy), and as long as Jack can stay away from the sea, he will be free from Jones and his monster, the Krakken.  Will finds Jack on the island, and after escaping a tribe of cannibals, are forced to return to the sea.  Will explains his plight to Jack, who offers an ambiguous solution.  Jack needs a key, and if Will can help him find it, he'll get the compass.  Of course, Sparrow's untruthful nature merely lands Will in a lot of trouble.Back in Port Royal, Governor Swann tries to warn his daughter that Beckett may not have been completely truthful to Will and tries to help her escape.  She eventually stows away aboard a ship and attempts to find Will, whom she believes (rightly) will only get trouble from dealing with Jack.As the film goes on, Will is reunited with his father, "Bootstrap" Bill Turner (Stellan Skarsgard), Norrington makes his not-so-triumphant return, and many exciting action sequences ensue.The movie's strongest point is definitely Depp's Sparrow.  Jack's odd mannerisms, tongue-twister dialogue, and bizarre movements are worth the price of admission by themselves.  His entrance in this film, while not as great as his one in the first, is still awesome.  The CGI is even better than the first film, though sometimes, I found Jones' crew to be a little too silly to be feared.  However, Jones himself is wonderfully creepy.  The story is kind of a mixed bag; the general story is good, with its little twists and turns, but some of the finer points are a little hard to follow.  Lord Beckett's part of the film is very hard to follow, and the inclusion of the fortune teller Tia Dalma (Naomie Harris) seemed pointless (until the end, that is).  In my opinion, one of the reasons that some of the finer points were hard to follow had to do with some of the strong accents.  Sometimes, I couldn't even hear what people were saying, especially Tia Dalma's very strong Jamaican accent.  I know this makes me sound a little uncultured, but I believe that one may have to sit through the film a few times and concentrate to hear everything.  The action sequences, though, were amazing.  My favorite was definitely a three-way sword fight that culminated on a runaway water wheel, with Elizabeth looking on and yelling at the participants.  Also, the scenes on the island at the beginning with Jack trying to escape being barbecued while Will and the crew were trying to free themselves from spherical cages was amazing.  One other thing is that the inclusion of Will's father helped fix a plot hole from the first film, and the post-credit coda is given purpose as well.Some of the negative aspects include some dialogue, the length, and the aforementioned story problems.  Most of the dialogue between Elizabeth and Jack was annoying (there were a few exceptions, such as the "dress or nothing" line, and even though the lines were sappy, Knightley's provacative facial expressions were priceless).  As for the length, the film clocks in at almost 2 hours and 50 minutes, and they could have probably trimmed at least 15 minutes without losing much.This next thing may be less of a problem after seeing the next film next summer, but this movie definitely feels incomplete.  Even though Back to the Future, Part II led directly into Part III, the plot of II concluded in II, and the plot of III was hinted at in II then was brought up in the final 5 minutes of the film.  This film wrapped up nothing.  The next film will be a continuation of the Davy Jones and Dead Man's Chest plot, though I'm sure that even more things will be brought up (I've heard that Chow Yun Fat will appear as a famous Chinese pirate and will have a significant role).  Still, I won't completely hold this against the film until I see Pirates 3.There were numerous callbacks to the first film, and if you haven't seen it (or don't remember much of it), it is required viewing to enjoy Dead Man's Chest.  One thing that I feel the writers did well was the inclusion of Pintel (Lee Arenberg) and Ragetti (Mackenzie Crook), two of the villains from the first film, who I'm sure were fan favorites.  Instead of pointlessly bringing back these characters just because people enjoyed them, they made their role in the film true to the characters' despicable natures and while they spent a lot of time on the Black Pearl, they were never actually a part of Jack's crew.As for whether or not I recommend this film, I'll say this: If you liked the Curse of the Black Pearl, you should definitely see this one.  You may or may not like this one (I did, but my brother didn't, though he still plans on seeing the next film), but it will be worth your time.  If you didn't like the first one, don't bother with this one, because they took what people liked most and upped the ante.  If you haven't seen the original, you should check that out, and if you like it, go see this one.  If anything, it will make you want to see Pirates of the Caribbean 3.

reviewText: First of all I liked the first movie and the acting performances were fine in both films.  I did have a few problems with the first movie in that I would have really like to see these movies have been made into really good realistic Pirate movies instead of all the supernatural stuff that I never experienced on the ride.  It didn't have to be factual, but a real good Swashbuckler epic would have been better.  Anyways, I had gotten over that and was excited to see the sequel figuring it had to be better than the first.  Boy was I ever wrong!The first forty-five minutes or so were fine, I was actually enjoying myself.  Then they ran into Davy Jones who for some reason was some sort of cross between a crab and an octopus, and his evil crew who were all demented sea creature people.  No two were the same.  Now don't get me wrong the special effects were good its just that everything seemed dark and macabre, not your typical Disney movie.  The animators have got to be sick in the head to want to incorporate this kind of material into a film meant for families.  I've never been for censorship, but the violence in this film is much more graphic than in other films rated R and children should not view it.Now getting away with the fact that this is a disgusting film visually its also a quite boring movie as well.  The purpose of the picture seemed to be to keep people watching as long as possible without turning it off. Everything took way too long to happen and everything was totally predictable it just seemed like you were behind an old lady in a walker and you didn't want to be rude and go around her so you tough it out and it takes you two and a half hours to get out of the pharmacy!  Good God people we get it now get on with the movie why don't you.  Most of the time nothing seems to happen.  Sure they had the obligatory chase through the jungle and pirate battles and don't forget about the ten minute sword fight it had one of those too except it was fifteen minutes long and as ridiculous as it gets ending with Will and the Commodore slashing away at each other on a rolling water wheel and yet neither gets hurt.  Then theres the whole point of the movie which was to get the Treasure chest before Davy Jones so when the "good guys" get the treasure dug up they totally abandon it to have their little sword fight.  Who would do that?This film is a pure money machine.  With no plot, no heart, and no spirit there is nothing to be gained from watching this film.  Mindless junk thrown out there to capitalize on a ripe new franchise. This film wasn't made for people it was made for profits.
summary: Not For Children, Not For Anybody

reviewText: That's right.  Not Depp, Bloom or Knightley winning the prize here.  But, Nighy as Davey Jones(who is by far one of the best movie villains this year if not for the past few years) brings this film to life. When the movie industry seems to be one step from crying for help from inspiring minds like myself and many thirsty artists across the globe, the characters that pack a punch are dwindling in numbers with the fans.  But, Davey Jones and his band of well constructed special-effect goons(not quite as dull as a bunch of skeleton-by-nights)save the day(along with a few flickering flames of action and "suspense" to keep you on the edge of your seats).  Sure, Depp has his comical moments.  And, Knightley's dad in the film makes a strikingly heart-felt attempt to show genuine concern for his daughter and the freedom of the seas for Jack Sparrow.  But, the chemistry between Bloom and Knightley is as pale and cold as the dead fish spilling out all over the place. It's like watching bad Shakespeare.  I guess eye candy still wins sales--which is a real let down and sign of further decline in quality, lasting films in the near future.  [Slaps a few drooling faces with a wet cod.} Wake up, people. Arr. It won't "hold water" forever, and it's just infatuation. [Although, even I cannot deny the attraction of miss Knightley.  But, honestly, the witch doctor friend of Jack was more appealing and surprisingly attractive by far(under the grimey make-up of course).]I would definitely say the sequel out plays the original(which seemed to go in circles and was a bit of a sleeper).  And, you might not understand a few details if you see this one first.  But, I think the sequel could possibly stand on it's own with an added flashback or two.  I'd hate to have to go back and try to watch the first after this.  There is one scene in this second of the films between all three main heroes which gives it the slightest bang of dramatic tension near the end of the film...and then it fizzles sadly.Lastly, I recommend if you don't know it already--many films nowadays are getting on track with my thoughts and making good use of credit time--to sit through the credits for a little highlight similar to that of X-Men 3, etc.  I give it three stars to plot a course for all of us to the third(And maybe final? Are we going for the trilogy shtick or gonna try to drag the dead man out a little longer?) film with hopes of a grand finale on the horizon.
summary: Bill Nighy rocks this film on an unstable ship

reviewText: First, regarding the movie itself. I purposely waited until seeing At World's End before reviewing Dead Man's Chest. This, the second in the Pirates trilogy is a romping good film. Although darker than The Curse of the Black Pearl it still has a lot of what made the first film fun. Exciting sword fights, great sea battles, lots of tongue-in-cheek humor, and an absolutely wonderful musical score. Johnny Depp does a great job in bringing back all of Jack Sparrow's weird personality traits. Add a still serious Orlando Bloom as Will Turner and the ever-so-lovely Kiera Knightly as Elizabeth Swan and you get a wonderful movie experience.The basic premise is that years before the events of the first movie, Jack Sparrow sold his soul to Davy Jones so that the Black Pearl would be raised from the depths of the sea. He was given 13 years to continue as Captain and upon reaching the end of that period he would have to join Jones crew for 100 years. As Dead Man's Chest opens we find a desperate Sparrow trying to forestall the inevitable. At the same time, Will and Elizabeth are arrested for aiding in Sparrow's escape and in exchange for their freedom Will is sent to retrieve Sparrow's weird compass.What makes this movie great is:1. Sparrow is still the character from the first movie. Unfortunately this did not carry over to the third movie where we're treated to a weak and confusing character.2. The growth of Elizabeth into a more complex character as she must take matters into her own hands to win her and Will's Freedom3. The Norington character, as we see him become a major role in this movie. Having fallen on hard times he looks for a way to win back his life as a Royal Naval Officer. Again, unfortunately in the third movie, after this great build up in Dead Man's Chest, we see him in only three scenes, and only one of those is more than 2 minutes.4. The introduction of Naomie Harris as Tia Dalma, the Voodoo priestess/queen/person/whatever. We only get two scenes with her but she steals both of them. By far the most interesting character in DMC and those two scenes sets up her more expanded role in Pirates 3. However, as good as she was in the third movie (and she was good) the resolution of her character was SO disappointing.5. The surprise appearance at the end of the film of a former nemesis.6. And of course, the special effects. By far some of the best I have ever seen, only surpassed by At World's End.And now for Disc 2. Do not, I repeat, do not spend the extra money for the two disc collection unless you are really into how the Davy Jones Character was created. Of all the special features on disc 2, that was the only really interesting one. The rest were filler, nothing more. We are treated to a blooper reel on disc 1 which was great. But what were missing were deleted scenes, which surprised me. They had them for the first movie. But since this movie was longer maybe there weren't any left that would have been interesting.To recap, I loved the movie, not as much as the first but more than the third. It is still a blast to watch even after viewing it many, many times. But just buy the 1 disc version. The second disc is mostly a waste of time.
summary: An outstanding film but disc 2 is not worth the extra cost.

reviewText: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest is a very engaging film, but if you are expecting something that is like the original then you will be a little disappointed.  It maintains a similar spirit of the original, but it creates a very different style of movie the second time through.  Dead Man's Chest brings back many of the favorite old characters.  Johnny Depp of course comes back as the infamous Jack Sparrow continuously playing the character strictly for humor with his swaying swagger and slack, waving arms, and hilarious facial expressions.  Orlando Bloom and Keira Knightly come back as the couple Will Turner and Elizabeth Swann.  Jack Davenport comes back as Norrington, except exiled and stripped of his status as an Officer in the Royal Navy.  Jonathan Pryce returns as well, to play Governor Weatherby Swann or simply Elizabeth's Father.  Other reprised roles include Kevin McNally as Mr. Gibbs, Lee Arenberg and Mackenzie Crook as the pirates Pintel (angry bald pirate) and Regetti (the pirate with the wooden eye), and many others.The new characters we meet add a lot to the story such as Bootstrap Bill played by Stellan Skarsgrd.  Will Turner's Father who is a barnacle/crustacean riddled servant of Davy Jones, the captain of the Flying Dutchman, played by Bill Nighy.  While the fight scenes are not as engaging as the sword fighting from Curse of the Black Pearl they are still exciting nonetheless.  Another thing Dead Man's Chest brings to the silver screen is more interesting visual effects such as the way Davy Jones and his crew look crustacean-like and barnacle encrusted, all of whom (for the most part) are completely constructed from computer animation.  One will find undead sea-creature pirates a little more eye catching than undead skeleton pirates.  The new characters give the audience a small feeling of the original while, at the same time, adding a completely new and original chapter to the story.I will also say that if one were to not see the opening Disney logo, it would be very difficult to know that this was a Disney movie.  Unlike the stories of the cartoons that we all know and love, Pirates of the Caribbean is far more violent.  Even more so than Curse of the Black Pearl.  There is more death, more gore, and more violence altogether.  Not to mention that there are also a lot more scary situations as well.  This movie is definitely more intense than the first in terms of its increased level of brutality.  So, if you're not into that then stay away from this movie because it has a lot of it.Finally, I will say this without giving away any spoilers:  If one is expecting a conclusive ending, then prepare to be disappointed.  Just like in The Matrix Reloaded, this movie is just setting everything up for the third installment for next year.
summary: Not For Those Who Want Another Curse of the Black Pearl.

reviewText: I wasn't as sure I liked this film as much as I had the earlier one.  It relied much more on CGI for its impact.  Furthermore the story line seemed rather thin.  While it brought up a lot of questions regarding personal agendas and conflict of interests, it also seemed to go on forever without purpose.  It seemed as though "adventures" were added ad infinitum until the movie was "long enough" at which point it was brought to a dénouement.  It seemed that manic hijinx for its own sake should carry the film.  After a repeat of a marginally funny uncontrolled roll down a hill into water, I felt that even the insanity was too staged.What really put me off, though, was that the dénouement had "to be continued" written all over it, which suggested a far greater desire to milk financial gain from a popular first film than for the entertainment of the audience.  It was very formulaic, sort of A + B + C = movie--or more properly $.  A definite disappointment.I also ended up feeling sympathetic with no one.  Well, perhaps a little with Jack.  Though he is his usual reprehensible but charming self, he was never less than honest about whom or what he was, so he seemed less objectionable!  More than anything, I felt this film had less of the light hearted insanity of the earlier film.  Despite the impressive CGI and the constant bedlam, it seemed a much darker work.  Again there was a sense that "more was to come," and indeed it almost guaranteed that the viewer would return to have his sense of balance restored, which seemed manipulative.  I chose not to purchase or attend the film until after the third was available.  One could only hope that by the next film the series itself would be redeemed.

reviewText: Let me start off by saying how much I loved the first Pirates of the Caribbean.  Johnny Depp was brilliant, the story was fun, it was immensely entertaining, even Orlando Bloom didn't annoy me as much as he usually does.I think Disney let their idea people get out of control. The movie just got too crowded with special effects and totally goofy plot twists, which eventually robbed a good cast of any opportunity to actually act. Davey Jones and his crew are so over-endowed with gimmicks squirming over their bodies that they ended up more being more distracting than entertaining. And why did the director need to get so focused on being as gross as possible? Johnny Depp nibbling on a necklace made of human toes was something I didn't get; I didn't need it, and neither did the movie.Compared to the first film, Dead Man's Chest was a let down. I can't think of any redeeming qualities, except maybe that it is making a few people a lot of money.

reviewText: Yes, it is possible to get too much of a good thing. Unrelenting action, confusing twists and turns of plots and sub-plots, creative special effects -- yes, this movie is just too full. And, to be blunt, too long.OK, I love Johnny Depp about as much as it's possible to love any actor. One who hasn't actually showed up at my doorstep in the flesh, that is. (That's the only thing wrong with Johnny; he apparently does not even know I exist.) But the last hour of this movie could have been edited down to half an hour without losing anything all that great. We can only have so many clashes of one faction against another, only so many people slamming against the deck as the Kraken's tentacles sway menacingly and curl around everything they touch, only so many scenes of using the little undead monkey for comedy relief . . . I think I actually nodded off there for awhile.Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed the movie on the whole. But frankly, the members of the Davy Jones crew are indistinguishably horrible, and I never did get up any perceptible sympathy for Bootstrap Turner. And they might have slowed the pace just a tiny bit once in awhile, so I could breathe.
summary: I Adore Johnny Depp, But Not This Film

reviewText: There is a trend with sequels to a great original never being able to match the first film or best it. Every once in a while there is a sequel that acheives one of those feats. 'Dead Man's Chest' is one of those rare films. It isn't necessarily better than the first film, but it's every bit as good. And that's really good. Our favorite cast of characters return as Will Turner and Elizabeth Swan(Orlando Bloom, Keira Knightley)are imprisoned and set for death for letting Captain Jack Sparrow escape. Will cuts a deal with a man to find Jack and bring back his compass. Meanwhile, Jack is battling the evil Davey Jones(insert "Daydream Beliver" joke here), a sea creature pirate Jack owes a debt too. Then the race is on to find Davey Jones' heart, buried in a chest, and destroy it. The plot and main focus here get shuffled in all the action and great set pieces. And what great set pieces they are. Director Gore Verbinski has crafted one amazing looking film. The cinematography is sharp and sparkling, and his eye for detail is amazing. The action scenes raise the bar from the first film, including a water wheel fight that is nothing short of brilliant, and a giant sea monster destroying the Black Pearl that has some of the best effects I have seen. The film itself is a bit darker in tone than the first, is a tad bit more violent and may be a bit more terrifying for younger viewers. But the spirit and the humor is still there in full bloom. If there is one problem, it's that the film seems to go on forever. This usually doesn't bother me, but even I felt like it would never end. It's about the same length as Superman Returns, and that didn't bother me. As for the ending, it's jaw dropping superb. It's not a cheat and will not upset you. It's perfect. It will make you want to see part 3 even more. It's like a "Star Wars" cliffhanger, which makes sense since this movie is like the "Empire Strikes Back" of the Pirate movies. Bravo!. The score is wonderful as well. Hans Zimmer does another great job to make the music lift the already rousing scenes and action moments to even greater heights. But really, this is Johnny's movie. Captain Jack has lost nothing. He has another classic and memorable entrance in this one as he did in the first. I can't say enough about it. There has just never been a character, or a performance, like Depp's. He's a genius. Bloom is steady, but his parts are the least interesting. Knightley is breathtakingly beautiful, but she doesn't really serve the script much. Jack Davenport returns as Norrington, and Jonathan Pryce has another small role as Governor Swan. The sea creatures are unbelieveably designed and acted out. Bill Nighy, as Davey Jones, does wonders with the role. You haven't seen anything like this villain before. I loved "Superman Returns" to death, but this is the movie to see this summer. It's the perfect summer movie. What big summer blockbusters were made for. But see Supes's big return as well. I for one cannot wait until next May. Spider-Man 3?. Nah. Pirates 3 all the way. Yo ho ho!.
summary: More Fun Than A Bottle Of Rum
Title: N/A

reviewText: Captain Jack Sparrow and assorted friendlies and enemies sail again into mad adventures and other worldly trappings, continuing the frolicking fun of the original.  Have no fear; it is fun.  The humor and chaotic banter goes on and on and on, and that in the end is the biggest problem with the whole production.  It just doesn't end.  The theme of 'what goes around comes around' is explored in both principle and in lavish stunts involving giant circular props and certainly everyone has their chance to get their due.  The story is a bit convoluted, though not so much so that it distracts from the joy of watching Depp chew up scenery with his magic touch of inebriated craziness.  When Depp isn't on screen the flow is lethargic.  When he emerges the film flows like the Niagara and he is almost enough to keep the film going for nearly 3 hours.  Almost.  The sheer length is overwhelming and the story - such as it is - really doesn't require that much time to properly tell.  This probably should have been slimmed down to a thrifty 2 hour romp with nothing significant being washed away into the editing room abyss.  Numerous participants from the original show up in unexpected places including a fine surprise cameo that you won't see coming.  The cast, including the oft - criticized Orlando Bloom, do a splendid job even if they serve no other purpose than to give Captain Jack someone to work off of.  The picture leaves you hanging so that nothing will be resolved until the subsequent trip to "World's End" next spring, and with a proper resolution this one might not seem so long winded in the context of the bigger story.
summary: Dead Man's Chest is great fun, but tooooooooo long

reviewText: I was never a fan of these Pirates of the Caribbean movies.  I mean, they have plenty of exciting and distinct scenes that make the movies stand apart from other pirate films, but trying to follow along to any kind of plot is a very difficult thing to do.  What was going on throughout the movie?  Why were certain fight scenes happening?  What were those giant worms that were popping out of the water and attacking the ship?  I guess the overall weirdness is supposed to be unique to the viewers, and the reason the series caught the attention of millions, but, I don't know.  I'd just like to know what was going on.Also, I'm not a fan of the way the movie comes off like I'm watching a play.  Seriously, it's like the whole time I was sitting in the audience watching Johnny Depp do his typical weird pirate mannerisms on a giant stage.  That's kind of a turn off.

reviewText: I knew that this movie would be released as soon as it began pre-production, and have watched its progress (through the internet) all the way until it was released. It took forever to get here, but it was well worth the wait!!The Plot: The plot was even better than the first Pirates! If you thought the Black Pearl was a scary ship, its nothing compared to the Flying Dutchman, who's captain is Davy Jones himself. The movie also seems to have a darker atmosphere than Pirates 1. Another good aspect of the plot, is the fact that several small "meaningless" aspects in the first Pirates that were never explained, are brought back, and explained in this movie with much more meaning to the plot in this film (Jack's compass and his P-shaped brand on his arm, for example). Unfortunately, the movie ends with a cliffhanger, but has such a big twist, that I still left the theater with such satisfaction at such a surprising and interesting ending. I was skeptical at first about Disney making Pirates 2 & 3 at the same time, knowing how rushed sequels turn out, but seeing the ending, I'm no longer worried (they did the same thing w/ Lord of the Rings and the second two Matrix movies, and did it just fine). Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End may still be 10 months away, but its better than waiting 3 years for the next Star Wars movie, right?The Humor: What made about 60% of Pirates 1 so enjoyable, was the humor in it. Johnny Deep as Captain Jack Sparrow was the one that made everything around him react in such a funny way and, thankfully, he was center stage of the movie. In this one, the humor is different in style. Jack is still hilarious, but it seems that the humor comes, this time, from the things that happen to him and how he reacts to them. My favorite part was when Jack, Will, and the crew are trying to escape an island inhabited by African-like natives. The entire 20 minute scene was absolutely hysterical, from start to finish. Two pirates from the previous movie (can't remember their names, but one of them was always losing his right eye) return and steal every scene they're in. I also enjoyed the scene when Elizabeth Swann (Kiera Knightley) simply got beside herself when Jack Sparrow, Will Turner, and former Commodore Norrington engage in a 3-way every-man-for-himself sword fight over The Dead Man's Chest...wonderful scene.Acting: One word: flawless. Everybody returning from the previous movie seems to have gained experience and act even better than before (there was no more improvement left for Johnny Depp, however), and you can simply tell that all the newbies were simply born for the roles they were given. Davy Jones's actor perfectly portrayed a villain with truly morbid ways, but a heart-breaking past. Will's father, "Bootstrap Bill" Turner, shows up for the first time in the series as a slave of Davy Jones's, and has an actor who pulled it off perfectly. My only real complaint is that, in the first movie, Jack tells Will that he and his father look exactly alike, however, in the second movie, Bootstrap neither seems to look or even act like Will. I guess that's what happens to you after being a slave of Davy Jones for 15 (or so) years.The Special Effects: From the colorful settings, to Davy Jones, the SPFX never falters even once. This movie even gives Peter Jackson's The Lord of the Rings a run for its money. What can I say? The special effects are flawless. Enough said.Conclusion: Overall, better than Pirates 1. Go see this wonderful movie as soon as you can before it gets thrown into the dollar movie and get ready for Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End (coming May, 2007). FYI, keep a lookout for the trailer for Pirates 3, which shouldn't be too far off. Can't wait!!!
summary: The perfect sequel to a fantastic film!!! Get ready for Pirates 3!!!

reviewText: Captain Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) is back and he's in bigger trouble in Dead Man's Chest. Along with him, of course, comes Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley), the two would-be married lovers whose wedding is interrupted by the corrupt and unscrupulous Cutler Beckett (Tom Hollander), a true marketeer for the East India Trading Company.The continuing story. Jack, sashaying his way across the Caribbean, is trying to continue his infamous ability to cheat death. Problem is, though, is that he owes a life-debt to the dreaded Davy Jones (come full-on as a character and not just a small piece of sea karma by Bill Nighy). Davy Jones and his barnacled crew take the souls of those not willing to venture into the Great Unknown and apparently Jack had met Mr. Jones previously and wrangled a deal: he'd captain the Black Pearl for 13 years, and now that 13 years is up. So, in true Captain Sparrow fashion, Jack decides to cheat, steal, manipulate, and do whatever is necessary to save his skin. Even if it means finding the heart of Davy Jones (which is stowed away ...somewhere, waiting to be found). The more trouble is that Beckett wants the heart of Jones so that he can control the seas (he who controls Davy Jones' heart controls something called the Kracken, a mythological beast ...more on that in a minute) and thus be the only trading ships on the ocean. But Will Turner also needs the heart in order to save Elizabeth from the deadly clutches of Beckett who has promised to hang both Will and Elizabeth if he doesn't get it. The race is afoot! And what a race it is!As far as summertime blockbusters go, you'd have a pretty tough time finding something as entertaining as Dead Man's Chest. The action is incredible, the dialogue fun, and the special effects first-rate. Johnny Depp, as always, inhabits the role of Jack Sparrow. His mannerisms, line delivery and antics are just a sheer joy to watch. Keira Knightley and Orlando Bloom are also fun to watch but not nearly as much as Depp (who steals every scene he's in).There are problems though (Argh!). Length is an obvious issue. At 2 and 1/2 hours, younger kids might find it a bit irritating to sit through something so long. Indeed, little youngsters should avoid the film altogether as it has some rather gruesome if not downright frightening scenes in it (gaining its full PG-13 rating by having images of eyeballs being plucked out of living and caged pirates, etc.) The other problems involve the meshing histories. A tenuous connection between Davy Jones and The Flying Dutchman can be made, of course (the true captain of the Flying Dutchman was NOT anyone named "Davy Jones" but the myth is adequate enough to have him helm the ship). The other issue is Davy Jones' mythological undersea monster, the Kracken. The Kracken is a beast related to Greek and Norwegian mythology, not something as current as Davy Jones (who's myth started, I believe, in the early 1700s). My only other movie experience with the Kracken was in the sad, sad, sad B-movie CLASH OF THE TITANS (maybe not a true B-movie, but it sure felt that way!) I will admit, however, that Dead Man's Chest got the creature's features down more appropriately according to legend.At any rate, this is a wonderful summer film. Blockbuster? Definitely. Disney has done something amazing in their marketing, too: pulling stories from rides at their theme parks is a sure way to ensure that people come back to Disneyland and Disney World time and time again. Sheer genius.

reviewText: This is a good sequel to the first Pirates movie, which is saying something because most of Disney's sequels to their movies are REALLY bad.  But this one is well done.  It picks up where the first left off and the storyline is different from the first and similar because you still have Captain Jack Sparrow trying to manipulate events so that he comes out on top.  But you love him anyway.This movie has many of the qualities that I look for in a movie: good storyline, good characterization, humor/comedic elements, action/adventure, and of course romance (Will Turner and Elizabeth Swann).  This movie does leave you hanging at the end, which disappointed me the first time I saw it, but I've warmed up to it since then.  Basically I'll just have to go see the third Pirstes movie, which I cannot wait to do.  I also love the music in this film.  This movie is fun to watch and I find myself laughing and singing along with the music.

reviewText: Being honest, I did not much like the 1st "Pirates." However, I found this 2nd chapter to be a major improvement. A certain annoying character kind of ruined the subtle spooky horror Part 1 could have had. But fortunately, he never reappears now.Johnny Depp (Sparrow, I mean of course Captain Jack Sparrow) has of course gotten his ship back. But we see that he is in trouble with Davy Jones. (Depp owes a huge debt that has to be payed.) So, Depp is doing what he can to win some negotiating power of Jones. (Find his weakness, namely his heart, and hold that over Mr. Jones.) Will finds himself trying to save Elizabeth, and then his father. Of course fate will bring Depp and Bloom together. Granted the island of 'some undefined religion' seems a little silly, but at least it offers some laughs.In an interesting plot, Elizabeth joins the party looking for Will. We also meet a worn out James Norrington. While he was pompous and not so likable in Part 1, his destroyed defeated state allows us sympathy for him now. While we're on this subject, Elizabeth's father has also become a more sympathetic character.It's hard too say much without ruining the movie, but we have an interesting situation where we feel at least some sympathy for Captain Sparrow, Will, Elizabeth, and even James Norrington. But we also know that they aren't all going to get what they want in a neat package that doesn't do anyone else any harm.Another character worth some attention is Mr. Davy Jones. He is this interesting character that has elements of Gothic Horror but yet also sea horror. (A nice character who fills the emptiness left by Geoffrey Rush's death in Part 1.) Mr. Jones is really, really, bad. But he carries a charm that makes it virtually impossible not to like him a little. He wants Captain Sparrow's soul. But he is willing to negotiate. For 100 souls, he will consider Captain Sparrow's debt payed.Perhaps the most sympathetic character in the story is Will's father Bootstrap Bill who is trapped in Davy Jone's service. In a game of dice, he gives up any hope of salvation to save his son from Davy Jone's wrath. (Try to keep a dry face when he helps his son escape and says: "What more can they do to me?")Without going on too long, Captain Sparrow and his 'friends' find Mr. Jone's heart and only vulnerability. Then, we find that Captain Sparrow, Will, and James Norrington all want Mr. Jone's vulnerability for different reasons, and we have a dramatic, but not totally void of laughs 3 man sword fight. Soon, we see why we needed a few laughs here.There is a huge fight at sea. Mr. Jones is of course trying to get his one vulnerability back into safe hands. And he unleashes his HUGE monster. Captain Jack Sparrow wants to run, but he has a crisis of conscience and in a dramatic moment, flips the tables at least for the moment on this terrible monster. This really serves to underline the atrocity of betrayal from Elizabeth.  If you're on this website, you probably already know what happens after Johnny Depp pulls out his sword and says: "Hello Beasty."From here, there is utter sadness and what I consider the most sad, evil, and totally void of conscience cliffhanger end I have ever known. There is some hope when a character from Part 1 (who should be dead) suddenly returns to offer help. But of course, we want to know how he cheated death, and of course why he would offer help to his former enemies. (One of who killed him in Part l.)If you haven't seen his yet, I strongly suggest you have a copy of Part 3 "At World's End" on hand. You probably won't want to wait too long before you know what happens from here.
summary: Sympathetic Characters Who Can't All Win

reviewText: Oh and what a movie this is. There is something for everyone in the family with this movie, romance, action, drama, horror, adventure and fantasy. A quality of acting rivaling no other movie in recent times, except for the Rings trilogy, but that's another thing altogether. I have watched this movies so many times that I can't even keep track. This movie never gets boring. Johnny Depp is at the top of this career with this film!! A must see, many times over. A true classic! The cursed tale of a pirate ship's captain, marooned by his mutineering mates and left for dead on a desert isle. He returns with another ship, this time stolen from the Royal Navy, in order to reclaim his rightful command of the infamous Black Pearl, a ship so evil that hell itself spat back her dead. He is joined by the son of a murdered pirate ship's mate, a swordsman who's skill and craft are equal to that of Robin Hood himself. The boy is motivated by love for a woman, herself of royal blood and captured by those mutineering pirates of ill repute in order to release a curse cast upon them from the captured gold of the famous Spanish explorer and conquistador, Hernando Cortez. With the Royal Navy in hot pursuit of their stolen ship, the captain and the boy, along with another crew of pirates, make haste for the Black Pearl, execute a cunning plan, and live happily ever after. Well, not exactly like that but almost. This film is destined a classic because of the dry, witty comments, superb acting of the entire cast, outstanding writing and special effects, and it's about time someone put this swashbuckling story to film. Rated PG-13, which is the number of times you should see this movie.
summary: A tale of love, war and power

reviewText: `Pirates of the Caribbean - Dead Man's Chest' released on `06 is the highly anticipated second installment of the Captain Jack Sparrow trilogy. While Captain Jack and the film doesn't retain the humor and lighthearted charm of the first film, it does compensate for the loss of innocence with a dark, haunting Lovecraftian vision and some of the most amazing special effects to date. Wait till you see the Kraaken.Make no mistake `Dead Man's Chest' does have some flaws. It doesn't quite hold your attention as well as the first, there are some undeniable slow sections and the film is a little too long overall. However it still contains lots of witty lines of dialogue from your favorite pirate and a surprising number of unexpected twists in the plots. The ending is absolutely perfect leaving you breathless for installment three. Ah that Disney really knows how to do it, don't they. Not as good as the first film, but it doesn't miss by much.

reviewText: Back in 2003, when we really needed a great summer movie to get things going, we got "Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl," a surprising gem of a movie whose magic and fun was only overshadowed by the performance of Johnny Depp and a deep fascination with the beauty of Keira Knightley. The movie pretty much came out of nowhere and took millions of unsuspecting moviegoers by surprise. I, myself, was so amazed by the movie that I went back two more times over the 2 1/2 months that it remained in my theatre! So, needless to say, I'm a fan! When I heard that the sequel, "Dead Man's Chest" was on its way, I was undoubtedly excited.Then I saw the trailer.To me, the trailer made the movie seem like a hodgepodge of boring CG characters and bad acting from Orlando Bloom ("We have to go back for Jack...ok nevermind"). To say that I was disappointed would be a huge understatement. Furious and skeptical are, perhaps, better descriptors for the rage that consumed my soul. Despite this, I simply had to see the movie for myself, being a huge fan of everything the original movie had to offer.The movie begins, by almost all accounts, poorly. We find good ol' Elizabeth and Will are to be married but are arrested for their involvement in the escape of Jack Sparrow (seen in the original). Will eventually strikes a deal with Cutler Beckett, the operator of the East India Trading Company in Port Royal to go after Captain Jack and bargain with him to return to ensure the safe release of Elizabeth. Meanwhile, Elizabeth escapes, herself, and leaves in pursuit of Will. Jack Sparrow, all the while, is being hunted by the notorious Davy Jones, with whom he has a debt to settle. This is essentially the plot of the story. Stated plainly in a few sentences, it actually takes the movie about 45 minutes to get to this point and this is why the first part of the movie is so dull. There is hardly any action for this period of time, and it's quite painful to sit through. Needless to say, I was regretting my decision to see the movie. However, when it finally picks up, it REALLY picks up.The movie is filled with humor, just like the first, and Johnny Depp's performance is, once again, Oscar-quality (though the magic from the first film has worn off a little). There are numerous humorous references to the first movie, mostly about rum, which are funny at first but eventually wear a little thin. Additionally, most of the funny, quirky characters from the original have returned to serve as comic relief. It really is a fun, if not funny, movie.additionally, the action sequences in "Dead Man's Chest" are top notch. Where as the first film essentially involved a lot of sword-fighting and cannon-firing, the writers of DMC rightly made sure to mix things up a little this time around. There are, of course sword fights and cannons (it is, after all, a pirate movie), but there are other circumstances that are happening simultaneously that keep things fun and interesting. Possibly the greatest addition to the action is the kraaken, a giant squid (or octopus. I'm not entirely familiar with the mythological beast.) When it's around, its one of the coolest CG monsters to ever grace the big screen, perhaps even topping those in the Lord of the Rings Trilogy. Additionally, the kraaken is truly creepy, almost frightening, as it engulfs ships like candy.Another memorable newcomer is Davy Jones, played by Bill Nighy. When I saw the aforementioned trailer, Davy Jones looked ridiculous with his octopus beard. However, I must say that I was really impressed with his character. Nighy does a phenomenal job of making this otherwise plastic character seem utterly real and complex, and his performance is on the level of Depp's. Also, Bootstrap Bill, played by the always great Stellen Skarsgard, is another great character. As it turns out, Bootstrap, who we know died, is enslaved to work on Davy Jones' ship for an undisclosed amount of time. When he encounters his long-lost son, it really is a touching moment, and their relationship is really, at times, captivating. Additionally, the relationship between Will and Elizabeth is more interesting this time, as is the relationship between Elizabeth and Jack.Overall, the movie is nothing more than a popcorn movie; a fun, big, exciting, phenomenal popcorn movie. Anyone going in to see an Oscar-caliber movie is probably going to be disappointed. Pirates of the Caribbean has never sought to be an epic movie like the Lord of the Rings, or other trilogies. It is simply a fun summer movie, one that you will undoubtedly enjoy for years and years to come.Oh, and the aforementioned line in the trailer said by Will, it never actually happens. How about that?4 out of 5 Stars

reviewText: This being the second of the planned trilogy is somewhat more predictable. Second movies are always the toughest for directors since they have to spend much of it tying everything together for the first and the third. This doesn't allow as much time for creativity. In fact some parts seemed stretched to fill time in  this sequel. Don't get me wrong I enjoyed the movie, I just didn't have as much fun as in the first one. It made me think of other second movies that are dark like "Back to the Future 2", "Temple of Doom", and "The Empire Strikes Back". My wife and others have said they thought the special effects were great, but the barnacles and some of the makeup was just to creepy. Being as this is Disney family fare I tend to agree. This is not "The Ring" or "Thirteen Ghosts" so it does not need to have overly scary effects to get the job done. You want kids to enjoy it as well without having nightmares. The overall story is okay. I think a little more time on editing and comedy and less on makeup and effects would have been well spent. This time Captain Sparrow, played by Johnny Depp, owes Davey Jones his soul, and of course he isn't ready to pay up. The action and comedy were not as spontaneous. Rather than new fresh things, it felt like much of it was just carrying on from the first movie. I would still recommend seeing it and buying the DVD when it comes out. I am looking forward to seeing the third movie next year.

reviewText: Shiver me timbers, this film is an action-packed good time! All the original actors return, including Johnny Depp, Orlando Bloom, and Kiera Knightly, for this comedic action sequel to "Pirates of the Caribbean: Curse of the Black Pearl". The mythological/supernatural aspects of the film grow deeper, and we are introduced to intriguing new characters, such as the heartless Davy Jones, and "Bootstraps" Bill Turner (Will Turner's father who is cursed to serve Davy Jones).From undead monkeys (yes...the monkey from the previous film is still undead, even though everyone else who used to be cursed is not), to surprise endings, this film has it all. The plot may appear a little convoluted at first, but be patient...it gets better. Character relationships advance (is Elizabeth Swan truly meant to be with Will Turner? Or is she inexplicably drawn to Jack Sparrow?), in addition to incredible sword fights, and battles on the high seas. Aaaaargh, thats good stuff!While the plot of the 2nd film is more involved than it's predecessor, it still managed to garner a few laughs while at the same time exploring a new avenue in story-telling. The majority of comic relief is placed squarely on the shoulders of Johnny Depp's character, Captain Jack Sparrow, who mesmerizes the audience with his eccentric and hilarious interpretation of a scalawag pirate who has more heart than even he knows.The main problem that most movie-goers had with this film was that it lacks any real closure, and this is due largely in part to the fact that it ends in a cliffhanger. All of the actors were contracted to do 2 more films for the "Pirates of the Caribbean" franchise. The director, Gore Verbinski, tried to cut costs, and wait time between films, by filming the 2nd and the 3rd movies at the same time. Essentially, the 2nd and 3rd movies are really just one big movie that is cut in half. Unfortunately, the production crew hit a few too many bumps in the road, including having to shut down filming all together due to a slight problem with a hurricane down in the caribbean (come on...if *I* was the director, do you think I'd let a little tiny hurricane stop me?.....absolutely!). Because of the many problems that arose, they weren't able to complete the 3rd film in the time frame they meant to, meaning instead of releasing the 2nd film in the summer of 2006, and the 3rd film that winter, they had to settle for the 3rd film being released in the following summer of 2007. This put a bit of a damper on the whole timing of releases, to say the least.However, "Dead Man's Chest" still manages to keep the masses entertained, and adequately leaves them begging for more. The 2 disc collector's edition is loaded with special features for all the fans and movie buffs out there. The single disc edition has a couple special features on it, but not much, so you're much better off purchasing the 2 disc special edition.Bottom line: Witty, sharp, and entertaining. I think it will be much more appreciated when the 3rd film is released, and everything seen in this film makes more sense.Will Turner: "Finding this key will save Elizabeth?"Capt. Jack Sparrow: "How much do you know about Davy Jones?"Will Turner: "...not much."Capt. Jack Sparrow: "Then, yes. This will save her."
summary: Drink Up Me Hearty Yo Ho....Awesome Sequel to the Much Loved 1st Film

reviewText: On the day that Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley) is to be married to Will Turner (Orlando Bloom), a detachment of East India Company Marines, headed by the former Lieutenant (now Lord) Gillette, suddenly arrives with warrants for their arrest, based on the part they played in saving Captain Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) from the hangman's noose.  Though Elizabeth's father the Governor (Jonathan Pryce) protests that they are under *his* authority, not the King's, Gillette is adamant.  The only option he'll suggest is that Will fetch him Jack's peculiar compass (which never points north) and a strangely configured key.  If he does, he and Elizabeth will be freed and Jack will be furnished with letters of marque, making him a privateer of the crown.  Will doubts that Jack will be eager to give up his freedom, but he has no choice except to go along.  Jack, it turns out, has troubles of his own.  To gain a captaincy he made a bargain with Davy Jones (Bill Nighy), the demonic captain of the Flying Dutchman, who is now ready to demand payment.  Jack protests that a mutiny deprived him of 10 of his promised 13 years, but Davy isn't interested in excuses, and he wants Jack's soul.  Jack knows that if he can gain possession of Davy's heart--reputed to be locked away in an iron chest whose key is the same one Will is seeking--he can save himself, and even for old allies Will and Elizabeth he isn't willing to share.  But when Will discovers that his own father, Bootstrap Bill Turner (Stellan Skarsgard), is a member of Jones's crew of the damned, he resolves to obtain the heart himself and use it to kill Jones and free his crewmen.  Then former Commodore Norrington (Jack Davenport), who was cashiered from the Navy after twice failing to capture Jack, enters the picture, resolved that gaining the heart will help him "get his life back."  So now there's a three-way race for the heart--or maybe five, if you count Jones and his crew, who are trying to protect it, and our old friends the formerly-undead Pintel (Lee Arenberg) and Ragetti (Mackenzie Crook), who don't know what's in the chest but can plainly see that a lot of other people seem to want it.Convoluted though this plotline may sound, it all works out surprisingly well, with plenty of top-notch special effects and costumery (especially the design of Jones and his crew, all of whom partake of the characteristics of assorted sea creatures ranging from hermit crab to hammerhead shark); Jones himself is one of the best--one of his forearms is actually a giant lobster claw, but his head and face are based on some kind of tentacled univalve, possibly a nautilus, and the tentacles on it are in constant writhing, restless motion.  (He and his crew, and the gigantic Kraken he commands, may be a bit scary for the youngest kids, which is probably the reason for the rating.)  Add in a brush with a tribe of cannibals, storms, escapes, and wonderful swordfights, plus Depp recreating his slightly fey piratical character, and you have a very satisfying, if rather long (over two hours), adventure/fantasy movie.  Hans Zimmer provides a thrilling scorePirates Of The Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest.

reviewText: 2003's "Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl" was so entertaining that it was difficult to comprehend the possibility of failure. I was absolutely enthralled with that film: a cleverly designed action/adventure/ghost story whose freewheeling plot was second only to its incredible visuals and highly energetic pace (no small feat considering it was almost two and a half hours long). Everything about it was over the top in a way that most audiences can't get enough of, from choreographed swordfight sequences to frenetic sea battles to strategically placed one-liners. But I think most of the film's success is attributed to Johnny Depp's performance as the flamboyant Captain Jack Sparrow. Never in the history of pirate films has there been a character outrageous enough to hit the audience like a ton of bricks. Depp is known for his remarkable sense of perception, and for that alone, it's no small wonder that he was inspired by the mannerisms of rocker Keith Richards for the role (and as ridiculous as that may sound, keep in mind that it earned him an Oscar nomination for the first film).With an eventual total of over $600 million in worldwide box office, it became impossible to miss the telltale signs of a sequel. And now we have it. "Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest" is, quite simply, a lot of fun, retaining all of the qualities that made the first film such a winner. This is especially true of the cursed pirates, all of which undergo some digital enhancements. We were originally treated to a crew of undead pirates, left to walk the earth as decaying skeletons (as seen only in the moonlight) for stealing cursed Aztec gold. Now we're treated to new a shipload of cursed pirates, all of which supernaturally take on the characteristics of various marine animals (some examples: one has the head of a hammerhead shark while another has the exoskeleton of a crustacean). They're all in the service of Davy Jones (Bill Nighy), the one-legged, tentacle-faced captain of the Flying Dutchman. Apparently, he has a score to settle with Captain Sparrow, one that relates directly to his service on the Black Pearl. Thus, the waterlogged corpse of Bootstrap Bill Turner (Stellan Skarsgard) is sent to give Jack the dreaded Black Spot, a mark indicating that a debt needs to be repaid.This basic plot serves as the catalyst for score of subplots, and while they all come together nicely, they're also a little hard to follow at times. For one, there's the continuing saga of Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley). Their romance (and as it turns out, their wedding) is abruptly put on hold when both are arrested by the cold-hearted, conniving Lord Cutler Beckett (Tom Hollander). Supposedly, the charges are conspiring to help a wanted pirate escape. Of course, we all know whom he's referring to. From that alone, it becomes obvious he wants something more with Jack than to just catch him and lock him away. From what the audience can gather, Jack and Beckett have run into each other before, each one leaving a lasting impression on the other (and I mean that in more ways than one). Beckett then offers a way for Will and Elizabeth to be cleared of all charges: Will must track Jack down, retrieve his compass (the one that never points north), and give it to Beckett. (Why exactly does he want it? I suppose I could tell you, but that would take all the fun out of watching the movie, wouldn't it?)While Will sets out on his mission, Elizabeth makes plans of her own, ones that don't exactly coincide with those of her father (Jonathan Pryce). It's a good thing she's so headstrong; her escape and eventual search do wonders for enlivening the plot. (Granted, her methods aren't exactly realistic. Then again, nothing about this movie is.) And it couldn't happen at a better time, especially when it comes to another subplot directly involving Jack. After his meeting with Bootstrap, he takes his crew on a frantic quest around the Caribbean for a special key, one that fits into the lock of an equally special treasure chest (the Dead Man's Chest, the contents of which I won't reveal). He also tries his hardest to stay in shallow waters while sailing; Captain Jones has the ability to call upon the Kraken, a mythical sea beast of gigantic proportions, with long tentacles and breath that can only be compared to decaying corpses (and believe me when I say that this creature eventually makes its presence known). Any nautical foul ups could wind up costing Jack his very soul (let alone his very life).Even more subplots, characters, and locations work their way into the story, including an island of natives who worship Jack (and wish to show their devotion by killing him), the mysterious voodoo woman Tia Dalma (Naomie Harris), the reunion of Will and his father, and the unexpected return of Commodore Norrington (Jack Davenport). In one way or another, all the characters are connected to the Dead Man's Chest. Some are more desperate to reach it than others, and like any good treasure hunt story, some are just greedy enough to fight over it. An incredibly elaborate swordfight scene comes to mind; most of it is fought on a water wheel that barrels out of control down hills, through forests, and over cliffs.But this is the kind of movie that depends on intense action sequences. When it comes to a pirate movie, no one steps into the theater hoping to be intellectually stimulated. It's pure escapism, fueled by the need for entertainment and made to deliver exactly what it promises. In every sense, "Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest" most definitely delivers (especially in terms of its ending, with a surprising plot twist no one will see coming). As I've already said, it's really nothing more than a fun movie, meant to provide a few hours of nonstop enjoyment. While it doesn't manage to outdo its predecessor, it does remain on perfectly equal terms with it. That's a good thing, considering director Gore Verbinski and writers Ted Elliot and Terry Rossio got everything right the first time. It helped that they cleverly yet respectfully paid tribute to the Disney theme park attraction, reinterpreting some of the ride's most famous vignettes. They do the same thing for this new film, and if they're smart, they'll do it again for the third (which everyone knows is on the way).But I'm looking ahead when I should be focusing on this current film. I think everyone should focus on this film, not because of the special effects or the story (which are both excellent), but because of the entertainment factor. You just can't walk out of the theater feeling bored or unsatisfied (and this is in spite of its running time; a decent 150 minutes). It's definitely not a subtle movie, nor is it gentle or relaxed. But I loved every minute of it, and I think anyone with a playful side to their personality will too. It appeals to the youthful pirate enthusiast in us all, and it will leave you wishing that every film could be just as much fun.
summary: Yo Ho, Yo Ho, A Blockbuster Sequel For Me

reviewText: I'm always in awe of Johnny Depp's love of acting and his dedication to the roles he plays, especially when his character is the pirate Jack Sparrow. I wonder if playing pirate was a boyhood dream, for he gets into it so very well. This sequel is a smooth transition in keeping with the lineal plot of the first film while creating vivid, new characters to spin off on their own. The result is the fresh fringe of fantasy that Disney does so well. I especially love the bizarre sea creatures/sailors that serve the dead Davey Jones, captain of the ghost ship, the 'Flying Dutchman'. Though the end is clearly devised to set us up for another sequel (a trick that makes some viewers go 'Arrgg!'), the tension and absorbing sword fight scenes will satisfy action film seekers, and especially pirate fans, of all ages!Chrissy K. McVay - Author

reviewText: If you own a Blu-Ray player, this is a must-buy movie!  If you're just a fan of great movies overall, this is a must-buy movie!  Johnny Depp delivers in this non-stop action/adventure film, with loads of laughs as well.  You all should know what this flick is about, so I will not go into details on that.  If you are thinking of getting this movie on Blu-Ray but you already own it on SD-DVD, then that choice is up to you.  The picture is pristine on BD-DVD, and the audio quality is very clean and crisp.I own a very cheap HDTV and sound system that I purchaed for my 15-month tour here in Iraq and am blown away by the quality and differance compared to the standard-def version of this movie.  Simply put, if you own this movie already, it is entirely up to you if you wish to purchase and view it in high-def.  But for those of you who do not own any version of this flick then the decision should be a no-brainer-buy this now!Disney did a flawless job with this one, loaded with extras and bonus material galore.  I'm not really big on the extras and junk, but all Blu-Ray releases should be as jam packed as this one.  Way to go Disney and I look forward to future releases from you guys in the future!

reviewText: This sequel has given Captain Jack Sparrow, Elizabeth Swann and William Turner even more action sequences to perform. Compared with the Curse of the Black Pearl, the plot may not be that alluring. Yet the movie should be credited for daring to be different from the first. Instead of monsters under moonlight and treasure hunt, here we have sea battles in daylight, leviathan and cannibals on a beautiful island. Moreover, Keira Knightley has a bigger role here - more adventurous, sophisticated and she looks charming. So does Bill Nighy (Davy Jones) in his own way.  It is interesting to see some mutual attraction between Elizabeth and Captain Sparrow. To be frank, Johnny Depp is still the one to watch. Without this Captain Sparrow, the movie will be just another big budget summer movie.
