reviewText: Dead Man's Chest personally is a bit of a mystery: it's nowhere near the best film of the year yet it's the biggest hit despite the fact that it doesn't have a proper conclusion, it's a bit overlong and let's face it, it's a movie based on a theme park. People knew the film was going to be a hit yet few could've guessed that it would be as massive as it is. Is it a great movie? Sure, it's loaded with big action scenes and recalls old school films where it was just meant to entertain you, not question life or make you re-evaluate things.The marriage of Elizabeth and Will Turner is abruptly stopped when they're arrested for helping Captain Jack Sparrow. There's a deal Will makes though: get a compass(?) back from Jack and they'll be fine. Jack though has problems of his own as the legendary Davy Jones is after him and there's some business of getting a key which'll unlock the titular box. Have to give credit to the screenwriters for really trying to go nuts with the plot writing but when you have a multitude of characters going after the same thing which in and of itself is not a David Lynch-like plot makes it seem a bit stretched.What made the first one cool was that there was that "blockbuster" stamp on it: it was dumb and loud but man it was fun. It was also a bit too long for its own good and Dead Man's chest suffers from it as well. There's a whole section of the film devoted to Jack and Will escaping from a carniverous tribe and in the end, it didn't really amount to that much, but an action scene involving an American Gladiators-like globe was really fun. The stars arguably though is a trio: of course Johnny Depp as Sparrow, a kind-of effeminate tough guy Keith Richards who manages to get a laugh with a widening-then-squinting of his eyes. The others are 2 digital creations: the villain Davy Jones who's incredibly detailed and blends perfectly among every one else. While there's some noticeable CG shots, the octopus Jones uses is just awesome and creates some of the more busiest action scenes in the movie.Is there a problem with the movie? Well, the length and the plot are covered but it actually has to deal with the actual film itself as a sequel. Some trilogies like say Jurassic Park can be watched out-of-order at any times because the films work as stand-alones yet a recurring theme runs through all of them. Pirates takes a Matrix-like approach where the sequel sets up the next one. While it creates a better cliffhanger than Reloaded did, it also makes the movie feel like a really long first half of a movie rather than having it self-contained. While you can watch Black Pearl anytime you want, you almost have to watch Dead Man's Chest and then the upcoming World's End right afterwards.Dead Man's Chest is probably the best example of just fun for the sake of it. Sure films like Saving Private Ryan or Lawrence of Arabia has its action as well as character moments, Pirates is spectacle-driven and this film is proof of a good one.
summary: A perfect film where it won't hurt your brain
Title: N/A

reviewText: When 'Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl' hit theaters in Summer '03, it was that rare blockbuster that took everyone by surprise. It was fun, and that was the point-no strings attached. It didn't try to move you, or make hidden social commentaries (or blatant ones). It was bold in that it was pure, unadulterated adventure, with one caveat: Johnny Depp. Captain Jack Sparrow was the perfect main character to make this movie fly, because the hero was combined with both a villain (in essence) and the comic foil. Who else could make this oddity come to life and still be unable to accurately describe but Depp, whose made a career at this sort of thing and finally was able to bring it mainstream.It seems that for some reason, alot of people wanted something else entirely out of a 'Pirates' sequel. They wanted something original again, forgetting that the first one wasn't that original either, it was just fun (which is original these days, I suppose).'Pirates 2' gleefully repeats itself which was exactly what it should have done. I would have cringed at an insightful attempt at reinvinting this series, or even expanding it, and I've never wanted to see 'Pirates: Reloaded.' The only thing this sequel has up its' delicious sleeve is bigger, better and slimier, but it's basically the same hat, but one you want to wear again, and that is decidedly not a bad thing in this case.The only thing that is harder to swallow about 'Dead Man's Chest' than 'Black Pearl' is that 2 is definitely incomplete without the upcoming part 3, whereas the first film stood on its own. That either makes it less satisfying or more intriguing depending on your tastes and patience quotient.As far as performances and direction goes, it's the same cast and crew with a few new additions. Depp of course owns the whole thing, and is thankfully even more prominent here than in 'Pearl.' Orlando Bloom and Keira Knightley both come off as strong as before, adequately developing their characters.The major new addition is Davy Jones, a Gollum-like creation in that he is a brilliant mish-mash of CGI and human performance, neither of which could succeed without the other. Bill Nighy, as the human portion, devlishly overplays Davy to tentacled perfection,  remarkably matching his eyes and voice to Jones' slimy, octopus-like visage.Overall, 'Pirates 2' succeeds because it shamlessly knows what it is: a fun, summer blockbuster. Nothing more, certainly nothing less. This is the reason it, like its predecessor, succeeds on such a marvelous scale. It's not restrained by self-conciousness, but instead it's released by self-awareness and lack of insecurity.For those who can let go and have fun-treat yourself! Bring on part 3 me hearties, yo-ho!
summary: Pirates 2, like the original, delivers pure entertainment on a grand scale!

reviewText: After seeing all three of the "Pirates Of The Caribbean" films, I still think this second one was easily the best of the three. Most friends disagree with me on this, but.....hey, we all look at films differently.This was the best "Pirates" to me because it had some fascinating new characters; it did not have the sappy or annoying characters and romance of the first film; it had just the right mix of action and lulls and it had some super special-effects and humor. Much of that good stuff, unfortunately, was overdone in the third film.which also dragged on too long. This movie isn't short, but none of the action scenes go on too long and so the entire two-and-a-half hours is entertaining.Also (and this goes for all three of the movie) it looks absolutely super on Blu-Ray. It's the reason POTC is often shown in electronic stores promoting high-definition televisions because this film is about as good-looking as it gets. It's incredibly sharp.
summary: Best Of The 'Pirates' Trilogy, And Demo-Quality For Blu-Ray

reviewText: What a hoot!  This movie is an amazing amount of fun.  It has adventure, fresh takes on the pirate and sea story genre, has some wonderfully creepy villains, has some laugh out loud hilarity, and is even touching at times.  It is one of the most fun movies I have seen in quite awhile.  I recommend it to everyone who likes to have fun watching movies.  And it is a decent family film, but NOT for young children.  The PG-13 rating makes sense because some of the creepy / frightening moments are even effective for adults.If you haven't seen the first movie, I would suggest you see it before you see this one.  It isn't absolutely required, but you will know the characters in a way this films assumes you do when it opens.  The movie opens with Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and his lady love, Elizabeth Swann (Kiera Knightley) being arrested by Lord Beckett (Tom Hollander).  They are to be hanged for helping Capt. Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) escape in the first movie.  I don't want to go into the plot any more than this because every detail of it is so much fun to discover for the first time.  Let me just say that you will not expect or predict much of what happens in this movie.  Even when you think you know what is going to happen, what actually is put on the screen is fresh and that goes for the sound of the movie, as well.Even the Capt. Jack Sparrow of Johnny Depp is given new twists and depths and delights.  Sure, there is the Keith Richards aspect, but then there is the shish kabob.  You will have to see it to believe what you are seeing.  I do want to praise Bill Nighy for being able to bring so much expression to Davy Jones behind that octopus mask.  That is not easy to pull off, but he does.This is a movie worth seeing several times.
summary: Fresh delights - full of adventure.  It is able to be funny, creepy, and dramatic - not easy to pull off.

reviewText: The first Pirates of the Caribbean was a welcomed title with being fresh, fun, enjoyable and witty at the same time. Three years later Director Gore Verbinski releases the sequel: Dead Man's Chest. Here a new story, characters and plot takes place, however it's still fun and enjoyable as the first. The story is darker, more violent and a bit confusing at times but don't worry the plot is definitely not the strong suit of the franchise, as the film excels during its stunt pieces, which are impressively extravagant (in particular a three-way swordfight atop a mill wheel).Bloom shows a tad bit more brawn this time around, Knightley is even more pretty, Bill Nighy (Love, Actually) weighs in as Davy Jones and Stellan Skarsgrd appears as Will's undead father. But the film still belongs wholly to Depp, who in a reprise of his Oscar-nominated role gets all the belly laughs with a single widened eyeliner-ed gaze. He still runs like a cartoon hen and slurs like Keith Richards--and he's still one of the most fascinating movie characters in recent history.Dead man's chest is great and success at being a good sequel and is very entertaining for most of the 150 minutes.

reviewText: It's amazing, really, to see how the whole world went ga-ga over "Piates" this past year. From a Hollywood dirty word, to a hot-hot-hot property, pirate films are "IT" now. I must admit I wasn't too sure about this film. I loved the first film, "The Curse of the Black Pearl", but I knew it was a stand-alone piece, while the next two films in the series were meant as a two-parter. Meaning, of course, that there would be no real ending to the second film, only a lead-in to the third. That said, I enjoyed this film. There is a noticeably darker tone right off the bat, which never lets up, even in the lighter moments. From the ruined wedding to the cannibalistic natives to the evil Davey Jones himself, not to mention the darker side shown to miss Elizabeth Swann and the fall from grace of Commodore Norrington. True, the critcs were not kind to the movie, and yes the plot does meander all over. Again, the film is saved by the performance of Johnny Depp as CAPTAIN Jack Sparrow. One watches and really wonders if he is really that bad, or is he hiding a heart of tainted gold under all those swaggers and innuendoes? Whatever the case, Johnny Depp is mesmerizing in the role. You simply can't take your eyes off him. Kiera Knightley and Orlando Bloom give more rounded performances this time around, and Jack Davenport is much more intrigueing this time around as Norrington on the fast track downward. The films effects are top-notch, almost overwhelming. At times, it seemed that the director just thought of something else to pop in and wrote a scene for it. There are some excessive scenes, but also some tender ones as well. The scenes between Will Turner and his father, Boot Strap, are well done. All in all, this movie isn't as well-conceived as the first one, but it is entertaining, and does get you ready for the third film, the series finale. Certainly, the surprise at the end caught me off-guard, and has me ready for the wrap-up! Yo-Ho-HO!

reviewerName: Damian Gunn "The Dark One is I"
reviewText: Breaking just about every box-office record, the follow up to the blockbuster hit `The Curse of the Black Pearl' was bound to be smashed with criticism and ridicule, that's just the name of the game.  It never fails that critics are almost determined to find something wrong with a film appealing to the masses, only able to give good reviews to small independent type films that will never garner an audience (that's NOT at all saying I don't appreciate the independent films as anyone who's read my reviews will understand).  My only point here is that this film was almost cursed from the beginning to get a bad name.  On top of that, it's a sequel and sequel have a tendency of truly, of what's the word, sucking.  The thing though, is that this film is actually really good.  It has just as much action if not more, just as good special effects if not better and it's just as funny even if a lot of the jokes are recycled from the first film.Picking up where the first movie left off, we are immediately thrown into what is supposed to be a very happy day, the wedding of Elizabeth Swann (Knightly) and Will Turner (Bloom).  This event it interrupted and halted by the arrest of the two of them for their aid in Sparrows (Depp) escape from the previous film.  The only way for either of them to be released is if Will agrees to find Jack Sparrow and bring his compass back.  That compass though Sparrows only way of obtaining `The Dead Man's Chest' which will ensure his freedom from servitude aboard Davy Jones' (Bill Nighy) ship.Filled with action sequences to blow your mind and, despite what anyone says, a plot that is intriguing and thought provoking, not to mention the brilliant character work of Johnny Depp who delivers once again as Captain Jack Sparrow, I really can't understand why anyone would trash this film.  Sure it had the big hype and the successful predecessor that usually accompany any big disaster, but `Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest' lives up to the hype and the predecessor with ease.  With the same original cast, each of which bringing the same natural charm, and adding some very delightful new characters like Davy Jones (Bill Nighy is a complete scene stealer) as well as Naomie Harris who is brilliant as the Voodoo Priestess Tia Dalma, this latest installment of the franchise is a welcome slice of grade A entertainment!

reviewerName: Dan Blankenship "Author of THE RUNNING GIRL"
reviewText: A good movie that keeps the story, action, and dialogue flowing.  "Dead Man's Chest" is an excellent follow-up to the first "Pirates of the Caribbean" movie.While some have criticized this film as not having a good storyline, I do not believe that to be the case.  Anytime the plot involves saving a beautiful damsel from being executed, it is bound to have an intense and active story unravel on the screen.Elizabeth Swann will be executed unless Will Turner can retrieve a magical compass from the belt of Captain Jack Sparrow.  This leads to some harrowing attempts that leave the audience on the edge of their seats for most of the movie.Johnny Depp, Orlando Bloom, and Keira Knightley are enchanting on the screen together, managing to create chemistry in almost every scene in the movie.The sets, music, and special effects are superb and interesting.  The monster verses man scenes are intense and different than just about anything filmed in the past.Depp makes just about every movie he is in a joy to watch.  But his ability to transform himself into Captain Jack Sparrow is part of the draw to these two films.  And there is no doubt about it; Sparrow has become one of the most talked about film characters in quite a while.  Depp really shows his ability to deliver fun and energy in this latest installment of the trilogy.  I laughed out loud quite a bit throughout this film.Knightley and Bloom really picked it up a notch or two in this film, nearly stealing the show from Depp, which would have been the most amazing feat in movie history.Trust the people who tell you this film delivers the goods.  Ignore the people who try and say this movie falls short.  It is everything a movie should be.If you haven't seen "Dead Man's Chest", run out and see it at the movie theater.  This is one of the movies that plays to the entire audience and gets them involved in the action and comedy taking place on the large screen.See ya next review!
summary: Don't Wait Another Day!  See it on the BIG SCREEN!

reviewText: Pirates of the Caribbean does it again!  It has managed to be everything that a movie should be.  It has funny moments, some creepy and scary moments, moments of drama, and action-packed sequences that keep you on the edge of your seat.  And oh yeah, it has Johnny Depp, Kiera Knightley, and Orlando Bloom returning.  Johnny Depp is great AGAIN, and he's back with that great Jack Sparrow walk and talk.  His weirdness shines through and he is excellent and funny, especially in the scenes with the cannibals (loved the eyes that were painted over his eyelids!).  Davy Jones and Will Turner's father are especially gross looking (loved it) and is one of the highlights of the many, many special effects that Director Gore Verbinski has put in Dead Man's Chest.  Like I said, this movie has it all, and only suffers from being especially long (2 and a half hours), but let's face it: the first Pirates' movie was long and still very good.  So that's not too much of a problem.  The only other problem is that the ending felt a little rushed and left you with many unanswered questions.  On the other hand, I think that this was done because of a third Pirates of the Caribbean that will come up.  They wanted to make it a cliffhanger.  All in all, this is a highly recommended movie and looks good on the BIG SCREEN!
summary: Very long but very good - NO SPOILERS!

reviewText: Cap'n Jack Sparrow is back, with his crew of sea-loving thugs, including Will Turner and the lovely Elizabeth Swann in this sequel to the smash hit "Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl".  I, like everyone else who enjoyed the first film, have been looking forward to the return of the wickedly funny pirate captain and the swashbuckling adventures that won us over a few years ago.  Though I didn't hate this film, I have to admit I was disappointed with this second feature.  While the first was fresh and charming, this sequel seems to rely too heavily on the special effects (which are quite good, I won't deny!) and a rather weak story that left me wishing they had taken a little more time and invested in a plot that really pulled me into the movie.Johnny Depp is good, as usual, as Captain Jack but Orlando Bloom and Keira Knightly, with all their glowing beauty in tact, just don't achieve their character's charisma the second time around.  Davy Jones is an interesting villain and an amazing CGI creation but he just doesn't pack the punch of Geoffery Rush's Captain Barbossa.  Davy Jones' cronies are interesting CGI creations as well, not to mention the Kraken, that feared "beasty" with tenacles that can drag an entire ship into the murky depths.  Visually, the film is stunning and the cinematography is beautiful but pretty pictures does not a great film make!Thankfully, this film is a bridge to the final movie in the triology, "Pirates of the Caribbean:  At World's End".  The ending definitely leaves the door open for the beginning of the third with a very welcome surprise appearance.  With the confirmed appearance of Keith Richards as Jack's father and the faith I have in Gore Verbinski and Johnny Depp, I believe we will see a better movie than this next year in May.  If you are a fan of Johnny Depp and the original film, you will still want to see this film on the big screen.  However, one trip to the theater is enough for this one.  The original I saw a couple of times on the big screen.  While Pirates has done gangbusters at the box office this weekend (an estimated 132 million, breaking all records) you would do better to see "Superman Returns" or "The Devil Wears Prada", both better movies than this one.  Recommended if you have nothing better to do on a Sunday afternoon!

reviewText: I would give this movie 3.5 stars because while it is a fun action movie like the first one, it has issues. Entire sequences feel unnecessary and some of the recycled dialog seems out of place. Still, the action was on par with the first and the special effects were even better. If you enjoyed the first movie and are looking for more of the same, this sequel does deliver.Right away, Elizabeth and Will Turner are in trouble - arrested before their wedding for having helped Captain Jack Sparrow escape (as seen in the first movie). Lord Cutler Beckett from the East India Trading Company says they are free to go if they can get him the special compass which Sparrow has. Will goes off in search of Jack, who has encountered his own new problems. Having made a deal with Davy Jones to obtain the Black Pearl years ago, Jack must now pay up by serving on Davy Jones' ship for 100 years or face the Kraken, a huge sea creature which destroys ships. Ever the pirate, Jack tries to find a way around it and searches for the Dead Man's Chest where Davy Jones has hidden his heart. Elizabeth soon goes off in search of Will, who has ended up on Jones' ship in search of the key for the Chest. Ex-Commodore Norrington also shows up again, this time disgraced and on the run as well.The special effects were great, especially the portrayal of Davy Jones and his crew who all looked like half human, half sea creatures. The Kraken - basically a large octopus - was okay but could've been better. For a period of time, the movie shows Jack and his crew captives of natives on an island from which they must escape. While it provided a couple humorous moments, this entire sequence felt unnecessary. It made the movie longer than it needed to be. They also tried to recycle some of the more humorous and popular lines from the first one, which worked in places but felt too forced in others.For me the highlight was a rather entertaining sequence with Jack, Will, and Norrington all dueling one another for their own self-interests. In general, the actors did the best they could with what they had; however, this sequel didn't seem as well-written as the first. The movie does maintain the same sense of humor and doesn't take itself too seriously (nor should the viewer). And the ending did leave me wanting to see the third film in the series.
summary: Silly fun like the first, but not as good

reviewText: While I am the first to admit that I was clamoring for a longer Pirates of the Carribean after the first movie sped along at breakneck pace and seemed to end much too soon, I now wish that dead Man's Chest was shorter. Depp is way more than competent and as supremely entertaining as he was in the first film, but the story drags on and on through many unnecessary scenes and is ridden with more plot holes than Jack Sparrow's wardrobe after a swordfight. There is more tedium which retracts the swashbuckling fun of the first film and the danger is less apparent in spite of a computer generated black pearl wrecking octopus the size of the national debt. The film has plenty to laugh about though, and entertainment is what a film like this is really about, so the fun value is still high, but Dead Man's Chest needs quite a bit more conniving on the part of the writers to bring out the abundant treasure we saw in Black Pearl. 3.25 stars

reviewText: Once Gore Verbinski completed his almost masterpiece POTC: Curse of the Black Pearl, a sequel was totally inevitable. Many stuffy people said "Just another exploitation", I hate when people do that, there just so boring and judgemental. I, along with many true fans of the original, said "OH Yeah!". Our faithfulness to the series did not go unrewarded, if you truly are a 'Pirates' fan you will like this sequel.Many critics claimed this was "too confusing", the truth behind most of these cases, is that the critics had no faith in the movie, thus they didn't make any attempts to try to understand the movies plot thus it quote-unquote "confused them". If these critics had actually made a proper analysis of the movie, a good many more of them would have said "Hey it's actually pretty good".The acting as well of the plot of this movie is equal to this first. The music for this one replaces the happy shwashbuckling themes from the first and replaces them with more slow and haunting themes, to fit the films darker more thought provoking style.The visual effects for this film are easily the best effects for a movie as a whole, I have ever seen, only to be outdone by it sequel.If you truly like Pirates, I can 80% assure you, you will like this movie.8/10 stars
summary: It suffers from people's unreasonable dislike of sequels

reviewText: This movie was simply amazing in picture quality and sound. I had already owned Pirates of the Caribbean Dead Man's Chest on standard DVD. When I compared the standard DVD with the Blu-ray version the Blu-ray outperforms on all levels. The scenes in the movie where you see the islands and ships sailing the ocean were very beautiful. Simply put everything looks life like in this Blu-ray movie. Also when watching Blu-ray scenes Davy Jones and his crew look very real. reviewText: I'm not quite sure what began the trilogy trend, though I have a guess.For movies, it was probably Star Wars. Star Wars, itself, likely was a trilogy to follow in the footsteps of the Lord of the Rings. Interestingly, Star Wars was originally conceptualized as a trilogy of trilogies (9 parts, comprising three sets). The first number of book series made from the Star Wars universe all had to be trilogies, too (like the Zahn series).Whatever the origin, the fact is that any book or movie today which touches on the fantasy/sci-fi universe *must* be a trilogy. It's expected.While Pirates of the Caribbean is only roughly fantasy, it certainly draws on the same sort of fan base. And, sadly, it suffers from the same disease. As soon as the first movie was successful, its backers *didn't* say: "Ooh! A hit! We should make a sequel"; what they said, instead, was: "Ooh! A hit! We should make it a trilogy!"Why? Why two more films, and not just one more? Was it, like George Lucas, that they'd already planned out an entire series, and so Dead Man's Chest was already a vital part in the larger, overall plot? Was it like Tolkien who, ironically, never envisioned the Lord of the Rings as a trilogy--did they simply write one huge movie that had to be divided into three parts so that audiences could view it comfortably?No. Pirates of the Caribbean, like the Matrix debacle of a few years back, is a trilogy simply because it is expected of them. And, watching this second film, you can tell.Dead Man's Chest is going through the motions. And there are, apparenly, a lot of motions to be gone through--this is a long film, clocking in at about 2 and 1/2 hours. It concerns that lovable rogue Captain Jack Sparrow as he does his damndest to escape the business end of the deal he'd made with Davy Jones--100 years of servitude on board his barnacled ship. Sparrow seeks the "Dead Man's Chest" which holds a power over Jones, while other players (i.e. Turner and Norrington, naturally) seek the same Chest for their own purposes. Adventure and hilarity ensue. Kind of.The plot of this movie is stretched rather thin, and cannot support the incredible running time. It's almost as though they'd taken half of what might be a good idea, and tried to make it into an entire, feature-length movie. It's propped up with some very long action sequences (much like Matrix Reloaded) which, I have to admit, are pretty frikken rad and inventive. Those action sequences are the best part of this film, excepting for 14 year old ladies who would probably vote Depp and Bloom as the best parts, without even needing to see it.The characters, themselves, don't get a lot of dialogue time with one another because they're all separated for most of the picture. It's a shame, too, because their interactions were such a strong part of the first. Their characters kind of need one another to play off of, and so Turner and Swann and even Sparrow all seem less charming, and less interesting, while off on their own adventures.The humor is intermittent, though the two "chorus" pirates (one of which is Mackenzie Crook--Gareth from the original BBC version of The Office!) are wonderfully funny, all the way through.All in all, I think it's a shame that they tried to stretch this out into three movies. It's clear from watching Dead Man's Chest that they really didn't have a whole lot to say in this film (there are only a handful of moments that really matter, and most of those come at the very end of the film, to set up the third). And so, instead, they just have the characters running around, telling jokes and getting into various awkward situations because the writers feel impelled to fill the time somehow. It weakens the characters, makes this movie feel long to sit through and hurts the franchise, itself.The Curse of the Black Pearl was wonderful--a five star film. This one only deserves three. I sincerely hope (because I'm going to be in the theater with all of you, watching it) that the third movie manages to reclaim this series' once-held substantial merits.

reviewText: Pirates of the Carribean 2 is funny, creepy, scary, tense, adventurous, slimy, gross and magical. Johnny Depp is once again superb as the mincing pirate captain, and Keira Knightly and Orlando Bloom are worthy back ups to Depp. As the movie starts, Knightly is left waiting for Bloom at the altar, only to find that they both have warrants out for their arrest for aiding in the escape of Captain Jack Sparrow. Their lives will be spared, however, if they can find a key and a hidden chest--- and the adventure is off!Let me just say it for the record that Johnny Depp is an absolute genius and the other actors n the movie provide excellent back up support for him. It's definitely his movie, but it takes all of the cast to carry it off. Some of the scenes have absolutely got to be the funniest in movie history--particularly the one where Bloom and some of the other pirates are suspended in a giant ball made of bones over a deep ravine. Watch the movie--you'll laugh your head off and bite your fingernails, all in one evening!
summary: Yo Ho Ho! The Pirate's Movie for Me!

reviewText: The sets, makeup, special effects and the Dominica and Bahamas' locations for this movie are great, but the story is the weakest link in the chain, and it brings the whole movie down. The star studded cast can't revive it, and even Johnny Depp poonce prancing through his role as Captain Jack becomes a joke overdone.The DVD extras include a great documentary on the making of Dead Man's Chest. The main challenge the director and producer had to contend with was a tight shooting schedule and the lack of final script. Parts of the movie were being shot before the story was completed. It shows. Hiding this weakness behinds lots of swash and buckle doesn't make it go away. The "Ask a Ninja" on-line review is surprisingly spot on.The third (and final?) episode of the Pirates trilogy hopefully will make amends.

reviewText: This is probably my favorite of the four Pirates of the Caribbean movies. The first one was a revelation but it really seemed to lose direction at the half way point and descended into chaos. `Dead Man's Chest' is able to start right in with already established characters and get the action going fast. Elizabeth and Will are about to get married when Lord Beckett interrupts threatening to execute the two for aiding and abetting Jack Sparrow unless Will finds and retrieves Sparrows magic compass in order to locate Davy Jones treasure chest. Meanwhile Jack Sparrow has regained the Black Pearl but the thirty year lease is up on the ship and Davy Jones is expecting payment in full which includes Sparrow's soul in servitude.Say what you will about these movies the action scenes by Gore Verbinski are absolutely amazing.  To get a sense of how good Verbinski's action and comedic timing are check out Rob Marshall's "On Stranger Tides"  to see an earnest but failed attempt to emulate Verbinski's style.  It should be no surprise the Marshall will not be returning for the fifth film. The escape by Sparrow, Turner and the crew of the Black Pearl from the cannibals on Pelegosto is one of the most uproariously brilliant action sequences I have ever seen.  Like the later swordfight on the mill wheel both are very long but so well done that they never outstay their welcome.  These are the kinds of scenes that come to mind of when I think of popcorn, sodas and summer blockbusters. These movies are this generations "Back to the Future" or "Indiana Jones" where you can just sit back and thrill at the spectacle on the screen. I would contrast these films with the other mega lucrative franchise, The Transformers, which lacks all the charm present here.Dead Man's Chest is one of the most expensive movies ever but in this case it's money well spent. When the Flying Dutchman rises from the ocean it is a sight to behold and the whole design of the ship is beautiful and terrifying. Nearly eight years later the CGI still looks cutting edge. Davy Jones and his hybrid human/sea life crew are all human actors with added CGI but this is how one does CGI correctly. I had assumed these were costumes because they look so stunning. The non CGI scenes of islands and pirate ships are just as gorgeous if not more so and they make me wish I were on location with the cast. The only really dodgy parts of the CGI were when the Kraken attacks and things go all video gamey. Maybe this is why the Kraken is dispatched in the follow up film off screen.Whoever did the casting deserves a gold medal. From the main trio of Depp, Bloom and Knightley to the secondary characters (Nighy, Hollander, Pryce etc..) and the smaller roles this is fantastic casting from top to bottom.  I can't say I love the way every character is used. In particular this is the film where Elizabeth Swann inexplicably becomes a master swordsmen and things only go downhill in the third film.  So is there anything wrong with this film? Yes, and it's all in the plot. It is overly complicated and character motivations are all over the place. I've watched the film more than a couple of times and I'm still confused by many of the characters actions. It's far from the worst plot ever and there are legitimate emotional moments but it could have used some trimming and tightening up.Overall this is a very fun movie. The biggest issue, perhaps, is that it is only the first half of the story with the conclusion in the vastly inferior At World's End. This is certainly not a movie series for everyone and I know several people who despise it but I love pirates and I think it has enough fun and excitement to make it very watchable while avoiding most of the dumbness of the typical Jerry Bruckheimer film.
summary: Arguably The Best in The Series

reviewText: Johnny Depp's preening cheekiness as Captain Jack Sparrow continues to be the invaluable glue that holds together this action-packed, over-the-top movie, the second in a trilogy inspired by the well-loved, nearly forty year-old ride in Disneyland. The jam-packed story picks up relatively soon after the point where the last one left off with spunky Elizabeth Swann about to marry adventurer Will Turner. Complications come in the form of British East India Trading Company's Lord Cutler Beckett, who charges the couple with conspiring to help Sparrow escape from the company's clutches. Death is their fate unless they can secure Sparrow's magical compass for Beckett. Sparrow has troubles of his own as he has sold his soul to the legendary dawn-of-the-dead pirate, Davy Jones, fabled captain of the Flying Dutchman, in exchange for the right to command his vessel, the Black Pearl. Sparrow's one option is to find the key to a chest containing Jones' still-beating heart.The storylines eventually collide but not before the main characters run into a voodoo woman, Tia Dalma, full of mystical advice on how to get the key; Elizabeth's jilted swain, Commodore James Norrington, out for revenge against Will; Will's lost-soul father, Bootstrap Bill Turner, somewhere between life and death; and a mammoth, octopus-like sea monster named Kraker. After a shaky start with far too much exposition, director Gore Verbinski gets the momentum finally going in the second hour with heart-racing action escalating in both scope and absurdity, although screenwriters Ted Elliott and Terry Rossio tend to layer all the developments in a most convoluted manner. Despite the pacing problems, what I do like about the film is its persistently irreverent tone and the way death is treated not as the final end but as a relative inconvenience. From my perspective, this is what makes the movie's spirit come alive for a contemporary viewer.Beyond Depp's devilishly clever performance, the real star is unsurprisingly the CGI-generated special effects, whether it's Jones and his ocean-morphed crew of half men/half sea creatures (the hammerhead shark is a particularly creepy figure to watch); Kraker and its engulfing destruction (though this gets repetitive in the story); or the variety of memorable action set pieces, such as the Black Pearl crew swinging in a ravine to escape their suspended spherical cages, or concurrently, Sparrow precariously maneuvering a pole where he inadvertently becomes part of a fruit shish kebob. My favorite set piece is the runaway waterwheel on the island where Will, Norrington and Sparrow are preoccupied with their swashbuckling and the search for the chest. The audacious silliness of these action sequences is what keeps the movie afloat.Both Keira Knightley and Orlando Bloom return from the first film as Elizabeth and Will. Looking beautiful, even disguised as a boy, Knightley has been promoted into more of an action role here and handles her part with aplomb. Bloom is still a relatively colorless presence but fulfills the heroic dimensions of the part almost by default. As Davy Jones, Bill Nighy is able to create an intriguing character underneath the CGI-generated visage of octopus tentacles, and in a tribute to Jules Verne's "20,000 Leagues Under the Sea", has a great scene where he plays the numerous keys of a pipe organ all at once. Granted, at 150 minutes, the epic movie does run too long for the story it tells, and the lumbering series of climaxes seems excessive. Regardless, it's still grand fun thanks to Depp and the oozing, barnacle-encrusted realism of the CGI effects.
summary: Shiver Me Timbers! Captain Jack Returns in a Lumbering Adventure That Improves in the Second Half

reviewText: I see this movie, as others have before me, as Part I of two. Dead Man's Chest left many questions open that hopefully will be resolved in the third film. How did Captain Barbossa become resurrected? Will Jack survive? There are two former castmates of the Black Pearl, but nobody ever stops to think that they're the enemy. The priates have, in a ddition, become caricatures of themselves. Norrigton, formerly Commodore, is reduced to perpetual sarcasm in the sequel. There's also an officer of the East India Trading Company, whose immense dislike of Governor Swan, his daughter and her fiancee is unexplained.On the good side, Bill Nighy is excellent as Davey Jones, the "dead man" of the title. Come back from the grave is Will Turner's father, now a crew member of Jones's Flying Dutchman. Jack Sparrow once again hijacks Will and involves him in an adventure in which Jack must save his own soul. Then comes the requisite part, where the foolish Will realizes that he's been duped and sulks in a way that only Orlando Bloom can.There are several scenes which I thought were ridiculous. First of all, I hated the giant squid, Kracken. Second, the sword fight between Norrington, Jack, and Will, while Elizabeth stands to the side and shouts at them. Also, the sceme with the natives, where Jack becomes thier chief.I loved the first film--really, I did. I think the intention was that Will and Elizabeth would end up happily ever after, and that would be it. But this movie continues their story, as well as that of Jack Sparrow. Jack as played by Johhy Depp is as funny as ever, but the other two main characters fall flat. Its true what they say: the sequel is never as good as the first.

reviewText: To be frank, I had to see this movie twice, as there is so much going on, so many seemingly innocuous elements, I just had to see it again in order to get some idea of what the final movie will be about!  On first view, 'Dead Man's Chest' appears to be a really over the top film with a lot of elements that initially I didn't care for, such as the Davy Jones character and his 'crew' (remarked upon by other reviewers).  A similar situation happened with the Indiana Jones movies, where the second film was so full of action it pretty much rolled over the storyline and character development.  But I urge all viewers of 'Dead Man's Chest' to be patient, and see it again!  There is a lot going on that you haven't realised!  Much darker in tone than 'Black Pearl,' 'Dead Man's Chest' is full of really tragic characters living in Hells of their own making. The creation of sympathetic villains is one of the great talents of the 'Pirates' writing team, and 'Dead Man's Chest' is no exception.  Davy Jones, an apparently heartless (literally!)monster bartering for the souls of his victims,is actually a soul in the constant torment of unrequited love, and since his world (as he sees it) is one of eternal anguish, it is his mission in 'unlife' to ensure as many others as possible share his fate and his misery.  Commodore Norrington, his naval career in shreds and love lost is another, and of course, Jack Sparrow, living in constant fear of the bargain he made many years ago with Davy Jones awaits his apparently inevitable fate.  And to top it off, all of them, even Will and Elizabeth, become the tools and victims of an even more calculating and truly evil monster, the East India Trading Company!  How will all of this be resolved?  You will just have to wait until the final sequel comes out Summer of 07!  But just for the fun of it, here is what I predict will be revealed in the sequel.... Jack Sparrow survives and escapes the belly of the Kraken by means of a magic ring that he stole from the voodoo queen (and possibly his beloved hat has certain properties as well).  The voodoo queen turns out to be the lost love of Davy Jones (each has half of a musicbox locket in the shape of a heart).  Commodore Norrington is actually on a secret mission for the government to bust the East India Company, and Jack Sparrow's father (who gave him the drawing of the key) is imprisoned by the East India Company, but is under the same sentence as Jack Sparrow having somehow escaped Davy Jones.  Captain Barbosa has been resurrected by the voodoo queen (by means of the undead monkey) in order to lead the expedition to rescue Jack Sparrow and allow her to reunite with Davy Jones, and they will find their way because Elizabeth has stolen the compass from Jack Sparrow, and everybody will gang up on the East India Company at the end. Of course, how the relationship between Sparrow and Elizabeth is decided is still up for grabs!

reviewText: Apparently more is alot freakin' more. (No Spoilers Included)The open-ended three sentence summary: Jack, Will, and Elizabeth are all fugitives from the East India Trading Company. Jack is also hiding from Davy Jones, who wants his soul. Each of them are trying to get a different thing to save their/their other friends' hydes. Following so far? I didn't think so.Content Inappropriate for All Ages: A little pirate-like bad language, creepy nasty barnacle-things, blood, a few indirect references to "adult situations", lots of drinking, violence of many kinds, cannabilism, guts, and explosions.Characters: 3 of 5 stars. Sure Jack Sparrow is back. And he's the same as ever. There is actually a bit of character development in Elizabeth, most notably. Jack has a tiny bit, and a few of the minor characters as well. But the film fails miserably on one important front: Will Turner. He has basically no character in this film at all. He is considerally more clever, but much more bland.Plot: 3 of 5 stars. Okay, get ready for all the memorable jokes from the last movie: you'll be seeing them again shortly. The plot, laden with negotiations, was just too thick to follow here. Especially with all the sword fighting and explosions to distract you. There were a few sequences that served no plot point, but were included for entertainment value. (You'll know what I mean)Cinematography: 3.5 of 5 stars. Liked the special effects, sets, staging, choreography, and props in the first movie? So did I. One thing I must note, the special effects were much better in this movie. But they went completely over the top. It's all just too detailed, too graphic for me to digest and appreciate. It actually was a little garish after the first hour and a half.Music: 5 of 5 stars. Hans Zimmer bangs out another great swashbuckling score with a memorable and popular theme. The "Davy Jones organ part" is really memorable.Impact: 3 of 5 stars. Though it kept my attention, I could still tell that it was 20 minutes too long. I wasn't too deeply impacted, mostly because of the thin characterizations. Still, I have to admit it was fun to watch. There were some memorable action/humor sequences. But be forewarned: the ending leaves you hanging, so you'll have to see "Pirates 3" if you want to know what happens next. A shameless marketing ploy. Grreeeaattt.And since I came to see Keira Knightley wear a cool pirate hat and completely "lose it" onscreen, I was happy.All in all, 3 of 5 stars.
summary: Review: Pirates of the Caribbean - Dead Man's Chest

reviewText: The first Pirates of the Caribbean was very entertaining, action packed, humorous and worth seeing but was more of a childrens film. Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest however, is more of the same but much better. Disney still stuck to what they did best in the first Pirates of the Caribbean and enhanced it. The second enstallment is far more better than the first one. With a better story, more action, even more comedy and bucket loads of amazing special FX, this really entertains the kids and even the adults.The action in DMC is literally on steriods. From trying to escape cannibals in a sphere cage made of bones to fighting of a hoard of sea men who have shark heads and crap claws for hands.The comedy of coarse is still great with Johnny Depp (Captain Jack Sparrow) as the joker of the movie and Orlando Bloom (William Turner) providing most of the action and this time, less of the comedy.One thing that does imediately stands out in this movie, is the truely amazing and spectacular SFX. CGI is used for almost everything in this movie. Bill Nighy's character,(the villian) Davy Jones, is completly covered in CGI fish related anotomy from a giant crap claw for a hand to an octopus for a head with moving tentacles acting as a beard. The design of Davy Jones is very impressive and at times looks like prostetics. Even Davy Jones' ship (The Flying Dutchman) and crew are CGI related, as the crew have sworn an oath to Davy Jones, that they have now become apart of the fish-like ship. The Flying Dutchman can also dive under water like a submarine. One CGI acheivement that I have to talk about is the gigantic mythological Kraken that Davy Jones can command at any time. This huge creature is an awsome sight to see on a cinema screen. With a bellowing sound as it rises from the deep sea and a thundering roar as it destroys ships and eats helpless crew members, the impressive Kraken is a character of its own. The Kraken attacks are very impressive action scenes and imediately fit into a summer blockbuster like this.The only negative thing I can say about this movie is the overly long and ridiculous sword fight on a hugh wheel thats just not entertaining.Holding the top position as the 'Highest Grossing Blockbuster Yet' at $55 million, Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest has lived up to its hype as one of the most enjoyable movies I have seen this summer so far. The sudden ending also makes way for a 3rd Pirates of the Caribbean, which will continue the adventure to destroy Davy Jones and his powerful Kraken.Along with a great musical score from Hans Zimmer, Pirates of the Caribbean 2 is a great summer blockbuster that the kids and adults WILL enjoy. A highly recommended and enjoyable movie that will most defenitly not dissapoint.
summary: The Quest for the Heart of Davy Jones.

reviewText: The first movie was incredible.  I actually did not go out of my way to see it but happened upon "The Curse of the Black Pearl" at a neighbors house one day on cable.  I instantly fell in love with Jack Sparrow, and have managed to sit through it at least a dozen times.I had hoped with all my heart that Dead Mans Chest would not let me down.  I wanted to see a stand alone film, more adventures of Wil, Elizabeth, Jack Sparrow, and whoever else they cared to include with a nice flow, clean story line, and an ENDING.This I didn't get.  Instead I get part one of a two part adventure in their lives, and now I'm forced to wait like a year to find out where its going to go.I was actually buying it for the most part until Elizabeth started hitting on Jack... its just not right....What bothers me most?  They could easily have given me a nice stand alone movie that I'd love watching over and over even without the first (and upcoming installments) like I would say.. Batman.  Batman never gets boring.  Instead they gave me an insane longing for the next issue when it just wasn't that interesting to begin with, and will probably disappoint me more than this one has like... the Matrix.If you're a movie fan and a Depp fan, definitely see it.  If you think you can live without it.... live without it (at least until part 3 is released, then watch them together).

reviewText: There's usually a lot of reviews from U.S. viewers and relatively few from European viewers at Amazon. Let's try to set that right a little. Pirates Of The Caribbean 2, or in short Pirates 2, rocks !!! Like its predecessor did (Pirates 1). The pace is even more fast and furious (pardon my pun). It stars even more exotic, sometimes frightening or repulsive figures, like Davy Jones and Co. and Bootstrap Bill. For pure entertainment value, it is an excellent, smartly put together movie. I watched it in the movie theater together with my 13-year old son. We both enjoyed it tremendously. Everything is done with so much class and care for detail and sense of humour. As it ought to be, if you have a budget of well over $ 200 million to spend. We specifically liked The Flying Dutchman and its crew. OK, so there are a few holes in the script and at certain points the explanation lacks. Not a little, but a lot ! But who cares ? Explaining it all would have necessitated a fourth movie. Not that we would have minded, though. In all Pirates 2 is a delicious, almost 2,5 hour rollercoaster ride, with Johnny Depp who carries the whole movie almost alone (as he did the previous part of the saga). With Captain Jack Sparrow he has created a movie figure that has already become legendary in its own time and will become a classic for the ages for sure. Captain Jack's every line was a feast in itself. We both can't wait for Pirates 3 to come out and hope that the DVD-edition for home viewing will come soon and equipped with lots of savvy extra's. The cliffhanger ending in itself is not too bad (I see similarities with the search for Han Solo in the Star Wars saga), but in my opinion the film could have been even better if it had had more of a closure.

reviewText: When I titled my 5-star review of the first move,Pirates of the Caribbean - The Curse of the Black Pearl, "Worst Idea for a Movie Ever", I was being ironic, but with the title of THIS review, I am, sadly, only slightly exaggerating. Towards the end of that review I wrote:"The question that cannot be answered yet is whether the creators understand why it worked. With two back-to-back sequels in the works will this be anotherBack to the Future, with two marvelous sequels or anotherThe Matrix, with two terrible sequels that leave you convinced the first movie was just a fluke? We'll know soon."Now we know part of the answer, and it doesn't look good. Despite reassembling the talent, despite a lavish budget that produced some truly gorgeous images, and despite some great new characters and a number of intriguing plot points that may yet pay off in the finale, Disney has produced only a partial success that cannot stand on its own and depends on a great third movie to redeem it. In fact this movie is proof of the old movie axiom I just made up: "Live by the last minute rewrite; die by the last minute rewrite."As the screenwriters' commentary track on the first movie DVD makes clear, it was something of a miracle that ANY sort of script emerged from the chaotic mess of that star-crossed creative process, much less one as brilliant as it turned out to be. The second trip back to the same well was much less successful, at least based on this first of the back-to-back sequels. In this case the bonus videos chronicling the production process are remarkably revealing, clearly showing the director's barely controlled frustration at the STILL nonexistent script while the two writers are joking (?) about how they prefer not to submit a first draft until it is too late to request a rewrite. They ended up still madly writing away WHILE ON LOCATION so that the director could better keep an eye on them! Probably as a result they made three major mistakes, each of which cost this movie a star IMHO.1. Don't ruin the ending of the first movie! Of course I realize that when no sequel is originally planned one has to come up with SOMETHING to justify tossing the characters we all want to see again back into action again, but you should be careful not to COMPLETELY destroy the ending of the original. At the end of POTC I, Will and Elizabeth are reunited, intending to be wed; Jack and his crew of miscreants are free, intending to recover the NON-cursed treasure that will set them up for life... or one Heck of a weekend; and Commodore Norrington has removed the ramrod up his..., er, backside long enough to give his blessing to Will and Elizabeth and grant Jack a one-day head start, probably hoping he'll take the hint and find a new line of work, while Norrington takes what solace he can from a successful career. So how does POTC II start up? With Will and Elizabeth arrested on their wedding day for their part in Jack's escape, with all that treasure deus ex machina-ed into oblivion, and with Norrington sunk while chasing Jack, disgraced, cashiered, and now a washed up drunk.2. Don't make the likable characters unlikable! Arguably the main reason for a sequel is to spend some more time with characters we've grown to know and love, though there are the occasional villains we want to see more of, too, which POTC II BEGINS to deliver by the way. Unfortunately POTC II is pretty hard on its "good guys". Norrington has become bitter, cynical, and corrupt, and his unrequited love for Elizabeth has turned into hatred, or worse, contempt. Elizabeth, who had made up her mind (and heart) by the end of POTC I, is now shown lusting after Jack for no discernible reason other than the fact he is available when Will is not, and her final act of betrayal is as shocking as it is impossible to justify. As for Jack, making him so much of a coward for so long is not an improvement, and unlike his almost hilariously shameless treachery and suave rascality, not particularly endearing. Only Will Turner remains anything like his original character, vowing to save his father right after his father tells Will that he owes him nothing. Perhaps the writers were merely trying to heighten the dramatic tension at the halfway point, but that brings up the final problem.3. If you've only got plot enough for ONE sequel, don't stretch it out over TWO! This was by far the most annoying defect. After over two and a half hours of beautifully shot, beautifully choreographed, beautifully CG-ed action sequences that were nevertheless demonstrably too long, the movie just ends! Absolutely NOTHING of importance is resolved in POTC II, in order to hook us into coming back for POTC III: Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End.In addition there are a couple of annoying, even downright inappropriate ideas the writers have chosen to toss in. One is a sort of moronic Marxism apparent in their rather ham-handed attempt to criticize giant corporations. The problem is that Lord Cutler Beckett is not some 18th Century Robber Baron or CEO, but rather a corrupt politician who bought (or murdered) his way to the top, not of some too massive to regulate private enterprise, but rather a government created and protected monopoly. The EITC is not the result of Capitalism gone wrong, but rather a logical consequence of Mercantilism gone wrong, in this case the idea that it was more important to ship cargo in British flag ships under at least nominal government control than to ship cargo as cheaply and efficiently as possible in whatever. Finally Lord Cutler Beckett is not scheming to drive his competitors out of business by providing better service and/or lower prices while still making profits hand over fist but rather to squeeze every loose dime out of them with a government bureaucracy/organized crime style protection racket. They must either go to work for or pay protection to the EITC or let Davy Jones sink their ships.Second, as the writers make explicit in their audio commentary, the reason Elizabeth is so vulnerable to lusting after Captain Jack Sparrow is her (or overly honorable Will's?) unfortunate choice to practice sexual abstinence during the year-long engagement before the wedding. Leaving aside whether this argument makes any sense (because methinks that it would be harder to be suddenly "cut off" than to keep missing out a little longer on what you haven't yet experienced), is this REALLY an appropriate message for a DISNEY film?Still in re-watching the movie on this DVD, I cannot deny that it was a lot of fun, and if they come through with a strong enough ending, I can still be won over. I'd LIKE to be. Maybe the thing to do is to stop thinking of this as a lousy 2 & 1/2 hour movie but rather as a possibly darn good 5 hour movie...With a year long intermission (and the annoying requirement that you pay AGAIN to see the second half of the movie).
summary: Worst Idea for a Sequel Ever

reviewText: Arrrrr! Johnny Depp does it again as he reprises his role of slightly whacko, always mildly drunk Captain Jack Sparrow. Yes, he and his crew of Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and his beau Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley) take on the seven seas once more in "Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest." Hold on to your vessels people, because this thumping good adventure will leave you clinging to the ropes and demanding the third installment!On their wedding day, Will and Elizabeth are rudely interrupted when they are charged with conspiring with pirates (a brutal crime) and sentenced to their deaths by hanging. In a twist of luck, Will is summoned by the higher order to find and bring back the compass of Captain Jack Sparrow, which has some sort of powerful significance. As Will sets out in search of Jack, Elizabeth follows leading all three of them involved with the menacing supernatural tyrant Davy Jones and his deadly score to settle with Jack Sparrow.Disney nailed this film, to the point where I can't decide if I liked this one or the original better. The special effects are outstanding, giving "Lord of the Rings" a sure run for their money. I honestly couldn't decided what came out of the computer and what didn't! Absolutely stunning.And, most importantly, what is "Pirates of the Caribbean" without its swashbuckling comedy, accentuated by the genious that is Johnny Depp. So many scenes had the sold-out audience in absolute barrels of laughter. No doubt, I think this addition punched out more laughs than the last. I had tears in my eyes from laughing so hard on more than one occasion.Finally, the entire movie cinema was left with their jaws dropped wide open as a string of surprises (good and bad) climax to a whopping good cliffhanger. But I won't talk about that, I'll leave it to audiences to experience the brilliant ending (?) themselves! All I'll say is expect the unexpected! It will leave you simply gasping for the next installment!All in all, "Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest" was the full package. Loaded with action sequences that will take your breath away, laugh-out-loud humour, and magical chemistry of Johnny Depp to his alter-ego Jack Sparrow alongside Orlando and Keira, this film is one you would be surely sorry to miss. And judging by the sold-out sessions I witnessed today, you'd be in the minority if you did.Bring on number three!
summary: Swashbuckling good fun with a shipload of laughs

reviewText: Elizabeth and Will's wedding day is interrupted by an arrest warrant, and Will goes off on a desperate hunt for Captain Jack. This sequel starts off with a bang and gives back all our favorite characters, but goes downhill from there. There are too many subplots and too many loose ends that are never tied up. The movie gives us plenty of dazzling swordfights - but they're dragged out for too long, and improbability is only entertaining for awhile before it becomes simply absurd. The viewer begins to wonder if the movie will ever end, and then is disappointed with a cliffhanger that leaves nothing settled.I was also turned off by the violence. Davy Jones and his monster crew crossed over from simply grotesque to stomach-turning, and the violence (floggings, prisoners being murdered) crossed the line for a swashbuckling adventure flick.Let's hope the next movie gets it right. Only three stars.
summary: Entertaining but more than a bit disappointing

reviewText: Style and substance is always going to lose to action...No matter the plotlines or the characters.Do any John Huston movies have any plot structure issues?  Yes.Is Capt. Blood and other Errol Flynn movies more of a "roller coaster ride of fun" than a potential nod for an Oscar or Golden Globe?  Yes.Then don't worry about style, plot holes, open ended finales (Back to the future, anyone?) and the like.  People that see this movie are seeing it for the same reason they saw the first.  Johnny Depp.  Granted, he wasn't as much of a scally-wag in this than in the first one, but that's what gives his character so much more presence.  CAPT Jack Sparrow is one of the best characters Disney has in its marketing arsenal.The stunts (especially the big wheel) were fantastic and breathtaking.  I can't wait to see the Making Of of that entire sequence when the DVD comes out.Davy Jones was a bit over the top...his character wasn't the greatest I've seen, and left me wanting a little more....and the running time of the movie (after shampoo, car, and Sprite commercials [which, by the way, you can download on V-Cast]) is about 10 mins too long.But if it's popcorn entertainment the way a summer blockbuster should be, you can't do wrong with POTC: DMC.  The summer blockbuster is BACK, Jack!

reviewText: I probably would've liked it even more if it were 20-30 minutes shorter in the middle but as it is - great fun. Jack is back and he is magnificent -drunk most of the time, his morals as unstable as his walk, lying, seducing, running, hanging by his leg on the rope, and always irresistible. Depp's Capt. Sparrow is the reason to see the movie but there is so much more. The movie's last hour is simply awesome and the way its creators prepared us for the third film is very clever. I am happy that one of my favorite characters from the first movie made the appearance and will be the part of this trilogy (?) final(?) chapter. The film is exiting, has stunning special effects and I was sure that the make up artists would be nominated for all possible awards in the end of the year (they deserved them all). Well, I was wrong about make up artists but the movie has recieved the nominations for Best Achievement in Art Direction, Best Achievement in Sound and Sound Editing, and Best Achievement in Visual Effects and it is very fair. I will not mention the plot - it is there but it's not that important after all. The film is a rare case of equal opportunity entertainment and enjoyment - for the young children, their parents, cynical teenagers, sophisticated intellectuals, rednecks - for everybody and their uncle Max.

reviewText: I don't go to many action movies of this type, but I got roped into seeing this one. The thought of having to sit through a 2+ hour movie dismayed me. Well, I hadn't seen the original "Pirates" and that probably turned out to be a hinderance. As the whole thing unraveled I became rather awe struck. So what did I expect, the Disneyland ride? The entire movie was unrelenting action. At no place did the activity level lull. The visuals were spectacular and interesting in a bizarre way. The stunts were amazing. Most of the characters were ugly and repulsive, both in looks and in person. The whole movie reminded me of a wild out-of-control dream, and it made about as much sense. The pure stupidity of the unfolding scenes actually brought out a lot of laughs in me. Both the high activity level and the visuals kept me from ever getting bored and I was surprised when it ended. It seemed much shorter than the indicated running time.The story line was exceedingly weak. Furthermore, the movie required a strong belief in the supernatural in order to get into it. I lack such belief and most of the plot, if there was one, was exceedingly hard to follow. Oh well, this was not a movie to promote deep thinking. What unfolded for me was an unrelenting stream of unrelated activity, most of it violent in one way or another. In places it was quite funny in a visual sense. I wondered how they could possibly put such a thing together. It must have taken an enormous amount of computer animation. Am I looking forward to "Pirates 3?" No.In any case, the movie came back to mind as I was browsing through the DVD bins in my local warehouse club. It was an interesting and enjoyable movie to experience and I've enjoyed writing this review. Would I buy the DVD? Not likely.

reviewText: Johnny Depp, Orlando Bloom and Keira Knightley put on their sea legs once more for the "Pirates of the Caribbean" sequel "Dead Man's Chest". I liked the first one, so I went to see this one. Though there were parts of it I admired and enjoyed, I wouldn't exactly call it a great film.Our heroes Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley) are due to get married, but they're bound for the death penalty due to the consequences of their last adventure. The only way they can get off is if they can capture that renegade pirate and their one time ally, Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp), a man who has quite a few troubles of his own.You see, in the oceans of the Caribbean, there lives a slimy squid like creature called Davy Jones (Bill Nighy). He sails over and under oceans in his supernatural vessel, "The Flying Dutchman", seeking the dead and dying. When ol' Davy finds these poor souls, he offers them a deal. He can delay their Day of Judgement for 100 years in exchange for 100 years of service aboard his ship. It's not exactly a sweet deal. Davy is a cruel master, and the longer the crew of the "Flying Dutchman" serve, the more they become bloated, barnacle encrusted husks of human beings. That, and if the poor fellows refuse, Davy kills them anyway.Jack Sparrow has made a similar deal with Davy Jones, and now Davy wants Jack's soul. Will Jack be able to wriggle his way out of this fishy adventure? When there's a Will (Turner, that is), will there be a way to escape Davy Jones?When the first "Pirates of the Caribbean" film came out, a lot of people (including myself) saw a lot of parallels between it and the LucasArts "Monkey Island" video game series. The parallels continue here. There's a voodoo lady whose advice is sought, just as there's a voodoo lady in "Monkey Island". There's cannibals, just as there is the game. Davy Jones' wriggling beard reminds one of the living beard of the ghost pirate LeChuck. It's a shame that there's all these Monkey Island references, because all they do is make me think of how much I would have liked to have seen a Monkey Island movie rather than this one.One thing that bugged me about "Dead Man's Chest" was that it didn't seem to know what film it wanted to be. It had funny moments, yes, but there was so much dramatic music plastered over the top it didn't come across half as funny as it could have been. There is intrigue, but due to the fast pace and dispersion of action, this intrigue was hard to follow. For instance, I thought Will's father was Barbossa for most of the film, since he kind of looked like Geoffery Rush (who plays Barbossa) covered in barnacles. But then again I'm not even sure that Barbossa isn't Will's father, I'm so confused! There is dramatic dialogue in the colonial scenes, which sounds psuedo-theatrical, but really doesn't sit well against the comic vocabulary of the pirate scenes. There's just so much going on, so many characters and everyone's adventures tangled up with everyone else's, it was hard, for me at least, to feel truly involved.That's not to say its all bad. I really liked the design of Davy Jones' undead crew. They look like nothing I've ever seen before, yet they look entirely natural, like something that indeed could be found in the sea. If such a race of seaweed plastered, half coral half men existed, I am sure they would look like this. I had no idea if some of them were real or computer animated, which is a big compliment for the SFX people. The appearance of the crew reminded me a lot of the stuff that washes up on the beaches and piers down where I live, actually. Speaking of beaches, the beach and jungle scenery is beautiful, and is a great atmosphere for pirate-y hijinks.As for the actors, everybody looks like they had a wonderful time, which always shows in the performance. Johnny Depp was great, though I didn't find him as funny as some members of the audience I was in. Johnny just had to make a facial expression and there'd be roars of laughter. It's a very disorienting experience, a crowd laughing at something you didn't realise was a joke. Is there something wrong with me? Is there something wrong with them? Is there something wrong with me for thinking there's something wrong with them? Etc.As the film went on, I realized that it was turning into the second part of a trilogy. There was no way that everything was going to be wrapped up. The ending had a very Back to the Future II feel to it, I thought. Slightly disappointing conclusion.I liked the first film, and that's worth checking out on DVD. There's a novelization of this sequel, and I do wish I'd have read it before seeing the film, as I may have been able to understand some of the more intrigue-y parts. If you haven't, do check out the Monkey Island games. They've got pirates, action and comedy, just like this one, but being a game, you can take your time with it rather than have it all whiz by.

reviewText: There are many people out there who claim the original was the best in the series and this sequel is nothing more than a collection of stunts, over the top imagery, with little plot or coherence. I call shenanigans. This movie not only furthers the original movie, fleshing out the principle three leads (Sparrow, Turner, and Liz Swan), but also expanding the myth. It is an adventure movie with a childish heart beating loudly throughout. The only bile being spit up are by those who love to hate something once it has turned into a large success. God forbid they join the masses in loving something. I call it the Titanic complex. Everyone loved the movie until it became the largest grossing film in history. Then suddenly everyone claimed it was awful, horrid, no plot, etc. The box office receipts don't lie. As to Dead Man's Chest, it is a worthy addition to what seems will be a trilogy.

reviewText: 'Pirates Of The Caribbean - Dead Man's Chest' is but the second installment (the third has already been shot) in the series of movies based on a Disneyland ride: strange nidus for a story idea and one that takes a bit of patience to sit through, but a fun evening nevertheless.  Though the first installment took the audience by surprise with the character of Jack Sparrow so inimitably portrayed by the gifted Johnny Depp and therefore served as a tastier treat, this second installment substitutes sea-dead cum barnacles for the dancing skeletons of the first and is a bit more grisly...and a lot less fun.But Gore Verbinski knows how to choreograph these outings and he is able to marry some very fine special effects to the genuinely good cast of characters and the result is a fantasy that is a visual delight.  The cast  includes Depp, Orlando Bloom, Keira Knightley, Jack Davenport, Bill Nighy who is completely covered in tentacles as Davy Jones, Jonathan Pryce, Tom Hollander, Stellan Skarsgrd,and Naomie Harris and they all seem to be having a glorious time.  It is a bit long for a slight story (well in excess of two hours) and the special effects of the kraken (octopus like tentacles) overwhelming boats becomes tedious, but it is a fun outing and it all too blatantly sets us up for part three due our next spring.  Grady Harp, December 06
summary: A Cute Little Disney Film but Not for Children

reviewText: I've been so excited to see the second installment in the Pirates Of The Carribean series.  Okay, so it wasn't quite as good as I hoped it would be, but that's not to say it wasn't good.It starts with Will Turner and Elizabeth being arrested at their wedding for helping Jack Sparrow escape his hanging.  The man who arrests them offers Will a deal that he will drop the charges if Will finds Jack Sparrow and brings back his compass (that doesn't point north).Meanwhile, Jack has his own problems to worry about such as a debt that he owes to Davy Jones (not the singer) that if he does not pay, his ship, the Black Pearl, will be sucked to the bottom of the sea.Jack is on a hunt to find a key and a chest which he believes holds a certain item that could free him of his debt.While this movie was very entertaining and action-packed, I feel that the story kind of suffered.  The second installment of a trilogy should be where we find out some sort of very interesting fact but instead we are just left with lots of questions (which hopefully will be answered in the third film).Also, the entire scene where Jack is the cheif of some native tribe has no real significance in the film, so there's almost 15 or 20 minutes that could easily be removed and have hardly any affect on the movie.One other flaw is that many characters speak very fast which makes their lines hard to understand.  And the lady they see in the cabin speaks so strangely that you can only understand about 1 out of every 10 words she says.So while this movie is fun and entertaining, it just doesn't stand on its own.  It seems like the only reason it exists is to lead into the third film.But what the heck?  I'm gonna see it again anyway!

reviewText: This action-packed sequel to the 2003 Walt Disney Pictures hit "Pirates Of The Caribbean" is crammed to the brim with a great storyline, spectacular action scenes (especially one terrific swordfight atop a mill wheel), awesome special effects, good performances and, as usual, Disney humor. I won't spoil the storyline, for the sake of those who haven't seen it, but I will say one thing. If you loved the first movie, which grossed $650 million (so far, this film has grossed $361 million, with a budget of $225 million), you will enjoy this one even more. Keira Knightley is as charming as ever and her performance is well-done, exuding greater empathy and fire. Orlando Bloom is good as Ms. Knightley. Jack Davenport, looking more like Pierce Brosnan in the torture scenes from "Die Another Day," is good. However, this movie is entirely Johnny Depp's. Having seen him in the family-friendly J.M. Barrie biopic "Finding Neverland" and the first "Pirates," he has proven his worth to me as an actor. Ms. Knightley proves herself worthy of holding her own in period pieces and against her male co-stars. I love this movie.Word to parents: Despite Walt Disney Pictures producing this wonderful movie, this film is darker than the original and is therefore not suitable for very young children (depending on their tolerance for the heavy material, of course; thanks, in part to Jerry Bruckheimer-"Pearl Harbor," "Remember The Titans"- and the excellent script by Ted Eliott and Terry Rossio-the writers behind the smash box-office hits "Aladdin" and "The Mask Of Zorro"). This film, along with the first movie, should have been rated PG. The violence (period-style swordfights) isn't graphic (you'd expect that from Walt Disney Pictures, a company which prides itself, and made its name on, family-friendly entertainment; the camera cuts away before any graphic execution takes place) and there is absolutely no language or sexual content (the cleavage shown in the films is consistent with the period in which the films are set-England in the 1600's). Walt Disney is still riding high. Watch for "Pirates Of The Caribbean 3: At World's End" due out next summer. Rated PG for action-adventure violence.
summary: An Enjoyable Sequel With Promise Of Another Film. Great Action/Storyline. Leaves Me Waiting For "Pirates Of The Caribbean 3."
