reviewText: That's right everyone, hide the rum because believe it or not, you won't need it!I'm going to start by saying one thing: midnight premieres are amazing. The first one I went to was for the 4th Harry Potter film, and this time around I've commandeered some of my friends to come along. It was a blast. You don't get energy like that in a sold-out room unless it is a midnight showing. It was a roomful of people who all love Pirates, what's not to love about that itself? Everyone was pumped. We cheered the grand entrance of Captain Jack Sparrow, weren't afraid to lose ourselves in laughter over some one-liners, and held onto our seats for pretty much the entire show.The original cast returns: Gibbs, Cotton, and two of the pirates who had previously crewed under Barbossa, Pintel and Ragetti (the guy with the eyeball and his mate). I was a bit surprised that Anamaria didn't join them, but we can't have everything in life. Jack Davenport reprises his role as Norrington as well. We find him in Tortuga as a matter of fact, a little worse for wear.Several new and just as memorable characters surface in this sequel, including Bill Nighy as the notorious Davy Jones himself, Stellan Skarsgard as the barnacle-encrusted Bootstrap Bill Turner, and Naomie Harris as the wacky fortune-teller/ voodoo mistress Tia Dalma.The beginning of the film was a bit disorientating; after the "arrest" of Will and Elizabeth, I mean. Before Jack's entrance. It was all dark and you could barely see what was going on. I give Gore Verbinski credit though: this time around, he definitely uses the camera itself to an advantage. It rocks, pitches and rolls more often than the ships, helping to create a better scene.If you're hoping for some memorable quotes from the sequel, you won't be disappointed. There are some great one-liners, like "hide the rum", among other things. Johnny is just as hilarious (if not more so) as in the first film, and there are actually quite a few throwbacks to COTBP, all of them bringing back wonderful memories.The special effects are state-of-the-art as well. Definitely upped the ante from COTBP. If you thought the skeletons were amazing, think again. Davy Jones' monstrous Kraken will shake you to your core. Come to think of it, his crew are also a sight to behold: they, similar to Barbossa's crew, are rotting away. Although, this is because they have sworn servitude to Jones. These crew members are so old that they are starting to mold to their watery environment. Take Bootstrap for example: he is so encrusted with barnacles and the like that it's hard to imagine him as a real person anymore. Even Davy Jones' beard is made of octopus/squid tentacles.There are so many different plots and subplots and below-subplots that you have to pay attention every step of the way or else you'll miss something. Everything is crucial, everything fits together somehow. The ending of this film means we have one great ending to look forward to over Memorial Day weekend 2007! And make sure you stay through the end credits again! It's funny!Well, this was one helluva ride. Cheers! <clinks rum tankard and staggers off>

reviewText: Trying to make a successful sequel is an interesting thing.  There's a lot of expectation, but where the expectation comes from is contradictory--on one hand, everyone expects the same characters and the same general quality as the first movie; on the other hand, they don't want the same movie with repetitive, tired jokes.  In a movie like Pirates of the Caribbean, which is very popular mostly by force of its interesting and dynamic characters, that line is a bit harder to hit because everyone is attached to the characters, but don't want them to ever really be damaged.I would say then that this is a very successful sequel.  It doesn't necessarily rely upon the first movie, but a lot of what is going on is very aware of the first movie's influence on these characters.  It brings back almost all of the characters, major and minor, from the previous movie, but it does accept the task of taking the time to develop them.  In a sense, a lot of what happens in this film could be considered unnecessary pandering towards icon recognition.  In the opposite sense, this movie seems willing to take risks with character development that might not be agreeable.  I personally consider the two to even themselves out and create a sufficiently self-contained movie experience.A major issue with the film is its ultimate tie-in with the next sequel.  This movie, like The Matrix Reloaded, is a bridge between two different movies that deal with different issues.  It would probably behoove any potential viewers of this movie to understand that while it has a sort of climax, it doesn't really have a complete story-arch.  Don't go expecting to have the complete story else you will be very disappointed.  Go to see where the next movie will take you and figure out where the character development is going.Many have said that this film is "dark".  I don't really consider a lot of the imagery darker than the original... this one does seem to like its Eldritch horror, but what really makes this movie less light and enjoyable than the first is that for the first time, we see the characters (and especially Jack Sparrow) at their very weakest.  Throughout the first movie there's a sense even when things seem to be in conflict that the character's overall capability will eventually work itself out.  In this movie, the characters themselves are completely unsure of themselves (the compass, anyone?).  This development is actually why I really like this movie by itself: we know Jack the graceful but klutzy looking sort-of-drunk, but now we get to see Jack the nothing seems to be working out serious captain.  We also know Elizabeth and Will the lovers, but now we get them not quite knowing what they're doing for each other as well.  Because it's such a big change from what they were in the first movie, it does seem almost necessary to have them resolve it over two more movies.The idea of forcing it into two movies is kind of depressing to me; technically, there is no rule that says a movie must be between one and a half and two hours long.  A movie could be a stunning narrative and still be five hours long.  However, Hollywood does know audience impatience, and as many people have said about this movie: "It starts to get a bit long..."  Nobody seems willing to sit down to watch a complete four-hour narrative, so instead they are more willing to pay the price of two tickets.  If that's the way their time is valued, that's the way their time is valued, and I don't think I can really do much about that.So for what it is, this is a very good movie.  The strong parts are the ideas behind the character development (though I still don't think Knightley nor Bloom really have that much ability to carry the weight of serious acting on their shoulders) and the very inventive action.  The swashbuckling is presented to quite an extreme degree here, and a lot of it is actually quite surprising in where it goes.Go out and enjoy it.  Most everyone else is.--PolarisDiB
summary: How to make a successful sequel

reviewText: FINALLY the long-awaited sequel to Pirates of the Caribbean: Curse of the Black Pearl. Now, I realize sequels generally regarded as worse than the orginal, and I can certainly understand why critics might feel that way about this film, but I definitely do not agree.Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest is a much darker, but still extremely good sequel to the highly entertaining original. The storyline here reunites the most beloved characters from COTBP, Will, Elizabeth, Jack (of course), and many others. Jack Sparrow made a deal with Davy Jones 13 years ago, a deal we never really know the details of other than the Black Pearl was raised from the ocean in exchange for Jack's soul. Meanwhile, in Port Royal, their comraderie with Jack has cost Will and Elizabeth their freedom and their wedding. Imprisoned by the East India Trading Company, they face death for helping Jack, along with the missing Commodore Norrington. They are offered a deal in exchange for their freedom. The film focuses on Jack's attempt to save his own skin (as usual), Will's quest to free himself and Elizabeth (and others), Elizabeth's general transition into a savy pirate, and Norrington's determination to regain his lost honor.The characters are much more human in this film, I find. Jack Sparrow becomes much darker in his self-service than one might expect. Elizabeth is a strong character, sword-weilding (which was one of Knightly's desires for this movie) and much more independent than the damsel in distress she was at first. Will is much more troubled, and faces forces more powerful than himself using him like a pawn.The general tone of the movies is very dark. Of course, Jack is there to lighten the mood with his ever-popular humor. The film is much more graphic, as well, much more dead and blood than I remember in the first movie. The fight scenes are intense and creative, and I personally find the waterwheel fight scene to be one of my favorites.The special effects are as marvelous as can be expected, although Davy Jones's crew is so complex and usually featured in the shadows, it's somewhat hard to catch all the details in the scene. The Kraken is only partially shown, but still a wonderfull bit of special effects. The actual settings are beautiful as well.You simply will not believe the ending, any of it. There are so many plot twist and cliffhangers crammed in that it leaves you craving more. I honestly can't wait until next July to see how this is resolved. Also, some of you may have heard of the extra scene at the end of the movie, following the example of the monkey stealing a piece of gold from the chest in Curse of the Black Pearl. I wouldn't exactly recommend staying, it's rather pointless and just meant for some kind of cheap humor, rather than anything plot advancing.This is much less of a family-oriented, disney type of film than the first one was. I don't really recommend you take any children who are easily frightened, but it isn't exactly gory either, so some children might enjoy it. Try to keep your characters straight also, I often forgot who Norrington was because he looks so much different. However, this film was spectacular, deep and interesting as well as action-packed and humorous. I would strongly recommend it for anyone who enjoyed the first movie.
summary: I saw Dead Man's Chest twice in less than 12 hours...

reviewText: While I don't particularly like pirate stories (with exceptions like Treasure Island, and space pirates), I enjoyed Dead Man's Chest immensely.  It's a fun story with good performances and spectacular effects.As someone with a life-long interest in special effects and animation, I especially liked the Kraken, a giant sea monster that reminded me of Ray Harryhausen movies - but it's so good you can't tell which parts are CG. Most impressive, I am told Davy Jones is entirely CG - there's no actor involved - and the same is true of his entire crew save one, Bootstrap Bill.  No doubt this one will get an Oscar for the special effects / animation.  Oh, and the human actors aren't too bad either.

reviewText: Johnny Depp, Keira Knightley and Orlando Bloom return in part two of the Pirates series...According to the special features, this project began without a script and I believe it. We already know the characters and save Davey Jones and Bootstrap Bill - none of consequence make it into this sequel. I expected the latter to be given more character development and screen time, but I was disappointed.I won't go over the details of the plot, which is rather weak...you can read that in the synopsis. Let's just say it would have been more believable if it actually had some structure and made sense. Although, there were a couple of cool surprises (no spoilers here), the story itself was a let down.  There were a lot of unnecessary (read predictable) references to the first film.  The sea creatures of Davey Jones' ship and even Jones himself (their appearance) just seemed silly to me. Bill Nighy, who played Davey Jones, is a great actor and probably did more than anyone could with this role.  I know Pirates is a fantasy themed attraction, but come on.  The movie relies entirely too much on special effects. The dialogue in the movie was formulaic, weak and predictable at times.  I'm not a screen writer by any means, but even I had to roll my eyes at some of the lines (just wait for the sword fight on the beach).So how can I still give this movie three stars?  Now that I've told you what I didn't like...here's why I actually liked this movie...It's a lot of fun.  As long as you don't think too hard about it, you'll enjoy it. Ignore the weak plot and some of the bad lines and you have an entertaining film.  The film is a big ocean adventure with funny and interesting characters who we came to like in the first film.  The special effects, music score and sound effects are awesome.  The enemies in this film, while silly in appearance, were excellent.  The stunts were big, fun and entertaining.One of the highlights in the film was the the return of the two bumbling pirates from Captain Barbosa's ship. Their antics actually carried some of the film.  The second was ex-commodore Norrington's return.  It made me laugh almost every time he was on screen - compared with his character in the first movie.Johnny Depp carries the movie on his back.  He puts everything into his characters.  It's a shame that the writers on this film didn't give him more to work with. Bloom is actually a bit boring in this movie, which makes it a good thing that Depp has the lead roll.  Keira Knightley is solid as usual, but again the writers failed her (again - just wait for the sword fight on the beach).I didn't see this in theaters and I bought the DVD without even seeing the movie first like I usually do.  I had high expectations because I loved the first movie.  I assumed that this movie would be on par with the first one, which it isn't.  It's not a Godzilla-type letdown, but I was a little disappointed. I hope the screenwriters and directors go back to the drawing board, find something resembling a plot and then find some good people to write good dialogue.  Otherwise, they'll need to depend on Depp and CGI to carry the film once again.  Here's wishing for more in Pirates 3.
summary: Over-hyped, overdone, but still a lot of fun....

reviewText: Following the enormous commercial and critical success of the 2003 PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: Curse of the Black Pearl, corporate greed made a sequel inevitable. Good or bad, it didn't matter; and the sequel "Dead Man's Chest" duly appeared in 2006, made back-to-back with another 2.5 hours of footage that will be released as a third installment in May 2007: "At World's End." Sequels can be fine: some, like SPIDER-MAN 2, even surpass their predecessors. When gold is the *only* prize however, as Disney's corporate pirates should have heeded, there is often a price. In the case of "Dead Man's Chest," that price is quality. The first film was conceived as a closed system, with a beginning, middle, and end. It was buoyant, humorous, exciting, wise at times, crisply executed, and carefully researched historically--right down to the English period violins and bows used, generally brilliant. Topping it off was a lead performance as iconoclast as one is ever going to see: Johnny Depp as the witty, sardonic, and wonderfully fey pirate, Jack Sparrow. Sparrow's position in the plot, his world-view, and his ambiguous sexuality telegraphed him immediately as an outsider, with all the insight that can bring. The film also had a surprising horror theme of undead pirates, adding a note of the surreal to the impeccable 18th-century action and settings."Dead Man's Chest" couldn't be more different except for its rough basic premise and its excessive length: apparently the director hates editing; even his fine first PIRATES entry was a tad long at 143 minutes. "Chest" is historically sloppy, genuine period details actually dismissed in favor of showier ones. It began with NO script: in the DVD extras, the writers freely admitted that they were not prepared for a sequel and couldn't come up with anything. So when shooting time came, the director simply filmed a lot of action sequences and the script was made up along the way. As for themes, much is an untalented retread of the first film; even the same fine musical score is reused--its best feature. The result is an utter mess, without any real humor, continuity, pacing, or appeal. It's 2.5 hours of confusion, tedium, some uncomfortable sadism, and an unhealthy dose of racial stereotyping.We do not identify with any of the principal characters, whose natures have changed radically since the first film--except perhaps Will Turner (Orlando Bloom), now a doormat for his fiancee Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley) and for Jack Sparrow. Jack comes off here as a treacherous, cowardly opportunist more than anything else. Apparently, the "gay reading"--which Depp intended and discussed with Rolling Stone, citing his study of the scholarly "Sodomy and the Pirate Tradition"--must have been too scary for Disney, though not for audiences, given the first film's returns. For "Chest," the writers and/or editors have assured that Sparrow is no longer a clever, witty, or interesting outsider; he is simply a selfish, manipulative alcoholic. Moreover, the writers and/or editors lessened or eliminated any sexual ambiguity by bolstering Sparrow's male persona, hinting at gratuitous past histories with women; they even included a preposterous pseudo-romantic link between him and an equally treacherous Elizabeth--who is mysteriously transformed into a pirate and expert duelist. Depp does the best he can with the material, and it is astonishing what he manages to salvage from the wreckage of the "script." The special effects are well-done but overwhelming while going nowhere, and there is a 25-minute racist interlude on an island occupied by cannibals that is so repugnant as to be worthy of a vulgar 1930s comedy. That an actor of Depp's sophistication and political views could have permitted, much less participated in, such sequences after reading them in the script fragments, apparently unaware of their obvious pernicious resonances, is beyond comprehension. Again, referring to the DVD extras, the attitude of the actors, especially Depp, is not one of glowing achievement as with the first film: muted comments appear tinged with mild regret. Depp received $20 million for this film, apparently enough for him to rationalize compromising his artistic ethics. This is a film to borrow from the library as a curiosity, but the Disney pirates have raked in quite enough already and don't need anyone else's hard-earned cash for something that started out with a brilliant offbeat film and ended as a leaden franchise. The anamorphic widescreen DVD transfer is quite good; with a film of this caliber, the plethora of extras is ludicrous.

reviewText: It's hard not to find something likeable about many of the Pirate's characters. That's about all I can say that might make it worth your while to sit through 2 hours of pointless, hammy action that's like something out of the goofy movie Hook, more than the first Pirate's movie. Gone is the atmosphere, and whimsical charm, not to mention coherent story. It's been replaced by an open ended series of nonsensical "action" sequences... including Jack becoming a human shiskabob, and not one but TWO lengthy scenes in the movie of people ROLLING AROUND in giant circular contraptions. Now that's action and adventure! Where the scenes in the first film adeptly weave a story while conveying the (fake but charming) pirate life atmosphere, the scenes in this one neither tell a story nor usually evoke any atmosphere.However, the film does pick up greatly in the last half hour. It's a funny transition because I can distinctly remember simply enduring, enduring, waiting for the end of this 2 1/2 hour boring cash-in, when suddenly there's a fight on a beach where several characters all define a conflicting motive with each other. Wow! What a nice element of plot. Thanks for getting to that 2 hours into the movie. The reason becomes clear though, as Dead Man's Chest has no ending, just a setup for a sequel. In other words, they didn't have anything for this movie... it was filler to set up another movie. Pretty cheesy.You may want to watch this for the visuals and characters. Even at it's worst in empty dialogue and lack of any memorable character moments, it's slightly more interesting than watching night time TV. Let's hope our money from this filler version goes into making a third movie more like the first's charm and adventure.
summary: A Plotless Journey Back To The Carribean

reviewText: After Star Wars and Indiana Jones and others, the history of the film franchise is alive and well with the Pirates series. Of the current franchises, the Pirates films have been very enjoyable for me. All of the characters are fun, and I'm a huge fan of Keira Knightley. reviewerName: Richard W Little "I am a maple leaf on the wi...
reviewText: Keira Knightley, Orlando Bloom, and the talented Johnny Depp are back this summer, with their supporting cast, in Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest. I saw it at a matinee showing last weekend.I have to say, I was somewhat disappointed, in comparison to the original. It was difficult to put my finger on why, exactly...at least at first. In the past week, here's what I've noted.I enjoyed the supporting cast's performances more than that of the three primary stars....with one notable exception. I was happy to see Jack Davenport (of Coupling fame) put in a great performance as Norrington. The actors playing the pirates put in great comedic and supporting efforts. Bill Nighy continues to impress me; in this case, he's able to put emotion on the screen through all of that costuming, by his voice alone.Tom Hollander, who plays the villian Beckett, was the lone supporting cast who didn't really pull through here. You just know that a good smack to the head, and he'd just cave...which is not how he's really intended to portray the character.Orlando Bloom...either he's playing woodenly, or his character is written one-dimensionally, or both. I know if my love were threatened, I'd act with a little more depth of emotion than Bloom brings to the screen here.Keira's one of the saving graces...not just because she's easy on the eyes, but because she can portray emotion, and emotional changes, and because she sells her character as a match in wits against Jack Sparrow.And then there's Johnny...a great job, right up until his last scene.So, this brings us to the plot. It's too linear. The first film in this trilogy had a complex storyline, because the A story and the B story were given equal weight. Here, there's almost no weight put upon the B story. And, there are no real twists, at least not until the very end.I'd recommend the movie...it's light summer fare, great for the kids and to beat the heat. But, it's not as hefty as the original, so be prepared.
summary: "You keep me searching for a heart of gold"

reviewText: Probably the most review-proof movie ever.  I've read a dozen critics' reviews, and they ranged from so-so to terrible.  Yet the movie smash box-office records and left everyone I talked to about it feeling very well entertained.  So I'm not sure it's wise to weigh in with my opinion, but here goes anyway.DEAD MAN'S CHEST is VERY entertaining.  It's a big, bloated movie...but that's kinda what makes it fun.  They say it cost over $200 million to make, and I can believe it.  Every single scene is just PACKED with stuff.  Cool costumes, great sets and props, wonderful Caribbean locations, well compensated actors...and so on.  The special effects are actually pretty special...there is scarcely a moment when the CGI effects are distractingly obvious.And Johnny Depp is wonderfully in charge of the proceedings.  Clearly, these movies would be a waste of money were they not populated by Jack Sparrow.  I remember seeing the first film and being simply floored that a major studio would allow such an eccentric performance to exist...and aren't they glad they did?!  Depp received an Oscar nomination, became a huge star and the film was a worldwide Blockbuster.  Depp gives us more of the same in the sequel.  His character is an enigma...is he a good guy who acts wicked?  A wicked guy who sometimes does good?  A drunk who can't remember what he's doing from one minute to the next?  A con man to his core?  Who knows...and that's part of the fun.Orlando Bloom & Keira Knightly return and do nice work in their old parts, but their screentime is certainly a bit smaller.  Depp is the superstar now...Bloom has faded a bit after THE LAST KINGDOM and ELIZABETHTOWN...so they don't have equal screentime anymore.The wonderful Bill Nighy plays Davy Jones beneath a most astonishing and remarkable Octopus face (don't ask).  If you don't know this actor...then you MUST see him in STILL CRAZY, LOVE ACTUALLY or perhaps HITCHHIKER'S GUIDE...  Or heck, even his small part in SHAWN OF THE DEAD is worthwhile.  I'm glad he was in DEAD MAN'S CHEST...too bad he's unrecognizable.The movie has its flaws.  I found the plot just a bit hard to follow.  The Davy Jones legend and Sparrow's part in it are pretty sketchily presented.  Perhaps the sequel will fill us in more...I kept waiting for a flashback when we found out why Sparrow owes a debt, and how exactly it all works with the chest, the key, the heart, etc.  The film is also quite long.  It keeps you entertained, certainly...so much to look at...but I think the pace was affected.But this is more than countered by the wonderfully funny stuff set on the cannibal island.  Depp's escape and the escape of the captured pirates are gems of physical comedy.  Later, the appearance of the fearsome sea creature, the Kraken, is frightening in a good way and very impressive.  The waterwheel sword-fight is inventive.  It's just ALL such good fun that you can't help but have on a smile throughout.I'm sorry the critics just didn't see the film I did.  Must be rough.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl was one of the most enjoyable films of the 21st century. The film was funny, action-packed, and of course contained one of the best performances of the year by Johnny Depp as Captain Jack Sparrow. Unfortunately, the sequel loses all of the fun that the first brought to the table. This time, Depp just seems goofy as the fidgety Sparrow. While at first his humor and perfect pirate aura were clever, now they seem outdated. Many jokes and gags from the first film are repeated. Also, the plot bogs down the movie and loses the light-heartedness of the first. Basically, Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley) are arrested on their wedding day for helping Sparrow escape execution. Will makes a deal with Lord Cutler Beckett (Tom Hollander) to find Jack and bring him back, along with Jack's magic compass. Jack is currently on an island being held captive by worshipping natives, and is being chased by Davy Jones (Bill Nighy), who wants his soul to repay a debt. Jack has to locate the heart of Davy Jones in order to control the sea. Everyone else is also after the heart. Confusing, right? This complicated plot takes away too much of what people come for: great action and piraty humor. Overall, this film fails because of the loss of humor and a complicated plot.
summary: A Step Down From The First

reviewText: Pirates of the Caribbean-Dead Man's Chest"(released June/06)returns us to the wonderful world of swordplay and swashbuckling that made the first installment such a hit.However something is amiss in this film and things don't hit the mark like they did in the first;not by a country mile.Let's look and see what happened.The story this time takes us back to the exploits and troubles of Capt.Sparrow.The EIT(East India Trading Company) now holds sway in Jamaica and their number one man Lord Beckett.He controls the British fleet in the area and has sentenced Will and Elizabeth and ex-Commodore Norrington(in absentia)to die.However he will stay his order if Will and Elizabeth hunt for Sparrow and his errant compass.To buy time they agree and set off.Their search leads them to an island where the Pearl has run aground and Jack and his crew are indentured to local cannibals;with Jack as the head of a tribe.Will and Elizabeth eventually free Jack and his crew and they head for the sea.Jack persuades Will to help him find the key to the chest which contains pirate Davy Jones'(Bill Nighy)heart.Sparrow's time is now up and he must change places with Jones as its captain.Jack will give Will his compass if Will will help,but a dark priestess Tia Dalma(Naomie Harris)tells him the compass won't work unless the person who possess it really knows what he wants.While at sea however Jones in the Flying Dutchman catches up to the Pearl and captures Sparrow.Jack puts off his purgatory by persuading Jones that he can get 100 souls for his crew within three days.Will is left behind as collateral.Back in Jamaica a grieving Governor frees his daughter Elizabeth and at gunpoint she retrieves a letter from Lord Beckett which originally was to hire Sparrow as a privateer but she now wants for Will.She steals aboard a ship which lands in Tortuga just as Jack is there recruiting crewmen/souls for Jones' ship.After finding Jack he lets Elizabeth in on the compass's secret which he gives to her;and to their amazement it seems to get a bearing.They head off with a now disheveled and disgraced Commodore Norrington aboard also.They eventually reach an island and all three join up with Will,who with the help of his father,had escaped the Flying Dutchman.They find the chest with Davy Jones heart inside but Will has the key which he stole from Davy Jones.A fight breaks out between the three men but Norrington escapes with the heart and the letters from Lord Beckett.Sparrows crew escape with the(empty)chest and outrun the Dutchman in hot pursuit.Jone's has no choice but to call on the Kraken to kill Sparrow.As everyone abandons ship Jack is finally devoured by the beast and Jones calls the debt settled.However he is less than happy to find the chest empty.Back in Jamaica Norrington delivers the letter and heart of Davy Jones to Beckett.Tia Dalma meanwhile is host to Elizabeth,Will and the remaining crew of the Pearl.She asks if they have the courage to sail to the ends of the earth to return Sparrow back to the living.All are in agreement and who should agree to Captain the venture.....old Captain Barbossa.This movie like the first has non-stop action and alot of humour throughout but this time around something has gone awry.The movie seems to have psyched itself out by trying to do TOO much with the plot.There are so many plot twists in this film it is very easy to lose track of who knows what or who is doing what to whom at any given moment.There are also sequences on the Cannibal island and the deserted island where the chest is located which are far less than what they should have been.In the former when the crew is rescued the action goes on interminably long with them dangling over cliffs and their inter action with the natives.On the island where the chest is located again the fight scenes which are supposed to be funny aren't and the silly three way fight scene on the turning wheel falls flat.Some judicious editing should have been done here.However the most important factor in this movies' lackluster performance falls on the one person who made it the success it was in the first place;Johnny Depp.The off beat eccentric character with all his eccentricities are not there as they were in the first one.Here Sparrow is more often than not quite serious and circumspect and the underlying "flakiness" is not to be seen.This totally deflates the impact the movie would otherwise have had and had it been there it would have deflected attention from the shortcomings I listed previously.No matter how talented the actors are if the same qualities that make an original do not make a sequel,then my maties,there be troubles ahead!This "ship" definitely hit the doldrums.Technically the movie has been transferred well in sight and sound and is presented here in its widescreen version.The only extras available in this one disc DVD are some bloopers and audio commentary.All in all a big disappointment from the first film.The film tries to do way too much and the plots twists can leave your head spinning.Depps' characterization of Sparrow is NOT what is was in the first film and this especially drags the proceedings down.The fine SFX effects are there as are the solid cast but it can't overcome its own hurtles.Let us see what the third installment does.
summary: A decided drop in the "Pirates" fortunes!

reviewText: While I love some of my kids' films, such as the Harry Potter series, Depp's Pirate series does very little for me.  It is very hard for me to get into it, to believe it while I am watching it with them.  They absolutely love the raucous nuttiness of it, the impossible feats, and the outlandish characters as they switch sides and pursue interests impossible to fathom.  I envy the way they scream and laugh as they watch it, so I am glad to have them put it on.  But the way we use it at home is to get them out of our way so that we can do things around the house rather than as a family viewing experience.  I find the battles tedious, the characters and situations unbelievable, and somehow lacking in spirit, like it was written by a marketing committee rather than conceived as a story.  I also find the acting rather flat and unengaging, which is unfortunate given the quality of the cast.  I guess this reflects the fact that the film idea comes from an existing ride in the theme park rather than a story that on its own inspired a new theme-park experience.  So my wife and I are willing to put up with this as background noise.
summary: OK, but lacks its own magic

reviewText: It would be fair to say that this is a film whose whole is less than the sum of its parts, except some of the parts are very weak indeed.  There are definite strengths, not least Johnny Depp in reprising his Oscar-nominated role of Captain Jack Sparrow.  And it is obvious that no expense was spared in trying to make this as spectacular as possible.  The special effects were suitably impressive and the large and excellent cast threw themselves into the film with great gusto.Nonetheless, this film was more than a little disappointing, not least because there was simply no real story.  Indeed, what story there was seemed to have been rather casually assembled merely to give an occasion for the actors from the first film to get back together and do it all over again.  As all too often, this is a sequel in which far too little effort was expended in the writing process.  Well-written sequels are rare, and the few that are well writen are far too rare.  The finest recent box office example of a sequel that profited from a strong story was undoubtedly SPIDERMAN 2 and that largely because director/producer Sam Raimi understood the importance of a great and compelling story.  To that end he hired Pulitzer winning novelist Michael Chabon to write a completely original story to build the sequel around.  But DEAD MAN'S CHEST seems rather to have been built around the special effects they wanted to use in the film.  There is as a result a bit of hollowness at the core of the film that none of the spectacle can quite overcome.Another big problem with the film not having much of a story to tell is that there are significant segments where nothing of any importance seems to be taking place onscreen.  Instead of moving crisply along, the movie just seems to drag.  As a result, the film seems much longer than its two and a half hours.  One other factor compounding these problems is that the film is the first half of two films.  It therefore ends with no resolution whatsoever of all of the central events in the film.Still, despite all this, there are many moments of genuine enjoyment.  Most of these feature Johnny Depp in rather low-tech moments, proving to me at least that perhaps less effort should have been put into special effects and rather more in creating a better story involving the characters who are, after all, the main reason we watch this thing to begin with.  Why distract us with an overlong scene with the Kraken (which bears, by the way, little connection with the traditional Kraken, apart from its enormity and its being a sea creature) when you could have had another scene with Captain Jack?  Some viewers may have enjoyed parts of the film a lot more than I did.  For me the scenes with Davy Jones possessed an intense "ick" factor that made them unpleasant to watch.  Many of the crewmembers were even less pleasant.  Even the relatively normal looking Stellan Skarsgrd was close to unrecognizable, while virtually no feature of Bill Nighy as Davy Jones could be made out.  Some, however, might find Davy and his crew compelling.  I did not.So, a mildly entertaining film, mainly because of Johnny Depp.  All in all it was a far less interesting film than its predecessor.  We'll all have to toast some rum that the final film will be more like the original.
summary: Despite Johnny Depp's finest efforts, sometimes slow, sometimes fun

reviewText: So you missed Talk Like a Pirate Day, don't let that get you down.  You can go to [...] and use the English to Pirate translator or you can buy one of the most enjoyable action adventures of all time.Starting where the first movie left off, Will Turner and the lovely Elizabeth Swan are all set to be married, but both are arrested for aiding in Captain Jack's escape. The charges will be forgiven if Will can hunt down Jack and bring the new Capitan (Beckett) Jack's magic compass - you know the one that points to what you want the most. Along the way we learn Jack has other problems. Years ago, he made a deal with Davy Jones to raise the Black Pearl and it's time to pay up...with his soul. Will finds Jack, and steps unaware into the situation and Jack convinces Will into boarding Davy Jones' ship, the Flying Dutchman, to retrieve a mysterious key. This key opens the chest that contains Davy Jones' secret that has the power to control Davy Jones and his fearsome beast, The Kraken. Will retrieves the key sparking a roller coaster ride of movie action as Davy Jones hunts both Jack and Will.Action and thrills to spare, a few surprises and great characters make this an unforgettable movie experience.
summary: Avast me maties, tis a great pirate movie!

reviewText: I don't normally watch movies of this nature.  I didn't see the first "Pirates" movie for that exact reason. reviewText: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl was an original piece, with excellent performances and a good story. The sequel to the original "Pirates" loses much of the originality and freshness. Maybe it's just because we've seen it before, but Johnny Depp's performance as Captain Jack Sparrow just isn't as strange and exciting as it was in 2003. All that plus a very strange story in which it's tough to figure out what's happening to who and who wants what.Dead Man's Chest begins on what was supposed to be the wedding day of Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley). The day is ruined, however, when Capt. Beckett arrives carrying arrest warrants for the would-be newlyweds. Turner sets up a deal with Beckett-fetch Jack Sparrow's compass and the couple goes free. So, Turner sets out to locate Sparrow. In the meantime, Jack learns that the time has come to pay back a debt to the legendary Davey Jones (Bill Nighy), captain of the Flying Dutchman.Jones has loosed an unimaginable terror after Jack.I was very excited for Dead Man's Chest, and I hate to say that I was disappointed. The story isn't as captivating as the original. I watched the original after seeing this, and I tell you, seeing Captain Jack sailing into Port Royal on a sinking ship still makes me laugh. This stupid, useless, and overlong sequel has none of the elements that made the first one such a winner. The final word: This unoriginal and not as funny sequel fails to live up to the original.

reviewText: Johnny Depp, Orlando Bloom and Keira Knightley return as swashbuckling adventurers in "Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man`s Chest," the loud but soulless first sequel to the surprise Disney mega-hit from summer 2003.  This time around the three set sail on the high seas in search of the key to Davy Jones' legendary treasure.Replete with creatures straight out of Greek mythology, the plot consists of little more than one absurdly over-the-top set piece after another with little heed paid to either continuity or coherence - and none at all to characterization.  Even Depp's mincing, oddly flamboyant Captain Sparrow, which was the one element of quality in the original outing, has faded into the background, doomed to insignificance amidst all the overwrought special effects (Bloom and Knightley are their usual bland selves).  Here is a movie without a single trace of literacy, grace or style to go along with its box office booty, an assembly-line manufacture if ever there was one.Hectic rather than rousing, this is crass commercial moviemaking of the most cynical and hollow sort.  One can almost hear the producers and studio execs saying to one another, "Just keep hurling enough `stuff' at the audience and they'll never notice that none of it makes any sense."  Let me be the first to assure them then; we do notice.

reviewText: Wow!  Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest, was full of action and intrigue.  I kept looking at the faces of others in the theater as they watched their favorite characters spin, roll, and jump (literally) from adventure to adventure.  The grins, laughs, shocked looks, and armrest gripping told the whole story.  This movie ranks high in entertainment value, the characters are well developed (I just watched Aeon Flux... talk about the opposite in terms of character development!), and the story... makes sense!  What a concept!The PG-13 rating ("for intense sequences of adventure violence, including frightening images") is right on, and reminded me of those intense Harry Potter scenes probably inappropriate for the very young, so make sure your kids are ready for the intensity (King Kong, Jurassic Park, etc.).  Davey Jones and his crew.... brrrrr.  Have you ever picked up a bottle that's been in the ocean for a while?  It's covered partially or totally with barnacles and algae, like a little ecosystem.  Picture a crew that has been under water for a while, and you'll get a sense for what these characters are going to look like.  My favorites were hammerhead shark guy and, of course, Davey Jones himself.  Oh, and did you catch the Phantom of the Opera reference?Pirates of the Caribbean (II) suffers from the same fate as most sequels... we expect something better than the first.  I'm not sure this one is better than the first Pirates of the Caribbean.  I do know that, at the end, my feelings were similar to how I felt at the end of Star Wars Episode V.  Don't leave me hanging here!This was a great movie for the theater.  I anticipate a real letdown seeing it on a smaller home theater system or television.

reviewText: I was lucky enough to catch a showing of "Pirates of the Caribbean:  Dead Man's Chest" at the El Capitan theater in Hollywood, CA which uses a digital projector.  I remember being astounded by the clear quality of the movie projected in front of me and yet at the same time I lamented the fact that such quality could not be achieved at home.  Oh but I was wrong."Pirates of the Caribbean:  Dead Man's Chest" is one of the best looking films released on the Blu -ray format.  The transfer of this movie holds a standard that all Blu-ray and HD DVD releases should be held to.  The picture here is absolutely spectacular and the audio thankfully is uncompressed from its original source.  Unfortunately the praise ends there.Sadly I can't say that such a great looking Blu-ray disc contains a great movie.  Although I did enjoy  "Pirates of the Caribbean:  The Curse of the Black Pearl" I, like many other people, felt that Johnny Depp carried the movie much farther than it deserved to go.  That movie would have been your basic Bruckheimer production with a thin plot line serving as an excuse for chases, fight scenes, and explosions.  But it was the character Jack Sparrow that proved to be most compelling.Well, Jack Sparrow is back but he's been he's on his way to becoming a caricature.  This time out we are familiar with this character so he's not as much fun as in the first movie.  The plot here is too nonsensical to go into and the romance between Will Turner and Elizabeth Swann is a major yawner.Also, there are too many sequences in this movie that try to be funny but are just plain silly.  An example is the scene on an island in which the camera follows pieces of fruit being thrown at Jack Sparrow and close ups of the splatters.  What is this?  Nickelodeon?  Another scene that was played for laughs, Jack Sparrow, Will Turner, and Norrington dualing on a mill wheel, goes on way to long.This is a great looking disc, but a poor movie.  Enjoy.
summary: Great Looking Disc Spoiled By A Mediocre Movie

reviewText: Hollywood these days seems to work along the lines of monkeys in a room with typewriters producing Shakespeare.  Eventually something truly great, exciting, and visually rewarding emerges and everyone rejoices.  The first Pirates of the Caribbean film seemed like one such instance of cinematic brilliance, an amazing and unexpected movie that reminded people that big studios can consciously make good flicks.However, when I heard that two more Pirates films were in the works, I winced with expectant misery of being subjected to a rushed and unfullfilling trilogy.  Would the care (and necessary budget) be applied to these films?  Happily, if Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest is any indication, this series should end up being the most amazing and entertaining movie series of the decade.Why should folks go see this movie?  Three words:  Captain Jack Sparrow.  Johnny Depp's reprisal of the equillibrium challenged pirate should (if there's any justice in the world) lead to a second Academy Award nomination for the same character.  Jack Sparrow is quickly becoming the new James Bond, in terms of name recognition.  The difference is NO ONE ELSE could play Jack Sparrow, so (hopefully) this series shouldn't be driven into the ground like 007.I've been saying the word series alot in this review and there is a reason for that.  Amongst the enormous pile of things the film makers got right, with the first two movies, is the presentation.  Folks, a long time ago people would watch serials in their theaters before the feature presentation.  Ongoing stories that kept people coming back to the movies.  Pirates of the Caribbean is a feature length serial, with all the action, drama, mystery, humor, and this time around, horror that any movie fan could want.What else was done right?  How about the special effects.  Obviously this is a movie about pirates but there be monsters here as well.  In fact, there's a whole pirate crew of damned souls in servitude to Davy Jones, all of which have characteristics of some sea going creature.  Davy Jones himself (played vividly and unforgettably by Bill Nighy) bears an unmistakable resemblance to an octopi, complete with flowing, squirming, and tentacled locks.  The SFX are both gross and gorgeous, any worries about topping the moonlight skeletons from Curse of the Black Pearl should be keelhauled immediately.But wait, there's more.  This movie has some of the most entertaining action sequences in any film I've ever seen.  Gore Verbinski should be the new go-to guy for action in Hollywood.Keira Knightley really vamps it up this go around, clearly she's grown with her character (even if she's more on the sidelines this time).  Sexy, thy name is Keira.No cracks about the Kraaken.  The mythical beasty makes several sizeable appearances with many loving nods, er, tentacle wags toward Ray Harryhausen.  The Kraaken is one gigantic, angry, and hungry sea monster that adds to the rewatchability factor at least ten fold.A word of caution to parents who might want to bring their little ones to see this.  First, it's almost three hours long.  Second, it pushes the limits of the pg-13 rating.  This movie might be too intense for the kids.  Aww, who am I kidding.  Pirates of the Caribbean is a movie worth letting your children have nightmares over.  They'll thank you when they're older.If you're looking for rip roaring fun at the movies this summer Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest is the film to see.  100% Buckle Swash Guarantee.P.S. In the immortal words of Captain Jack Sparrow "You Smell Funny".

reviewText: "Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest" is an aspiring screenwriter's paradise, a dense, twisting, bulky construction that, in terms of sheer scope, is one of the more ambitious action scripts ever written: Here is a picture, written by Ted Elliot and Terry Rossio, that not only fleshes out some of the details from "The Curse of the Black Pearl" but gambles by resurrecting characters who easily could have been left dead. The three films are to be a sincere trilogy: The final plank, "At World's End," will likely better inform "Black Pearl," and vice versa. And the "Dead Man's Chest" is not predictable.But it's comfortable - because it's true - to dismiss "Dead Man's Chest" as a draining, boring experience, so plot-heavy that it tears at the sense of fun established in "Black Pearl." The two big action scenes are nearly identical and steal too much from the "Indiana Jones" series. Johnny Depp, as Captain Jack Sparrow, has vaguer, more passive role that mostly requires him to lurch through the story. Orlando Bloom and Keira Knightley are purposely kept apart. And so on. There are too many crews, too many heavies and too much exposition. "Dead Man's Chest" is an overdose. It is not a film I ever need to see again.A too-deep breath is required to explain all of the gunk trotted out over nearly three hours, so here's the very skinny: Captain Jack, Will (Bloom) and Elizabeth (Knightley) are all more or less after the treasure chest of Davy Jones (Bill Nighy), a half-dead squid man who commands a crew of half sea animals who sold their soul to him. Now, best I can tell, this ship, the "Flying Dutchman," zips about with its giant kraken floating underneath it plundering boats and capturing more souls. Jones wants Jack's soul, Jack wants the chest, Elizabeth, quite oddly, finds herself wanting Jack, Will wants, it seems, to simply get out of this movie, and somewhere behind all this is a Lord Beckett (Tom Hollander) of the East India Trading Company and the now-disgraced Norrington (Jack Davenport) dragged in from the first film.There are pardons, keys, cannibals, those two dummy pirates from "Black Pearl," two or three trips to Tortuga, an elaborate scene featuring Elizabeth's wedding dress, a letter from the king, a voodoo priestess, Jack's loyal crew, a dog, five attacks by the kraken, a giant water wheel, fruit, cages made of human bones, Will's half-dead father, a game of dice, a drunken brawl, two giant pigs and a scene where Jack shoots himself out of a coffin. It just goes on and on.Director Gore Verbinski falls into an easy trap: He takes the franchise too seriously. The music swells in this movie like a constant squall. Action is created in a sheer flurry without much interest in skill or believability. It's created for spectacle, not pace or purpose, as when Will, Norrington and Jack engage in a triangular swordfight that because begin to make much sense. Davy Jones is a remarkable creation, but without humor or dash like Geoffrey Rush in "Black Pearl." And Knightley resembles a sullen, withdrawn Rachel Ward from "Against All Odds": Save one juvenile scene, there is none of the girl's good-natured, brash pluck to enjoy. When a person is gifted with the ability to embody sunny cheer, it seems a shame to have her mope incessantly.Bloom just has no charm or wits at all as Will, and Depp seems to have lost something as Jack - he's too much a dope. He meanders around. He talks a lot. He runs like a cartoon, arms flailing, legs scampering. Really try to sprint like this for 100 meters, and see if you're still standing upright. It's not the boozy devil of "Black Pearl" but a boozy dummy. Davenport, as Norrington, actually has the most presence and cleverness. Hollander, too, embodies a crisp intelligence. While the rest of the cast plays around in drunkenness, wild-eyed lust and debauchery, the two boring villains walk in, survey the landscape, and calmly grab the picture. They're creeps. But focused.
summary: Twice the plot, half the fun.

reviewText: The first movie already contained a lot of bollocks, but this practically identical sequel just goes beyond a certain limit. Again we find brave Will, spice girl Elisabeth and Captain Jack Sparrow up against a seemingly invincible opponent, Captain Davy Jones who has, yes here the bollocks really kicks off seriously, a face made of octopus. Jones and his also half man half fish crew have controls over a huge sea monster and live under water. Sofar the real scary plot...everything is just way too smooth. There are no real bad guys and all violence comes with a smile. In that case I rather watch the old A-team series again instead of this. reviewText: The expectations were high for the Pirates 2, and the special effects were great. But for me it was too slimy regarding certain creatures like the Flying Dutchman, etc. that were prevalent throughout the movie. Also, the storyline was a little weak and it was hard to understand every actor. Yes, there was lots of action, but just nothing was a significant surprise like the things in the first Pirates flick. Good thing is that the same actors are in Pirates 2 that were in Pirates 1. Needless to say that this film will certainly produce some records at the box office since the first couple of days are virtually sold out everywhere. I would give it almost 4 1/2 stars, but somehow I was a little disappointed and I had to fight falling asleep in the last 30 minutes or so, ... but I'll watch it again. It's good fantasy and Pirate romance and kids can watch it too as there are no stupid scenes, but some kids may get nightmares because of the overexposure of some creatures. Also some motion sickness during some scenes might be possible with some viewers. The musical score and the photography are excellent and very impressive.

reviewText: This second in the 'Pirates' series starts out with the arrest of Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and Elizabeth Swan (Keira Knightley) for previously aiding Captain Jack Sparrow (the fantastic Johnny Depp).  Will is released on the condition that he brings back Sparrow's compass.But the search isn't really for the compass, its for the key and the contents of the infamous 'Dead Man's Chest', which supposedly contains the still beating heart of legendary Captain Davy Jones, captain of The Flying Dutchman with its crew of dead, and rather intriguing, men.The Flying Dutchman's crew has long since molded themselves to the sea, one being a hammerhead shark, another being a hermit crab, and yet another molded into the boat itself.  Captain Davy Jones is a squid with crab claws, and the FX on these costumes is among the best.The race is on to find the key, and the chest, between three men who each want the heart for their own selfish purposes.  Will, Sparrow, and the disgraced Norrington.  Not to mention Captain Jones.  Will is in for a surprise when he's bargained to Jones by Sparrow, finding his father among the disfigured dead, trapped on Jones' crew for eternity.For a Disney film, 'Dead Man's Chest' is a little rough for the kiddies.  I certainly wouldn't want my little ones watching a crow peck out a man's eyeball or seeing some of the nightmarish creations of Jones' crew.  But as an adult, it's extremely entertaining.  The escape from the island is particularly hilarious.My only complaint with the movie is that a) it's a bit long and b) it's only a chapter.  The ending holds no resolution and is an obvious continuation to part three when it comes out.  Too many important plot factors are left up in the air.  Overall, its just as entertaining as 'Black Pearl' but with far better FX and a bit more jaunty action.  I consider this movie worthy of a purchase.  Enjoy!
summary: Tis a pirate's life for me ...

reviewText: One of the biggest cinematic surprises in recent years was that The Pirates of the Caribbean: Curse of the Black Pearl didn't absolutely suck. With most movies that have a built in name recognition, the producers skimp on the writing thinking the name itself is enough to bring in moviegoers, which it usually does. Add to that the name recognition in this case for for an amusement park ride. And not only did The Pirates of the Caribbean didn't suck, it was thoroughly entertaining and landed Johnny Depp an Oscar nomination for his portrayal of Captain Jack Sparrow, the most ambiguously gay pirate since Captain Hook.Of course with the amount money the first movie raked in, a sequel was inevitable and Disney quickly filmed two of them at the same time. The most recent, Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest saw its DVD hit shelves this week. Also back for another round are Orlando Bloom and Keira Knightley who open the movie with a little bump on their way to the alter as they are arrested for helping Captain Jack to escape at the end of the last movie. But it's not really the British that the Captain is really worried about right now as Davy Jones is looking to collect on an agreement he made with Sparrow ten years ago while Jack tries to find a way out of it. Jones' minions are a visual marvel as they have taken on the appearance of sea creatures or started to although not as spectacular are the midnight skeleton scene of the first movie.Where the first movie was great throughout, the second one falls into your typical Jerry Bruckheimer fair: action to start and end the movie but not much substance in between. But the two action sequences are as good as they come. Surely even if you have yet to see the movie, you have at least seen parts of them in the trailer. The first comes while Sparrow makes a pit stop at the nearest island because Jones can't walk on land only to run into some cannibals. The escape from the natives is fast and furious and has plenty of comedic elements thrown in thanks to Depp's performance and we even meet up with some familiar faces from the first movie. The movie end with another dazzling scene that had to take forever to plan which includes and one on one on one sword fight and one on two on an army that go on at the same time. Okay that scene does quite close the movie because the movie officially ends on a cliffhanger (but be sure to fast forward past the credits for one last laugh). I can't express how much I hate the idea of a cliffhanger for a movie and almost ruins Dead Man's Chest. But of course that won't stop me for reserving a seat for At World's End next summer.
summary: Turns out Not Even Jack Sparrow Can Best the Devil
Title: N/A

reviewText: Take your logic, your intellect, and your cynicism and chuck it over the side - the "Pirates" franchise is back and bigger than ever with "Dead Man's Chest."  And that's a darn good thing.This is a series that knows what it is - popcorn fodder extraordinaire.  I could try to recap the plot for you, but there are so many twists, turns, and subplots that I'd quickly run out of space. Suffice it to say that this is "Curse of the Black Pearl," only turned up to 11.What does it say about a flick when Stellen Skarsgard and Bill Nighy can play characters that resemble aquatic genetic mutations crossed with a zombie and still say that they get completely upstaged by another monster, the Kraken?  "Dead Man's Chest" is action, but with a brain and a wondrous imagination.  Too many sequels are extended reprises of the original, including dubious self-references to the first film.  While there is some of that here, most of it is done lightly and with tongue firmly in cheek - you can't help but grin when Jack Sparrow quickly mutters "Hide the rum" when encountering Keira Knightley's Elizabeth again.And ultimately Depp makes this movie, just as he did the first go-round.  Sure, he's surrounded by some excellent actors and special effects, but Depp carries this franchise as few have been carried - with a drunken stumble and a hilarious leer.  God only knows if Depp really hates or loves playing Sparrow, but he surely plays him with the same zeal that Mike Meyers brings to Austin Powers/Dr. Evil or that Jim Carrey brings to Ace Ventura - this is a character for the ages.Family-friendly but definitely scary at times when the Kraken shows up, "DMC" is a worthy second act in a three-act series - "At World's End" is teed up about as well as a next installment could ever hope to be.
summary: "Dead Man's Chest" keeps the franchise rocking the Seven Seas

reviewText: I thought this movie was great: it was energetic, moved along at a fierce clip, and contrary to what others think, I thought the story was quite coherent. I can hardly wait for the third and (alas) last instalment.I was afraid that Depp would not be as endearing(?) as he was in the first, but he was even better. And that Gore Verbinski and the writers capitalised on the chemistry that Depp creates with everyone (in this case Knightley) is credit to them.The special effects were, every one of them, a part of the story and not just for show. And they were extremely well done for the most part. There was a part of the 'wheel sequence' where it was obvious the 'world' was moving and not the wheel (check and you'll see the people in the wheel never go upside down even though it keeps turning).  But I forgive them that since the rest of the wheel bit was actually real (see Disc 2).  Every bit of the $225m was money well spent.I give the movie 5 very enthusiastic stars! :-DThe DVD extras were as usual well done. Disney's prices generally are way up there, but they never skimp on the extras and these were no exception.  The commentary by the writers was just OK to me.  They spent too much time second-guessing themselves and (in my opinion) not giving enough credit to the audience.  It would have been wonderful to have the stars (OK - Johnny) do commentary.  I really liked "Creating Jack Sparrow", but the extras were all pretty good.But what was with the Bloopers (on Disc 1) being brought to us by Verizon Wireless??? Even my slightly-jaded-as-to-the-commercial-aspect-of-everything-self was taken aback. Ah well.DVD Extras - 4.5 stars - the writers commentary and the 'commercial' - ewww - cost them half a star.See you all in the theatre come summer!

reviewText: Pirates of The Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest - A"You know, these clothes do not fancy you at all. It should be a dress or nothing. I happen to have no dress in my cabin."Here we are, the second installment in the ever popular Pirates of The Caribbean trilogy, Dead Man's Chest. Let's get right to it, I loved this movie. I enjoyed the first one a great deal so I had very high hopes and expectations for the sequel. Gore Verbinski has most definitely not let me down, in fact, he blew them away.Legend has it that a tortured soul called Davy Jones lives beneath the sea, his still-beating broken heart locked away in a chest, and a terrible sea beast at his command. Unfortunately for the notorious pirate, Captain Jack Sparrow, this particular legend is very real. Years ago, Jack made a deal with Davy Jones, who is now expecting him to make good on his promise by handing himself over to Jones's servitude. But Jack will not give in without a fight, which is especially bad news for Will Turner and Elizabeth Swann, who always seem to get caught up in Jack's mishaps. If Jack can't find a way to rid himself of Davy Jones once and for all, it may just spell the end for the three adventurers.That's the story of this grand adventure. The whole crew returns for the sequel. Orlando Bloom is Will Turner and does an adequate job. Not exactly what you'd expect from him but it isn't a bad performance in the least. Keira Knightley is back as Elizabeth Swan. She gives a good performance and it's nice to see her in the thick of things and not just a background damsel in distress. Stellan Skarsgrd is a newcomer as "Bootstrap" Bill Turner, Will's father. He gives an outstanding performance and it completely believable. Bill Nighy is Davy Jones. No, he is Davy Jones. That character, despite being completely CGI is damn believable. Not once did I not believe that character was doing something, his face is so realistic looking. But the star of the show is of course, Johnny Depp as Captain Jack Sparrow. He blows his performance in the original away completely, and that's saying something. His entrance in this one is even better than it was in the first one. It's damn funny too. The supporting cast is fine as well, they all get the job done.This is a very CGI heavy movie but it doesn't necessarily feel it. Sure we know there is lots of CGI being used, but it is all so believable that its not really noticeable, even if we know that it is CGI. As I said before, Davy Jones looks amazing. Maybe not as good as Kong last year but damn impressive for what he is and looks like. His crew is amazing as well. The creature designers are true geniuses. Some of the designs and concepts are out there, but damned fun to look at. Each is pulled off wonderfully and given the same amount of attention and care so not one looks out of place or more fluid or detailed than another. Each is a distinct design too and seeing them onscreen is a sight to behold. Especially when you see them on the beach in the daylight, they look damn amazing there. Jones' weapons, The Kraken, is easy on the eyes as well. It isn't in the movie a lot but when it is, watch out. It isn't convincing all the time but it is most of the time and you can tell that in those sequences, great care was taken.The first Pirates had some good action sequences in it. They were exciting and entertaining but mostly run of the mill stuff we expect in movies about pirates. It's taken up a notch (or 6 or 7) for this one. There's one particular scene past the midway point where three people are sword fighting. This could have easily been a small little fight and taken up little time. But instead, it's blown up into this huge battle that spans the whole island, and not for one second are you bored by it. It's very intense and this scene alone beats out all the other action scenes from the first one. The scenes with the Kraken are expertly handled. The camera shots are good and not obtrusive. Everything is clear and you know what's going on. That goes for the fighting scenes as well. Its nice to see a director pull back the camera for once so we can see what's going on, it makes a world of difference.The music is epic here. Hans Zimmer does a wonderful job. While it is epic and of good listening, it never overshadows the movie like some scores do (i.e. Elfman's Batman). Each piece perfectly compliments the scene it is used in and enhances it greatly. When the scene is exciting the music is loud and momentous when it's a low-key scene, the music is the same way. This is a great example of what a great score can accomplish. I'm still humming the main theme as I type this.The directing is very tight on this one. There's no doubt in my mind that Gore Verbinski is the absolute perfect director for this series. He brings a dark undertone to the movies and I honestly don't know how this one secured a PG-13 rating. A raven right at the beginning gouges out a man's eyeball, and it doesn't pull away. It lets us see it for a few seconds then pulls away, definitely  not something you'd expect to see in a Disney movie. In another scene, one of Jones' crew members stomach is cut open with a sword, fish and body juice (not blood) spill out all over the deck while the man is trying to keep everything from falling out. Again, great fun to look at but not something you'd expect from Disney. Of course, the ending is absolutely perfect. It ends on a cliffhanger but the very last scene (not the one after the credits) with Tia Dalma is classic. It brought a HUGE smile to my face and is executed perfectly. At World's End looks to be even better than this one was.Overall, this is the perfect sequel (not the best, but exactly what a sequel should be). The acting is great, the effects are great eye candy, the music is great, and the action is kicked up and is very exciting. The story is just getting started and I for one cannot wait for the third one next May. This is not a case of "Matrix-itis" where just because it's a big budget sequel shot back to back with another sequel, it is disappointing. Far from it. If you liked the first one you'll love this one.
summary: Yo Ho Yo Ho A Pirate's Life For Me...

reviewText: I swear these movies go nowhere, I mean on some level they are swashbuckling fun, but it gets old quick and this opus is almost three hours.  The screenplay is all over the place, I mean do you expect to find a voodoo priestess in the south pacific, it's like the writer was just like..why not?  I like everyone else, liked Depps Keith Richards impersonation in the first movie, but it's a one note trick, it's like ok we get it, you're doing Richards.  Frankly, im no fan of Bloom, he just does not responate, he gets lost when he is on screen with Depp or Knightly but I did like many of Sparrows crew, they were very funny at times.  The special effects were excellent, no doubt much money was spent on this film and you can help but be awed by it, but this is without question the weakest of the three movies; it's overlong and short on story, that sound contraditory I know, but there it is..enjoy.

reviewText: Someone earlier mentioned that they were disappointed that there were no 'extra deleted scenes' included on the disc. My answer to why that is is likely - Because they were ALL included IN the actual movie! (lol)  Though I fairly enjoyed the film (not nearly as much as the first) I do feel sadly that there were occasional good bits here and there (Bill Nighy's character (I like the scene where he's playing the organ in particular), The spinning wheel duel, and a few scant others...) that could have been easily included into a MUCH tighter, better scripted & plotted, edited (& even acted) film that could have been on par if not surpassing the original. I have to admit that in the past I was often a tad suspect of Gore Verbinski's directing style, as to me he often started with an interesting idea that was somehow often lost in an awkward, meandering climax that managed before the very end to sap all the edge and/or humor out of the whole affair. Much to my surprise, the original 'Pirates' (Which I still give Depp's input the most credit for - despite either Verbinski or {shudder} Bruckheimer) and his take on 'The Ring'.. had me starting to think of him in a much better light.  But alas, this film seems from beginning to over-long (non)ending to be a complete study of that old familiar out-of-control, tumbling-down-the-stairs and NOT QUITE landing on it's feet style. It was... ok, fun in spots, and had nifty special effects to be sure.  But I do hope the third film brings all involved to much better redeemed heights.  (Save perhaps the 'Bruckster' - He'll swim the Cheez-Wiz Seas for all Eternity... ;O)

reviewText: Captain Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) is a marked man.  He pledged to serve as part of Davy Jones' (Bill Nighy) crew for 100 years in return for being Captain on the Black Pearl for 13 years.  Desperate to escape this fate, Captain Jack flees to land, where Davy Jones' has no power.  Unfortunately, he lands on an island of cannibals, who believe that he is the reincarnation of one of their gods and must be set free from his mortal body - by being eaten.Meanwhile, Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and Elizabeth Swann (Kiera Knightley) are eagerly awaiting their wedding day in Port Royale.  The ceremony is rudely interrupted by the arrival of Cutler Beckett (Tom Hollander), a representative of the East India Trading Company, who has warrants for the arrest and hanging of both Will and Elizabeth for their involvement with Captain Jack.  But Cutler doesn't really want Jack and he doesn't care at all about Elizabeth and Will - what he really wants is Jack's compass.  For Jack's compass doesn't just point to the Isla de Muerta, no, it leads you to your heart's desire...Cutler has a deal for Will - get the compass from Jack and he will let them go free.  Will immediately sets off to find Captain Jack and eventually tracks him to the cannibals' island, where mayhem ensues trying to get Jack free and get off the island.  But escaping the island is only the beginning of their troubles - for Jack has found a way to escape Davy Jones, but it involves finding Jones' heart, which is locked in a case at an unknown location and can only be opened by a key that he can't find.  Jack offers Will a trade - his compass for the key to Davy Jones' chest...I was completely blown away by Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest.  I was expecting it to be good, but this movie far exceeded my expectations.  Johnny Depp is absolutely marvelous as Captain Jack Sparrow.  He retains the same funny mannerisms and sly humor as he did in the first one, but he has now really deepened the character to include more dark overtones so you never really know what to expect, especially since his life is on the line.  Kiera Knightley was luminous in her role as Elizabeth Swann and, this time, she really got to cut loose and show that she can keep up with the boys.  She is a really spunky character who is not content to just sit around and be rescued, but is determined to be involved in the adventure.  Orlando Bloom really surprised me in his reprisal of his Will Turner role.  He has made great strides since the last film and his character showed a great deal more depth than the first time we met him.  Will is still naive and innocent in a lot of ways, but he is slowly having that naivety stripped away through his interaction with Captain Jack and is letting his inner pirate out.  I felt that his character has the most development in this film and am excited to see where he takes Will in the third film.In addition to an excellent leading cast, the supporting characters were amazing.  Bill Nighy was goosebumpingly creepy in his role as Davy Jones and was an absolutely amazing villain.  Considering he was in very heavy makeup and prosthetics for the entire film, he really only had his voice and body mannerisms to make the character - but he really made the character.  Jack Davenport returns as Commodore Norrington and it was fun to see the prim and proper Commodore really cut loose now that he has lost everything.  Jonathan Pryce makes the most of his small role reprising Governor Weatherby Swann.  He added a much needed touch of realism and heartfelt feeling to the film while he struggled to save his daughter without compromising his integrity.  Tom Hollander was utterly creepy in his role of Cutler Beckett.  I am so used to seeing him as a bumbling fool (Mr. Collins in Pride & Prejudice and Anthony Meredith in Gosford Park) that it was a delight to see him take on the mantle of a cool, calculating villain who destroys lives in the name of profit and is not afraid to admit it.  Lee Arenberg (Pintel - the fat, balding pirate) and Mackenzie Crook (Ragetti - the tall, thin pirate with the wooden eye) are once again perfect to add the much needed comic relief when the movie starts to get too grim and I am so glad that they came back to participate in films 2 & 3.  New characters include Naomie Harris as Tia Dalma (a voodoo priestess) and Stellan Skarsgard (Bootstrap Bill) who really made the most of their roles in this film and I hope come back for the 3rd.The cast really make the film, but you simply cannot talk about this film without mentioning the spectacular special effects or the breathtaking fighting sequences.  Gore Verbinski really outdid himself this time as both the effects and the stunts were absolutely amazing.  Now that I have gushed about the movie for several paragraphs, I do want to say that, no, this is no great epic that will last through the ages.  It is very definitely a middle film in a trilogy that leaves you hanging with a lot of unanswered questions, but it is summer entertainment at its best.  Suspend belief and go to the movie just to sit and escape the world for a while.  With nonstop, breathtaking action, plenty of laughs, excellent acting, a delightfully creepy score and everything you need to be entertained for 2.5 hours this movie is simply not to be missed!

reviewText: Recently I have been lamenting the lack of quality adventure films in the vein of Back to the Future and Indiana Jones; I feel the Pirates series satiates my cravings. Jerry Bruckheimer, the producer, is known for over-the-top movies that defy belief so much it's distracting to the story, but perhaps director Gore Verbinski has toned him down a bit. Pirates is still over-the-top excitement, but it really doesn't distract from the storytelling the team of writers maintain. I'm not sure what went on in developing the final two chapters, but Will Turner and Elizabeth Swann end up in the adventure somewhat as an aside - Dead Man's Chest is really Jack Sparrow's movie. I could go into the story, but it seems pointless, the story is linear and the characters seem to develop almost forcefully. There are detours in the film that seem to only exist for spectacular adventure and could easily have been cut from the movie, especially when it ends at over 2 and a half hours in length. The cannibal island act didn't do anything for the story except to bring together four characters from the previous film. It seems like they couldn't figure out how to get these people in the story any other way. Honestly, the characters all come from different places and all end up on the same island together just to be chased about by cannibal tribes-people (some of which looked like Irishmen). Some of the characters were introduced in this film seemingly for no reason, but our main characters seem to be quiet fond of them. Besides some weak elements, as mentioned, everything was amazing. The story drew you into it with compelling drama, suspense and adventure. The action was exciting and big (true to Bruckheimer's pedigree). The vistas were amazing; filmed on location in the Bahamas. The most impressive part of it all was the innovative, cutting-edge CGI effects. It is amazing to see how far computer generated images have come over the years.
