reviewText: First of all, I saw this movie twice; and, as mentioned before, it is enjoyable - if you don't think about it too hard.  I confess, I found this installment to be "campier" than the first one.  I thought the schiskabab bit to be a bit much.  There were dull repeats of lines that were actually funny in the first movie - but they don't play as well in this second movie.  This movie seemed to underdevelop the characters the further it went along, undoing much of the development that the first movie succeeded in creating.  Jack Sparrow, though entertaining, suffered greatly from this.  We know he is a pirate, but some of his actions left you asking "what?"  Davy Jones was a great concept, and is masterfully acted out by Bill Nighy - but the CGI ruins it a bit.  Why couldn't they have put a prosthesis on him instead?  His crustacean encrusted crew, being so obviously CGI has a hard time comparing to Captain Barbossa's undead crew.  True, they were CGI too, but they seem to have been done better.  I think that producers were in such a rush to film movies 2 and 3 back to back, a that they welched a bit on the special effects budget.  Needless to say, I found myself missing Geoffrey Rush terribly, and it makes you realize that a flesh and bones villan adds a depth that no computer can match.This movie also leaves the viewer with a lot of questions.  One of my biggest problems was with the fact that Will and Elizabeth were ready to condemn Jack to the briny deep for his betrayal, and then suddenly all was forgiven, and they sat around with tears in their eyes declaring what a good man Jack was - did I miss a scene???  There should have been more development there, or at least acknowledge the realization on Will's part that would have brought this change of heart.  Maybe they did film such a scene, but the editors took it out to put some more flashy effects in.  The past between Sparrow and Davy Jones should have been developed more as well.  On the whole, this movie left me puzzled  and unfulfilled in many scenes - save one: I love the last scene in the film, and my above comment will attest to that!On the whole, this film was a fun 2+ hours, but I don't think it was a well thought out as the first one.  If we consider it to be merely a segway to the third film, then perhaps some of my questions will be answered and my concerns relieved.  I will buy this film, eventually.  I don't want to buy it yet, because once the third one comes out, I'm sure they will release them all in a pretty little gift set.  I do hope that the third film is more on par with the first film.  I was upset about the Empire Strikes Back in '80 (Geez has it been that long?!?!?!) too, and I found that I enjoyed it more after Return of the Jedi came out.  When the three films are played back to back - they make good sense on the whole.  I hope it will be the same with Pirates.  See you at World's End!!!!!
summary: Beyond this place... there be plot holes!

reviewText: Johnny Depp is back as Captain Jack Sparrow.  When Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley) is put in prison for whatever reason, it's up to Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) to get Jack's compass to give to whoever put Elizabeth in prison in order to set her free.  Jack also needs Will's help with finding a key that will open a special treasure chest."Pirates 2" has non-stop action from beginning to end, and I was at the edge of my seat watching intently.  Meet the most disgusting-looking characters (sea phantoms), such as octopus-head (I forget his name in the movie - The Dutchman, I think!), and that other guy who had a head as a saw fish.I recommend watching Pirates to anyone who saw the first one.  It's long, but it's worth every minute.
summary: Pirates of the Caribbean 2: Dead Man's Chest
Title: N/A

reviewText: When I heard the movie had a midnight showing, I couldn't resist.  The first Pirates of the Caribbean was a surprise success in my mind.  A movie based off a theme park ride?  How would that work out?  Pirates of the Caribbean became one of the most successful films of 2003.  Spotting a fantastic cast lead by Johnny Depp.  The dialogue was witty and clever, the adventure one to remember for a lifetime.  Brought on, of course, by fine actors at the helm.Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest takes off a few months after the first movie.  Elizabeth and Will's wedding is crashed by the East India Trade Company.  It seems Will and Elizabeth have to pay the price for helping Jack escape.  The East India Trade Company is willing to strike a bargain, however.  If Will can get Jack to turn over his compass, then he and Elizabeth can escape an appointment with the gallows.  But why does the East India Trade Company want Jack's compass?  The secret goes deeper than one could imagine.We then see several people dumping coffins off an island.  One of them happens to hold Jack Sparrow (CAPTAIN Jack Sparrow) as he has stolen away with a cloth that shows the next treasure he is after.  The key to Davy's Jones chest.  It seems our charming Captain has a debt to pay, and he can help to do away with it if he can get a hold of the real key itself.  Even more comes about when we discover the fate of Commodore Norrington, and just why Jack's compass is so special.  Simply put, Dead Man's Chest is not a rehash of the first film.  There is plenty of excitement to be had, and plenty of good fun and humor along the way.The cast of the first film all reprise their roles for this follow up.  Johnny Depp as Jack Sparrow is astonishing.  He has certainly out done himself in this movie.  Orlando Bloom and Keira Knightley also return to reprise their rolls as Will Turner and Elizabeth Swann.  As the adventure unfolds these actors are more than just acting.  They are who they are.  And when the end credits roll, it's like saying goodbye to an old friend you haven't seen for years.Other cast members return as well.  Kevin McNally reprises his role as Mr. Gibbs and much like the others, it's like reuniting with a friend you haven't seen for a while.  Jack Davenport also returns as Norrington and his performance is just as charming as Johnny Depp's.  Not much has happened between the two movies to the characters, but the movie does a brilliant job of filling in any holes that may have been left from the first film.New cast members are also a blessing.  However, of the new cast, only two characters are important at all.  Bootstrap Bill played by Stellan Skarsgard and Davy Jones played by Bill Nighy.  Both cast members fit in quite well with the movie and the story as a whole.  Bill Nighy rightfully does a fantastic job as Davy Jones.  He's just as sinister and evil like as Geoffrey Rush playing Barbosa in the first film.The movie also sports some fabulous special effects.  Even better than that of the first film.  Seeing the large monstrous tenticles of Kraken raise from the sea is a wonder to behold on the big screen.  Seeing those tenticles rip a ship apart is just as amazing to take a look at.  Perhaps the best part of these effects are Davy Jones and his crew.  If you thought the skeletons of the first film were amazing, this will truly blow your mind.Along with those special effects come some magnificant battles and swordfights to go along with them.  While some of them can drag on for a while, they are, for the most part, fun to watch.  Even Keira Knightley gets a chance to partake in some swordplay this time, and watching her is just as fun as watching the others do their tricks.The dialogue may not be as witty and charming as the first film, but it has a lot of good moments and throwbacks to the first film.  For example, when Elizabeth first approaches Jack wanting to get on board his ship he quickly tells Mr. Gibbs to hide the rum, a clever throwback to the first film that just about any fan will understand.  There are plenty of other throwbacks and inside jokes with the first film as well, and they're all funny and charming in their own way.This movie is just about as fun (if not MORE fun) than the first film.  The only sad thing is that like every movie, it has to end.  It does, however, do a fantastic job at setting us up for the third film in the series.  And also like the first movie, there's more if you sit through the credits.Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest is fun for the whole family.  Not only does it maintain the charm and wit of the first film, but it doesn't spend a lot of time rehashing it.  Dead Man's Chest is just as good, if not better, than the first film.  Enjoy!

reviewText: Pirates Of The Carribean: Curse of the Black Pearl was an enjoyable, creepy and funny pirate movie. Dead Man's Chest, the film's first of many sequels to come, has Johnny Depp (Donnie Brasco) delivering an extraordinary performance once again, but the movie overall gets washed away into the sea with the Black Pearl.Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed some of the film's action sequences, but it didn't awaze me as much as the original did (maybe I'm not a pirate fan after all!). What struck me about Pirates 2 were the cliches (a disgusting Octopus-like creature using its arms to snatch people and destroying the ship has been used before, and is used twice in the film), Depp's satirical performance (running around tied to a barbeque stick), and the cliffhanger ending (brace yourselves for a Pirates 3 movie coming out soon!).Maybe it is me, but Pirates 2 really didn't cause me to jump, cheer, and go insane. Maybe I'm getting old to watch all these Disney films, or maybe the film itself is lacking substance or new material to deliver. It's up to you to judge. One thing I can assure you of is that Pirates 2 is a much better sequel than Superman Returns. Unlike the latter, Pirates succeeds in staying true to its predecessor.Mildly recommendedC

reviewText: I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed the first "Pirates of the Caribbean" film a few summers back.  Imagine my supreme disappointment to find that I did not like its sequel, in spite of virtually the entire cast and the director returning.  The film opens with Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and his fiancee Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley) being arrested by Norrington (Jack Davenport), who desires a compass owned by Captain Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp). Not surprisingly, Sparrow is up to no good, and bad goes to worse for him when he is paid a visit by an old, quasi-dead friend (Stellan Skarsgard), who reminds him that the legendary Davy Jones (Bill Nighy)is seeking him to reclaim a debt.  The plot gets deeper, and stinkier, from here, as Jack finds himself in situation after situation, with the story stalling, then moving a bit, then stalling, then moving a bit, etc.The saving grace of this mess is Johnny Depp, who gets the opportunity to show off his gift for screwball comedy.  Orlando Bloom and Keira Knightley are relegated to barely-supporting roles, and there are too many sequences that misfire.  The original film had a spirit of fun that is missing here, and everyone, including Depp, seems to be winking at the camera as if to say, "did you get that joke, huh, didja?"  The finale of the film is a setup for the third, but by then I didn't care.  Most people this weekend will see this film - in fact, it's already on the verge of setting records.  But I implore you, if you feel the need to see a popcorn film this or any other weekend, see Superman Returns instead.  Final grade: D/ F if you ignore Depp
summary: "Pirates" capsizes under its own weight; doesn't hold water

reviewText: As I said in Pirates 1, there isn't much one can add to the discussion of these Pirate films at this point and with not having reviewed them before and after a weekend of watching Pirates 1 and 2 in anticipation of 3 next week, I thought it time to write up something on this sequel.I sincerely doubted that the team that gave us Pirates 1 could possibly top themselves with Pirates 2, but it appears that if they didn't top themselves, they at least succeeded with a film that, for the most part, is as equally good and entertaining as the first.  Oh, how rare that is in "sequelville."Everything I thought was great about the first is present in the second, except that this film is a bit less original, but still enormously clever.  It does what a sequel should do in that it gives us more of what we liked in the original film, has the storyline continue in some digestible manner and not just rehash the previous film, and has our characters not only be as familar as they were in the first film, but grow in the sequel as well.  Pirates 2 does all this and with great gusto and skill.  The special effects are different rather than better, but they are just as enjoyable and don't detract from the story or attempt to make up for poor writing. Gore Verbinski, the director, continues to captain this fleet of films with confidence and clear direction.  Hans Zimmer's music which although repetitive in this film is very welcomed as it really helps to define the Pirate films.  It's one of the best scores to a series of films since Indiana Jones.  Lastly, you have to love how this team found another great entrance for Depp.  I thought the first was the best I had ever since for a leading man and this one has to be the second.  Kudos to the writers for their cleverness and creativity there!Lightning can strike twice and boy I'm praying that it can three times.  I have never looked this forward to sequels before and I doubt I ever will again.  I'm good for more sequels and even prequels from this team.

reviewText: Like a Tintin adventure, there's fast-paced adventure in exotic lands with strange natives, exotic stunts a-plenty. There's the introduction of a new villain, the nefarious Lord Turner (who carries some sort of supernatural threat about his that is, sadly, never realised, nor do we ever see the mark Jack Sparrow left on him). Some ways into the film things start to get hot and heavy and plenty weird as we find Jack Sparrow now the chief of an island of cannibals. Great gags, stunts and physical humour here that include rotting fruit, a round cage of human bones hung over a cliff. Great dialogue and interchange between Jack and Gibbs, and between Pintel and Ragetti (not to mention Ragetti's bouncing eye) who share a surreal argument about the Bible, "you get credit for trying".Then there's the witch Tia Dalma, who speaks in a thick Caribbean twang, "you have a touch of destiny about you, Will Turner." "How'd you know my name?" Don't we all have a touch of destiny about us? Nonetheless, the dialogue is terrific, and the screenplay crisp, such as the argument over the correct pronunciation of "Kraken" - "It's a mythological creature, I'll pronounce it's name how I wants." (strangely, it falls flat in the third movie - this may be the best Pirates movie). Nice little dance, spin and spit when pirates confronted by a possible ghost (a nice trick played by Elizabeth Swann). "I don't give an azz rat's if I love or die." Each scene gorgeously luxurious. Davey Jones' tentacled face gorgeous, his snorting and weird way of talking great fun.His crewe are too CG-ladled, though, although the scum and grime coating the Flying Dutchman seems to have a deliciously grody life of its own. Elizabeth's flirt with Jack is a bit of a come-on, both in the middle and at the end. The three-man Caribbean swordfight is stunning choreography, as is the fight within the water wheel, and the rapid switching of sides, the battle over the dead man's chest, great physical humor. Awesome finale.This film marks the emergence of Stellan Skarsgrd as Bootstrap Bill, Will Turner's father. The name Stellan Skarsgrd is unknown to me, despite having actually seen him in tons of films - The Kingdom, Breaking The Waves, Insomnia, Thor and The Avengers.

reviewText: We may not have made the midnight showing but we were there front and center for the 7 PM showing on the opening night of PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: DEAD MAN'S CHEST. The theater was packed and all but vibrating with the sort of excitement usually reserved for INDIANA JONES and LORD OF THE RINGS movies. While not quite as good as the first movie, it was still great summer fun.Without going into major spoilers, I will tell you that the new movie sports a number of delicious developments including a deepening of the romantic triangle between Elizabeth Swann, Will Turner and Captain Jack and an ending that makes you wish May 2007 was next monthinstead of a year away.My most thrilling discovery during the movie came when I asked myself that eternal question: Captain Jack or Will Turner??? And discovered that my answer (surprisingly enough) was: Commodore Norrington! I must confess that I barely noticed Commodore Norrington (played by Jack Davenport) in the first movie (although judging by several fanlistings on the internet, some of the more astute female viewers did). I just remember him as the handsome, clean shaven, somewhat stuffy fiance of Elizabeth Swann who nobly gave Captain Jack a head start when he was escaping from the gallows and let Elizabeth go into Will Turner's arms at the end of that movie.But in the new movie, the former commodore is unshaven, dirty, drunk, desperate, brawling and out for revenge. And of course (being a romance writer)--suddenly I find him utterly irresistible! He needs to be redeemed! He needs love! He needs the perfect woman! He needs MEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE!!!(Originally published on the website of author Teresa Medeiros at [...])

reviewText: At the time of this writing, this DVD has sold something like 11 million copies, which means that regardless of what I say, you probably already have this or it's wrapped up underneath your tree. As usual, I'm just here to weigh in with my two cents, so feel free to keep reading, if you wish.I'm not completely sold on this movie in all honesty. I've watched it at least three times since I've received it and I've come away from it with several things:Johnny Depp is a pleasure to watch. His charm has worn off a bit since the first POTC but he still delivers the goods. For me though, the one reason to see this movie is Bill Nighy, the man who plays Davy Jones. I absolutely love this character. The design on him is magnificent and it's really difficult for me to believe that he's a CG creation. Nighy does a fantastic job and if there's any reason that I've been going back to watch this at all, it's because of him. Still, this movie is a bit too long in all honesty and I think that's what the main problem with it is. I'm waiting patiently for the third one, to see just how the trilogy ends and how this film fits in the overall scheme of things.This two disc dvd has some nice packaging with an eyecatching holographic slipcase. I'm recommending it because it has some nice featurettes and a really enjoyable and fascinating film commentary by the writers of the film. After watching it with the commentary, I'd have to say that I have a little more appreciation for how many small details the movie has that were worked in but you may or may not have noticed upon watching it. Other than that, there is a feature on the creation of the Davy Jones character that I implore you to watch, just so you can see for yourself just how far special effects have come in terms of character creation.I'll recommend this DVD as the good far outweighs the bad. I would have liked a DTS track like the first POTC DVD had but other than that, the picture is presented nicely here and sounds pretty great anyway. If you loved or even just liked the movie, you'll be satisfied with this disc.

reviewText: The first PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN was fun but I think its huge success went to the filmmakers' heads because the excesses of the sequels definitely take a toll on the franchise.More, more, more...of everything, except the fun.  Long, convoluted action scenes, a jumbled mythology weighing everything down.  Heavy helpings of CGI and stock plots.  Excess ruined THE MATRIX trilogy and it also nearly sunk the Pirates.There was a decent balance of the thin characters in the first movie but more of these people are definitely less.  Does anyone really care about Orlando Bloom and Keira Knightley's lovers?  In the sequels, they both appear to be doing nothing but posing and defiantly jutting their jaws at the never-ending battles.Yes, there's action and special effects and fighting and swordplay and cannons...but eventually it's just noise.

reviewText: Pirates of the Caribbean, Dead Man's Chest, is a fun movie to watch, even if the plot may make several people roll their eyes a little. It definately is exciting, the action is intense and the special effects are truly something to be seen (examples that come to mind are Davy Jones' tentacle face, the sea monster called the Kraken when it attacks ships in the open sea, and when Davy Jones' ship dives underwater) Some may not like the ending as a cliffhanger, but I found it a great way to lead into the third and (hopefully not) the final movie of this great story.Johnny Depp returns as the charming, yet off his rocker pirate known as Jack Sparrow. He has a life debt to the mysterious and deadly Davy Jones and cannot sail out in the open sea for fear of Davy Jones's sea monster, the Kraken, eating him and his ship The Black Pearl. Desperate to stay one step ahead of Davy Jones and his damned crew of sailors, Sparrow heads toward dry land.Orlando Bloom and Kiera Knightley return as well as Will Turner and Elizabeth Swann who are about to be married. However they are roped into finding Jack Sparrow as Will sets off to bring back Jack's broken compass to Cutler Beckett, a powerful and ruthless EITC agent who arrests Elizabeth Swann and Will Turner shortly before their wedding. They were arrested because they helped Jack Sparrow escape hanging in the previous film, and after being arrested Will makes a deal with Beckett who wants Sparrow's compass.The whole movie is about a giant cat and mouse game with plenty of humor sewn in between to bring it all together. Johnny Depp once again steals the spotlight as Jack Sparrow, and Davy Jones is another great treat to watch in this movie from his tencle face all the way down to his walk that he does as he paces back and forth in front of his crew.The action is spectacular but really far fetched in some places (an example that comes to mind is a three way sword fight on top of a rolling wind mill) not to mention a scene where the Kraken attacks the Black Pearl, but it is exciting just to watch. I actually went back the second the fight scene was over and watched it all over again!Extras include:Behind the scenes look at the entire moviedirector's commentarydeleted scenesthe making of Dead Man's Chestand much more!Anyways this is one movie that is awesome to see. Some may not find it as good as The Curse of the Black Pearl, but this is definately a good way to keep the entertainment at an all time high! recommended

reviewText: Yo ho, yo ho, a pirate's life for me.As I watched the new sequel, "Pirates of the Carribean: Dead Man's Chest", I felt transported back to the Black Pearl, as the dulcet tones of the crew singing a shanty enveloped me like a sea mist...Yo ho, yo ho, a pirate's life for me...Avast ye maties. Thar be a rip roaring adventure out there for all to enjoy. The sequel to the enormously popular film based on a ride at the Disney theme parks. "Dead Man's Chest" be one of those rare things, more precious than a Black Pearl, it be a sequel that works well. So far, "Dead Men's Chest" is the most enjoyable big studio release of the summer.We pillage, we plunder, we rifle, we loot...Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley) watches as rain pours down, destroying the area where her wedding was to take place. Soon, Lord Beckett (Tom Hollander), a leader of the East India Trading Company, arrives to arrest Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and Elizabeth, forcing the wedding to be cancelled indefinitely. But he doesn't really want either of them, he wants Captain Jack Sparrow's (Johnny Depp) compass, which can lead people to the location of what they most desire. But Sparrow has problems of his own. Regaining control of the Black Pearl, he soon realizes he has the Black Mark and must repay his debt to Davy Jones (Bill Nighy), the Captain of the Flying Dutchman, a creepy ship with a crew of Pirates who have died and pledged their allegiance to the half-man, half crustacean leader of the deep. If Sparrow is unable to repay the debt, Jones will release a terrible beast called the Kracken to reclaim the Black Pearl to the sea. But Sparrow is on a quest of his own, he wants to find a key; the key will open a buried chest containing the most prized possession of Davy Jones. Soon, all three are back together, fighting against one another and for the same cause.Drink up, me `earties, yo ho...One of the great pleasures of "Pirates of the Carribean" is Johnny Depps very eccentric performance. As Captain Jack Sparrow, he flounces around, channeling the spirit of Keith Richards into a boozy, effeminate ne'er do well who always manages to keep one step ahead of the authorities, enemies and death.We kidnap and ravage and don't give a hoot...Depp always provides an interesting performance, even when the film is less than spectacular. "Pirates" Sparrow seems to be the perfect combination for this esoteric actor's charms. Let's face it. Sparrow is an over the top character; a pirate who walks in a vapor of rum fumes, his dirty dreadlocks and bad teeth shining like beacons as he slurs his words. This pirate provides the actor with the perfect avenue for his abilities. In lesser hands, the character would be a disaster. But Depp embraces the role, kidnapping our better judgment, ravaging us with the persona. And he doesn't give a hoot.I have no doubt the character will be remembered for a long time.Drink up me `earties, yo ho...A key part of Depp's performance is Sparrow's constant influx of booze. In "Dead Man's Chest", he spends a significant amount of time worrying about his store of rum.Yo ho, yo ho, a pirate's life for me...Part of the reason for the success of this sequel is the return of the entire cast and key members of the crew. Depp, Orlando Bloom, Keira Knightley, Jack Davenport (British TV's "Coupling"), MacKenzie Crook (British TV's "The Office") and more. All of the actors from the first have returned, which is a bit of a spoiler. Think about it. Think about it. This means the sequel has a higher chance of being consistent with the first. In fact, they filmed both "Dead Man's Chest" and "Pirates 3" at the same time, ensuring even more consistency.But consistency can be bad. In some cases, this works. In others, it doesn't. Because the first film was so enjoyable, chances are the sequel would follow in the correct footsteps. Naturally, there are no guarantees. Look at "The Matrix" trilogy for how wrong this can go. First film, brilliant. Second film, good. Third film, a disaster. "The Lord of the Rings" trilogy was made as one large movie, with the cast and crew working consistently for years, and director Peter Jackson created a trilogy that will be remembered for ever.So far, we have a great first entry and a very enjoyable, amusing second.We extort, we pilfer, we filch and we sack...The biggest drawback to "Dead Man's Chest" is the lack of surprise in the performances. Much of the fun of the first film was watching Depp's great performance as he revealed more and more nuances. The performance is amusing and fun, but it doesn't surprise us.Unfortunately, bringing all of the characters back means Orlando Bloom returns as well. Bloom is good looking, I get it. But he is also one of the most boring actors to ever grace the silver screen. His stock and trade seems to be one facial expression, determined, his mouth, his eyes, nothing ever changes, no matter what the situation. His only concession to creating a character seems to be responding to others when they call his character's name. "Will?" "Yes."Drink up, me `earties, yo ho.The main addition to the cast is Bill Nighy who plays Davy Jones. You may not recognize the name, but I can guarantee you have probably seen him in some British film or other. He generally plays eccentric, older men, like the aging rocker in "Love, Actually". In "Dead Man's Chest", he has so much make up on, you would never recognize his face.As Davy Jones, he plays the Pirate of folklore who lives at the bottom of the sea. The filmmakers have created a very unique visual look for Jones and his crew; because the pirates are living in the sea, they have begun to assimilate various fish and other sea creatures into their bodies. Jones is part octopus, barnacles, crab and lobster with a whole host of other creepy crawlies crawling out of every orifice. It is a great look and helps to make the legend believable.Jones's ship, the Flying Dutchman is equally impressive. Covered with barnacles and living creatures, the sails are covered with eels, it has the ability to submerge and reappear above water at will.Maraud and embezzle, and even high-jack...I always find it a little easier to lose myself in a fantasy if there is at least a little basis in reality. In "Dead Man's Chest", the new `villain' in the film appears in the form of Beckett (Tom Hollander), the officer of the East India Trading Company. This company is so powerful and sponsored by the British Government, they are quickly taking over every port in the Carribean, extending their reach and their influence, running the pirates out of business. Actually, they are simply legalizing piracy, making it their own, and taking control of it.Beckett wants a compass in the possession of Sparrow and he needs Will to get it for him. This is the start of the adventure and ultimately will bring the three main characters back together.Drink up me `earties, yo ho...The other major addition to the cast is Stellan Skarsgard who plays Bootstrap Bill, Will's (Bloom) father. A pirate, he has made a deal with Jones and now serves as one of his crew. Throughout the film, we see his transformation, as barnacles and other sea creatures slowly attach to him, making him one of Jone's crew for the rest of eternity.Yo ho, yo ho, a pirate's life for me...The film is simply beautiful to look at. Using some spectacularly beautiful locations in the Carribean, the film seems to shimmer with color. As the action moves to a port, or to a shack in a swamp, the crew is clearly modeling the look after the popular ride, and fans of the ride will love the references, but the attention to detail is superb.We kindle and char, inflame and ignite...There are a couple of spectacular action sequences. The first is a lengthy bit involving circular cages made of bones. All of Sparrow's men and Turner are captured by a band of natives and imprisoned in two balls hanging over a gorge. Their method of escape is truly interesting, unusual and fun.But the real standout is a lengthy duel between Sparrow, Turner and Norrington. I know you have probably seen duels before, but this is a standout sequence. During a chase through the countryside, they end up in a broken down mill. Soon, the action shifts to the old water wheel on the outside. The three men end up on the wheel and it breaks off the structure, rolling down the hillside, with all three inside. As it moves, the three men end up in various fighting positions; imagine three hamsters in an exercise wheel, but fighting one another.Drink up, me `earties, yo ho."Dead Man's Chest" isn't a perfect film. In addition to Orlando Bloom, the film is about 15 minutes too long and it simply stops, not really ending, providing a starting point for the third installment. This give "Dead Man's Chest" an incomplete feeling.These minor quibbles aside, "Dead Man's Chest" is a rousing adventure which will provide a lot of fun for everyone. Drink up, me `earties, yo ho.

reviewText: We loved this movie...better than the first, although the first was a gem as well. Viewed in a movie theatre it was quite an experience, however, this series (referring to the first) when released on DVD is only in the EXTREEM WIDE SCREEN EDITION, I'm assuming this new edition is the same. Even on a large 16 x 9 format monitor there are still black bars on top and bottom of the picture...on a 27 inch standard or smaller TV the picture with all it's action is JUST TOO SMALL. There should be a choice of FULL SCREEN with all the extras on DVD as well as the wide screen edition. You also lose one-half of the picture resolution when the picture is reduced to a narrow band in the middle of the screen. At one time many DVD movies had BOTH CHOICES ON ONE DISC. A great movie with just a technical complaint. FOUR STARS due to the extreem widescreen formatonly.
summary: PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN - Dead Man's Chest -TOO Widescreen

reviewText: and as you can tell by the latest box office readings, it proved to be correct.  Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest has brought in a whopping 132 million over this weekend alone, while leaving Superman in the dust, which earned a measley 21 million, pretty low if you ask me for it being in its second week of release only. Why they put Superman to go head to head with the POTC is beyond me.  They should've known the man of steel would stand no chance against all them damn bloody pirates!!Now onto the movie, all I have to say is WOW!!!  This was an awesome fantastic sequel that really lived up to the first.  And I might as well go on to say it might have even surpassed the first.  Everything was outstanding.  The acting, directing, special effects, visuals, EVERYTHING!!!! All true Pirates of the Caribbean fans will not be disappointed! Johnny Depp is defintley of course the stand out in the film as Jack Sparrow. The entire theatre was cracking up mostly the whole time. Dang, now I really know he was born to play this role.  I couldn't see anyone else playing it but him. The other returning players also gave outstanding performances.  Orlando Bloom was given way more screen time this time around then in the first and deftinley shows his talent that hes a fine actor.  And Keira Knightley again shined playing the lovely stubborn Elizabeth Swann.And I have one thing to say to all the people who are bashing this sequel and saying it wasn't good at all because it just has alot of action scenes and special effects and that there is no plot.  So what???  The last time I checked, most people go to the movies to get away from the real world, so to speak.  They don't want to be bored by a bunch of scenes where it's just talking and thats it.  We want to see fighting, lots of action and special effects.  Hey, if you don't, this is your wrong movie. Go see Gone with the Wind or some other sappy drama.  I'll take this over any of those anyday!! And hey, if you didn't notice there was a plot, I'm wondering if your watching the same movie I am.All in all, this is defintley the Big Summer flick of 2006.  No doubt about that!!  HIGHLY Recommended to everyone who loves a good awesome action oriented special effects extravaganza!!!! This will be a real treat for you.  And yes, TAKE THE KIDS!!!!! There are some scenes that are frightening and scary, but not enough to make them cry. The showing I went to had numerous children in it, and all of them enjoyed the movie.  I didn't hear one cry or peep out of them except of course laughter.  So do take them.  The entire family will enjoy this!!!A MUST SEE!!!!!!!!!! 5 stars in my book!!!!!!!

reviewerName: T. Noever "Author of the TETHYS series"
reviewText: There appear to be numerous people who expected more of the same of what was in _Curse of the Black Pearl_ and complain that either they didn't get it, or else that what they got wasn't the part of what they expected. Which makes one wonder what they expected or had hoped for to begin with; and why they would be deluded enough to think that it was even possible to provide said elements. 'The same only different' is almost impossible to deliver. Every time it's been tried, it failed to excite, excepting neophobes. _Dead Man's Chest_ provides a nice combination of some of the expected, with a fairly good and sensible continuation of the story. Reminds me of Star Wars, episodes 4-6. Only this one is better. There you go: heresy!Seriously though: think of where PotC:CotBP ended. Sparrow gets away, but is likely to be pursued by Norrington across the seas. Jack has unfinished business with dark powers. Will and Elizabeth plan to marry. Pirates are about to be executed en masse, what with there being no anti-capital-punishment demonstrators handy. The East India Trading Company, an organization with a tainted history, and one of the precursors of modern multinationals, invades the Caribbean, piggy-backing its activities on the military colonial presence. The nasty monkey from PotC:CotBP steals a piece of gold and becomes immortal; but you had to watch through the end-credits to see that bit. Someone from the East India Company watches a DVD of PotC:CotBP, and so finds out about the Aztec treasure and that it is to be avoided at all cost.SPOILERS following, so be warned!What follows in this sequel is, as far as one can expect this in a silly fantasy flick, a view at the possible consequences. Norrington fails to find Jack and becomes a drunk eager to get back into the good graces of the powers-that-be; revealing dark streaks to his nature. Dark elements also surface in Elizabeth, who has always been a bit attracted to Jack and he to her, and who uses this for an act that she eventually probably regrets; something so ultimately pragmatic and survival oriented that I couldn't believe it at first. Will tries to be noble, but finds it extremely difficult, even though he's far more naive than his fiancee. Confronted with his father, he is pushed to places he might not otherwise have gone.The darknesses found in the characters reveals depth, as darkness always does, and makes them very much more interesting and three-dimensional. As a result the movie bears about the same relationship to the original that The Empire Strikes Back had to the original Star Wars. In many ways it works better, because one has the feeling that the writers aren't going for some grand deep-and-meaningful cosmic salvage plan, and are also avoiding thoroughly annoying elements like those pesky and tedious Ewoks. There is very little 'cute' factor in Dead Man's Chest; some pretty horrific stuff, implied and off-camera, but potentially disturbing for children; nice gross creatures; lots of "har har"; evil multinationals represented by psychopaths; great visuals and lots of noise; more twists and turns that you can shake a stick at, which a lot of people found confusing, but who cares about them; lots of shtick; and a Johnny Depp, who treads a fine line between being funny and becoming annoying, so much so that I almost hope we won't see much of him in the final instalment, but focus on the interesting people in the mix: those less concerned with parodying themselves.Despite Depp it was thoroughly enjoyable, and I have no problems with the lack of denouement. We lived through LotR, did we not? Except, of course, that there we knew the outcome...Till Noever, owlglass.com

reviewText: When a movie's good, I don't mind it being long (like "Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring") because it holds your interest the entire time, but this movie didn't do that. I couldn't wait for it to be over. Don't get me wrong--Johnny Depp is always at his best. He's the only good thing about the sequel. But even though he was in it throughout, it felt like his parts were watered down. His dialogues felt too few and far in between. Also, Davy Jones' crew was a disgusting bunch to watch. And I didn't like the connection they tried building between Jack & Elizabeth, which only hurts the relationship they built between Will and her. Anyway, what's worse is it looks like the 3rd installment will be more of the same.

reviewText: What a disappointment! I absolutely loved The Black Pearl but was admittedly  nervous about a sequel. As it turned out, I had every reason to be. It whole purpose of this movie seemed to be to return those characters from the original, major or minor, who seemed interesting. That they did but, unfortunately, the producers forget to give them a credible plot and interesting things to say.Depp seemed to play his role even campier than before while Keira must have, somehow, pissed off the writers so that they refused to give her any real meaty part of this movie. Legolas, I mean, Orlando Bloom also seemed to be sort of drifting along, sometimes good but more often, haphazardly. To my mind, the only real interesting addition was that of Davey Jones. Except for times when it was hard to understand what he was saying (due to the tentacles 'n all), at least his was a unique addition to the movie. I do sort of object, however, to associating him with the Flying Dutchman legend. The two have nothing to do with each other, fantasy or not. And don't get me started on the cannibals!Any way, I think this movie merits the two y'ars I gave it. While considerably beneath that first movie, it is somewhat watchable and even enjoyable at times, but it is most definitely not as good.And, as a final thought, the very last scene of the movie? Lose it entirely. It simply was unnecessary.

reviewText: I loved the first PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN film.  It was a major surprise; I don't think that anybody expected it to be as great as it wound up being.  It was, and is, one of the greatest films ever made.  So the immense success of its sequel, PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: DEAD MAN'S CHEST, is no surprise.  What is surprising is how incredibly fun this film is.The plot is enormous.  It grows and twists around throughout the entire film.  The early form of the plot is this: Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and his fiance, Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley), are arrested and sentenced to death for conspiring to release Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) from prison.  Shortly after they're arrested, Cutler Beckett (Tom Hollander) strikes a deal with Will: if he will retrieve Jack Sparrow's compass, than Beckett will drop the charges against Will and Elizabeth.  Will takes the opportunity and searches for Jack, hoping that he will help him free Elizabeth.  But Jack's got problems of his own.  BIG problems.I don't think I've ever seen a film with a plot so enormous as that of this movie.  That's not a bad thing, though, because the plot - huge as it is - is a great one; fortunately, Ted Elliott and Terry Rossio's script is great as well.  Director Gore Verbinski does an excellent job of bringing the script to life, but he has a lot of help from an extremely-talented cast.  Bloom is great, Knightley even more so, but it goes without saying that Depp steals the show.  Every moment he's onscreen, our attention is fixed upon him - a swaying, alcoholic, eccentric, grimy pirate.And the audience can't get enough of him.Screenwriters Elliott and Rossio have written one of the greatest adventure films ever made.  It's loaded with laughs, swashbuckling adventure, thrilling suspense, and high-flying romance.  I don't know if I've ever had so much fun at a film.  DEAD MAN'S CHEST is a delight, but it's major flaw is the length.  The film is just too long.  Not unbearably long, mind you - it's a fine-enough film to keep you entertained for its entire runtime - but too long nonetheless.  While the first film had a straightforward storyline, the storyline of this film feels like it could fill an entire island.  It's huge, expansive, a real BEAST.  But thanks to Verbinski's delightful directing, a wonderful cast, and a stellar script, the second PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN stays afloat.Is it as good as the first film?  I would say not, but it's very close.  It has many more laugh-filled sequences, more adventure, more intrigue, and one heck of a fine ending.  Those who enjoyed the first film, or just want to see a good ol' adventure flick, won't regret dishing out some booty to see DEAD MAN'S CHEST.  This is turning out to be a marvelous series.

reviewText: The movie business is a law unto itself. After Polanski and Carolco both near bankrupted themselves on pirate pics, nobody expected the original Pirates of The Caribbean to do anything but sink with all hands, let alone be both entertaining and hugely successful, and a few years later nobody expected its vastly inferior sequel, Dead Man's Chest, to do even better business and become only the third film gross more than a billion dollars.It's not a bad film and offers a fair amount of enjoyment, but the script lacks the polish, wit and surprise of the original and the film feels like it was thrown together in far too much of a hurry to get the best out of the footage (the three-way swordfight sequence in particular never feels that they had enough time to get right in the cutting room). The special effects and Bill Nighy are good, but it feels like they never had a full script and were writing it from day to day. But the biggest problem for me is that whereas the original boasted perhaps Keira Knightley's only okay performance, she more than makes amends here by delivering a performance of such staggering incompetence that it's almost physically painful watching her scowl or over-enunciate her way through her scenes. Surprisingly average.

reviewText: The second `Pirates of the Caribbean' is actually a very long (2 h 31 m) and costly teaser for the next entry that will be released in 2007. I don't mean to say the first sequel has no merits. It is fair to say that this film is entertaining enough with so many adventures, but at the same time I'm afraid that the magic that worked in the original is almost gone ... for now.The weakest point of the `Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest' is obvious from the very beginning. It is the script by Ted Elliott and Terry Rossio, who attempt to draw a bigger picture than it should be, trying to contain as many elements as possible. The basic story is about pirate Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp, good as ever) and Davy Jones (unrecognizable Bill Nighy), the latter claiming Jack's soul for an old contract.Besides that, there is another plot about the parenthood of Will Turner (Orlando Bloom), less memorable character from the first film. Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley) also comes back, together with Norrington (Jack Davenport) a forgettable character that few people would remember. So many characters are crammed into the 150-minute film, and you will never see the point of the story unless you have seen the original. Or maybe you won't if you have.The good news is Jack Sparrow (for which Johnny Depp was Oscar-nominated) retains his amusing eccentricity. Depp's interpretation of the character as rock-and-roll version of pirate is still the most attractive part of the series, and probably will be. Some delightful characters are back such as the comic duo of Pintel (Lee Arenberg) and Ragetti (Mackenzie Crook), both funny as before.Except for some set-pieces (like Jack's `fruits-throwing' sequences, funny slapstick), the second `Pirates' film has lost the unpredictability and originality of the first one. The film looks great, and entertaining as a whole, but is a letdown when seen beside the original. Let's wait for the next entry and what Chow Yun-Fat can do.
summary: Long Entertaining Teaser for the Next Seqeul

reviewText: PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: CURSE OF THE BLACK PEARL was a huge gamble for Disney that paid off big time.  The film was loosely based upon the ride at Disney World (though elements of the plot might have been plagiarized from an unknown writer). Pirate movies haven't done well in the past twenty years.  Not only that, but the film cost a bundle of money to make. However, it ended up being one of the biggest grossing pictures of 2003 and birthed the creation of a new cinematic hero, Capt. Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp).  Disney took the gamble even further and green-lit two sequels to be filmed simultaneously.  CURSE OF THE BLACK PEARL did well, but no one knew for sure how PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: DEAD MAN'S CHEST would be received.  Shockingly it became the biggest grossing picture of 2006.  In just two days it reached the $100 million mark and surpassed $200 million in just over two weeks.PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: DEAD MAN'S CHEST begins sometime after CURSE OF THE BLACK PEARL.  Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley) and Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) are engaged to be married, but their wedding is interrupted by the arrest of Will by Lord Cutler Beckett, a sort of CEO of the East Indian Trading Company.  It turns out that Beckett has a warrant for the arrest of both Will and Elizabeth for aiding and abetting Jack Sparrow in his escape.  The penalty is death, but Beckett agrees to release Will and Elizabeth if they can get an item of his that Jack possesses:  a compass.  The compass will show a person the direction to the thing that person most desires in the whole world.  Beckett wants the compass because he wants a chest that contains the heart of Davy Jones, an undead pirate captain that has a face like a squid and who rules the seas aboard his ship The Flying Dutchman, gathering up souls to serve on his crew before they go to the judgment.  If you have Davy Jones' heart, you can control Jones and if you control Jones you can control the sea.Meanwhile, Capt. Jack Sparrow is in a bit of trouble of his own and is trying to find Davy Jones' chest, too.  Apparently, Sparrow made a deal with Jones several years ago and now payment is due:  Jack's soul and servitude.  Jack doesn't like that and is trying to find the chest, too so he can get out of his agreement.  Eventually Will and Elizabeth both find their way back to Jack, but only after various adventures involving cannibals, a giant kraken, a voodoo princess, The Flying Dutchman, a game of dice, and several faces from the past.  Throw in a three way sword fight on a rolling water wheel and a pirate shipfight and you have one impressive, though slightly confusing movie.Some points of the plot are difficult to understand (such as the whole dice game).  Also, I was disappointed that DEAD MAN'S CHEST isn't a movie that stands on its own.  The first film stood on its own as a film and I was hoping that each of the sequels would do the same.  Unfortunately, that's not the route the filmmakers took.  Now all three movies are tightly connected together and every character from the first film is brought back in the second.  Nevertheless, I enjoyed DEAD MAN'S CHEST better than CURSE OF THE BLACK PEARL.  I liked the action sequences better and felt the characterization for everyone was greatly enhanced.  I actually like the character of Will Turner now whereas after the first movie I thought he was nothing more than a pretty-boy bore.  Johnny Depp is once again a complete delight as Jack Sparrow and the Tom Hollander portrays the conniving and sinister Lord Beckett perfectly.  Some of the jokes in the film are old, yet it adds to the movie's charm.  I also enjoyed the fishy-undeadness of the crew of The Flying Dutchman: they are creepy.Overall, if you can deal with confusing plot elements and a few lame pirate jokes, PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: DEAD MAN'S CHEST is a swashbuckling good time.
summary: It Really Is the Must-See Movie of the Summer.

reviewText: I knew that as successful that the first Pirates was there was no doubt going to be a sequel in the works. So this time when the trailers were being released for 'Pirates Of The Carribean: Dead Man's Chest' I was eager to return to the theaters and get great for another wave crashing roller coaster.With a successful first time around this movie got the same actors but a much bigger budget so now it was time for the story to take a back seat and let the special effects have their day in the sun. First and foremost the movie was not bad, it still had the same writters and cast so the jokes and action were still at its peak. Also casting Bill Nighey as Davey Jones was a stroke of genius because he also like Geoffrey Rush can nail the fierce pirate persona. The only thing was there were some scenes where it just didn't make any sense and also the movie was much longer than the first so there were points where things were just being taken too over the top to the point where a person can rise up in a crowded theater and scream 'Enough already!'Once again with more plot twists and very shocking cliffhanger ending, wehn the credits start rolling you will still put your hands together and clap and be a little happier because now you know the final instalment is on the way and you will finally get your answers. (Part 2 of 3)
summary: Over The Top and Just A Tad Over Done.

reviewText: Something awful happened when they were working on this movie.  I can't begin to dissect exactly what was most responsible for this wreck masquerading as a quality movie.  Perhaps it's the shadows passing as characters who were once enjoyable.  Maybe it's the obsession with fulfilling every cliché that could be fit into a movie.  It could be the reliance on stunts and action over a coherent, or entertaining, plot.  Perhaps it's the stupidity of the Elizabeth character that annoyed me throughout.  I don't know.Whatever happened, it's clear that everyone involved with this movie was interested in an easy paycheck.  No one seems to have even tried.  It's as if the whole project was run on the assumption that a good first movie would carry this one far enough.  Sadly, that is exactly what has happened.  But this film is an absolute and total waste of time, money, and energy.  Everyone involved should be embarrassed for having taken a part in such an awful excuse for entertainment.The only reason it gets two stars is out of respect for the outstanding original movie and the hope that third will recover and give us a satisfactory ending.

reviewText: FILM REVIEW (DVD review below):Although "Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl" didn't scream "Sequel time!", the box office gross, popularity, and the subtitle alone couldn't have demanded anything else. "Dead Man's Chest" was of one of the best summer films of all time and did everything a sequel should do: There was more action, more thrills, more laughs, and a richer storyline.Pros:*Outstanding performance from Johnny Depp and newcomer Bill Nighy as Davy Jones*The new villains are awesome*Amazing action*Rich, engaging storyline*Fantastic and emotional score from Hans Zimmer*The Kraken*Beautiful locales*Amazing CGI courtesy of ILM*Good pacing and an enthralling cliffhangerCons:*Plot could use more strengthening*More story?My rating: 5/5DVD REVIEW:This is where DVDs go right. This 2-Disc set has plenty of features. Disc 1 includes the movie plus "Bloopers of the Caribbean". Disc 2 features over 5 hours of bonus material. The highlights of this disc are "Charting the Return" and "According to Plan", which are fantastic "Making Of" features that last almost as long a the movie. There is also a feature on the creation of Davy Jones (which is awesome), an interactive feature on Jack Sparrow's costume, "Mastering the Blade" which shows how the actors trained for their sword fights, "Dead Man Tell New Tales" which shows how the movies inspired new additions to the classic Disney ride, and a feature of the Bone Cage sequence. All in all, this DVD delivers in terms of features and is a must have.My rating: 5/5

reviewText: "Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest" surprisingly holds its own and provides solid entertainment. Director Gore Verbinski pulls off a dazzling hat trick by managing to make the sequel entertaining despite all of the excess baggage it carries into theaters. "Dead Man's Chest" is a fun movie pure and simple. Enjoy it for what it is-- a summer movie designed to provide refuge from the heat and you'll have a good time. The film may not be quite as consistent as the first "Pirates" film but it's still enjoyable fun. A plot synposis is below for those interested. There are some minor spoilers so if you don't want to read them and be completely surprised (as I was) by the film, don't read any further.I should warn parents that this, like the first film, might be a bit too scary for some younger kids.***Minor plot spoilers in the third paragraph below******Captain Jack Sparrow (Depp) must find Davy Jones' (a digitally enhanced Bill Nighy of "Love Actually" and "The Constant Gardener) locker to get out of an agreement to give up his soul to the sea dwelling captain. Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley) are both arrested on their wedding day for aiding Sparrow's escape. The only way they will avoid prison and the death by hanging is to retrieve Sparrow's compass on behalf of the East India Trading Company and Her Majesty. All of this is somehow mysteriously tied into Sparrow's search for Jones' locker.***End of spoilers"Dead Man's Chest" succeeds as entertainment and while it may lack the surprises of the first film it goes down like a delicious desert. Fans will enjoy "Dead Man's Chest" but will have to wait till next year for the resolution to the cliffhanger.
summary: An enjoyable sequel to the first film

reviewText: Loved the first, really loved the second.Reminded me of the Indiana Jones flicks adventure wise.Depp rocks as "rockstar" pirate CAPTAIN Jack Sparrow. ;-)Lots of really good cgi effects all around. Some of the most amazing non-prosthetic work I've seen in a while. Davy Jone's character's tentacles/face is all cgi. Bill Nighy performed with dots on his face for reference. On that alone, this film will get nominated for best visual effects.Spoiler Alerts...........My favorite 2 scenes in the entire film were when Sparrow mentions the lack of Rum on the ship, gets up, wobbles, and realizes why there is no rum on the ship...Second scene is where Sparrow is looking through his spyglass at Davy Jones. Jones turns around, and Sparrow is actually standing right behind him. Those two scenes sealed the deal for me. I was rolling!!! lolI missed both of these films in theaters. I will be at the show for the 3rd one. You best believe that!Late!

reviewText: This is the second of three Pirates of Caribbean movies and this was filmed at the same time as the third after the phenomenal success of the first.  So be warned that the ending is somewhat of a cliffhanger, although how Captain Jack Sparrow could possibly survive getting munched by the Kraken is pretty hard to imagine.In any case, if you liked the first movie, which I did, you'll probably like this one too.  Hard as it is to believe, the stunts in this one are probably better.  Captain Jack's escape from the cannibals and his three way duel with Will and Norrington on the runaway mill wheel really standout.  However, some of the special effects are downright disturbing.  In particular, Davy Jones and his crew as well as the Kraken are especially stomach-turning.  I didn't find the skeleton crew of the first movie nearly as hard to look at, and they were fairly intense.The plot is a little bit weaker as well.  Jack is after a chest containing Davy Jones's heart, and his motivation is easy enough to figure out.  He owes Davy Jones his soul for being give command of the Black Pearl for 13 years, and if he finds Davy Jones's still beating heart, he has the leverage he needs to get out of his debt.  Less understood is why Norrington or the East India Trading company would want it, but the plot doesn't get in the way of the action anyway.I also wasn't particularly enthralled with the way Keira Knightley's character Elizabeth Swan has morphed into just one of the guys in such a pc way, and how she then falls for Captain Jack.  Nor did I care for the portrayal of the evil East India Trading company.  Typical Hollywood anti-corporation message worms it's way into a film set in the 17th century.But those are minor annoyances, this film's not out to change the world, just entertain it.  And in that it does a solid 4-star job.

reviewText: Plot in a nutshell - picking up where "Curse of the Black Pearl" left off, the Black Pearl's Captain Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) must try to worm his way out of a deal with the Flying Dutchman, Davy Jones (Bill Nighy). With a price on their heads, Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) and his star-crossed virgin lover Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley), are both forced to help Jack after the evil Lord Cutler Beckett (Tom Hallander) arrests them both and blackmails them to get Jack, or rather, his compass. The unexpected wild card is former Commodore James Norrington (Jack Davenport), who's life has pretty much fallen apart after getting caught in a storm pursuing Jack following the events of the last movie, and one way or another he's either going to get his revenge or get his old life back, no matter the cost.Sequels are a tricky business. It's so hard to live up to the first one, let alone surpass it. More often than not, sequels often just feel like vain imitations/remakes/rehashes of the films that spawned them as the same basic formula is usually just flogged to death (Rocky's 2-5 and Matrix's Reloaded/Revolution come to mind here). There are exceptions, such as "The Empire Strikes Back", but they are few and far between. For the most part I enjoyed "Dead Man's Chest" but I cannot deny that the original film was superior.The biggest sin of "Dead Man's Chest" is that it runs too long and tries to over-stuff itself, cutting back & forth between Jack Sparrow's antics, the misfortunes of Will or the misfortunes of Elizabeth, which then leads us to the misfortunes of Norrington, with a lot of action thrown in, whereas the first film had a more focused, driven feel to it. I saw the film with my dad and he commented that it felt like they took a book, ripped out the most interesting/exciting parts and then pasted it together in no particular order. Most criminally, the storyline with Will catching up with the sea zombie version of his father Bootstrap Bill Turner (Stellan Skarsgard buried under tons of prosthetic makeup & CGI) is probably the most interesting storyline going in the movie, but it deserves more time than it ultimately gets. The decision to turn Norrington into a full blown evil bastard was unexpected - I know he wasn't exactly the hero of the first film, but he wasn't the villain either, just the romantic rival (I blame this on the fact that they cut scenes that were meant to establish him as a nicer guy). The thing with Elizabeth becoming infatuated with Jack, or at least appearing to become infatuated with him, was a relatively minor offense but still an annoying one. It felt like the writers were trying too hard to both play to the popularity of Depp/Jack and also to try and resurrect the opposites attract magic of Princess Leia & Han Solo, the primary difference being that Solo was taller, better looking, had better equipment and had better hygiene than Sparrow. That seemed to go against part of Elizabeth's realizations in the first film that pirates weren't all they were cracked up to be, and she struck me as being smarter than to fall for an obvious scoundrel like Jack. Or maybe I'm just over-reacting to their decision to put the young lovebirds fate in doubt. And there are some who will undoubtedly be annoyed by the cliff-hanger setting up "Pirates 3: The Pirate Version of the Search For Spock".Okay, stuff I actually did like... there were some genuinely funny moments (some of which were overplayed), the action set pieces were well staged & well executed (if a little over the top), and the actors were generally good. Johnny Depp basically rehashes his performance from the first film, which works well enough since he still appears to be having fun as the drunken glam rocker pirate. Orlando Bloom is good in his usual low-key way (though he's basically got himself typecast as the earnest young hero and will probably spend the rest of his career being accused of just playing himself in every film he does).Nighy & Starsgard were good along with the rest of the undead crew, though they are basically a steroid fueled remake of the undead crew from "Curse". Keira Knightley was alright, though in a few scenes it felt like she was trying too hard (namely the ones where she's supposed to act like she's becoming infatuated with Jack). I guess I'm not being very positive here, am I? Well, if I make the film out to be worse than it actually is, I'm sorry. Just go in knowing that it's not as bad as the Star Wars prequel trilogy, Batman & Robin, Daredevil, Elektra, 2005 Fantastic Four and Catwoman.Now go hide the rum.

reviewText: This was one of the best movie that I have ever seen! I didn't see this film at the cinema, but I really wish I had because it has instantly become one of my favourite movies of all time. I bought the DVD because I'd heard good things about the movie, and I've been to both Disneyland Paris, and Disneyland Florida and loved the Pirates ride at both of them. Having been on the ride, it's quite easy to spot many things in the movie that pay tribute to the ride, especially in the town scenes. I wasn't sure what to expect when I bought the movie, but I definitely didn't expect to laugh so much! This movie has such a wonderful combination of excellent acting, astounding special effects, and dry humour. Johnny Depp steals practically every scene he occupies, and Geoffrey Rush is excellent and sinister in his villainous turn. It's about as high-quality fun as one might demand in a summer blockbuster, and will have you singing "Yo ho, ho ho" for days and days to come. A "pirate's life" is plenty the life in "Pirates of the Caribbean", an worthy, intelligent sea-faring adventure guaranteed to leave you, at the very least, plenty satisfied.

reviewText: I was not a fan of the first Pirates of the Caribbean, and I was just as surprised as Johnny Depp about his Oscar nod which was a total fluke. Not that I don't think he's a great actor or his performance sucked, he was good playing the role with the right amount of camp, but it's a cartoonish character, and it's got no depth like say his other less "successful" roles in Ed Wood and What's Eating Gilbert Grape, and Don Juan Dimarco. It's less interesting to see him play the same part, because it's just a bit repetitious. I must say that his performance still outshone Keira Knightly and Orlando Bloom. Amongst other supporting players, I was quite impressed with Bill Nighy(the "tako sunomono" villian), and the near-unrecognizable Stellar Skarsgard. Oh, and there is the scene-stealing Naomi Harris who was wickedly memorable. The fight scenes were better this time around and lots more special effects. They even let different ethnic actors play the creatures. I noticed the "Headless Sea Creature" spoke Cantonese in one brief scene. They do look very real and creepy, can't imagined the amount of prep work put in by the SPFX and Prosthetics department. The Production is quite lavish and impressive. Got to love the breakdown and continuity of the wardrobe department, even thought there is only a few changes for the cast. Wonder how many shirts they used for Bloom? The audiences is obviously divided into two sides; one will laugh at the physical and verbal jokes easily, and the other thinks they are not funny at all. I am more of the latter. Oh, do watch for a cameo appearance by Geoffrey Rush. I think he's going to make a comeback in Pirates 3, and I am certainly looking forward to seeing Chow Yun Fat's participation!
summary: Thumbs up to SPFX, Wardrobe,  Production, and Prosthetics departments!

reviewText: So last night I saw the film that has been breaking every single record in the history of film: Pirates of the Caribbean 2. So far, the film has claimed the top spot for best opening day, best opening weekend as well as best opening week....bye bye Spidey and Star Wars. Now, honestly, there are two very good reasons why film analysts should almost have EXPECTED these results- one general and one specific to pirates:1. Ticket prices are going up. Thus, the next blockbuster should do better than the one that preceded it. We shouldn't be suprised to see these records broken every couple of years.2. Pirates was in the perfect position to break these records. Pirates didn't inspire the kind of zeal that Star Wars or the Spiderman movies did. The reverse side of that coin, however, is that the first Pirates (and hence any sequels) appealed to a WIDER audience. How many people watched the first Pirates movie and flat out decided that it sucked? Not many; thus, most every casual moviegoer has/had some interest in Pirates 2. It might be said, in fact, that the Pirates movies have the widest appeal factor that any series of movies has ever had. Comic book movies still maintain a connotation of geekiness, and the Star Wars movies had already made their enemies with the first two prequels. Who doesn't like pirates? (even if they'll always lose a fair fight with ninjas) Thus, on a night often reserved for movies (Friday), Pirates was simply THE best option for anybody who could POSSIBLY ascribe the title "average joe (or josephina)" to themselves.I approached the movie with caution, then. I knew that Pirates was doing well without regard for its actual merits. As all sequels do in their first week, it was reaping numbers based directly on the popularity of its predecessor. In addition, many critics were calling the sequel overblown. Even worse, they were calling the film a vehicle to let Jack Sparrow take center stage. I was particularly sensitive to this mixed praise because I've seen sequels try to ride the popularity of a particular character before. Pirates 2 had all the potential to be a true shipwreck- a slow mess serving only to give Depp screen time and a few dance numbers (well, maybe not). And frankly, I didn't love the first Pirates and I definitely don't "love" Depp...he's a tad overrated and his performance here isn't the first reason to see Pirates 2.So if you've been educated at least through middle school and can follow tone, you can probably see where this is all headed. The previous paragraph serves to contrast with this coming paragraph, so here it is: Pirates of the Carribean 2 is everything that it should be and follows most all of the "sequel do's and don'ts." Now, if you're a boring person that thinks watching golf or baseball is a riot and detests action films...well, you're still not gonna like this movie. However, if you at all like the idea of the bigger, badder sequel- this'll be right up your alley. And in case you're worried, there will be no spoilers.Plot:This, of course, was the make or break aspect of the film. Either we get served up an extra helping of Jack, or the writers decide to actually tell us a story. For the first half hour, it seemed quite likely that the writers had elected to take the former route. Unsurprisingly, this feeling never ENTIRELY disappears. However, by the end of the film, it at least feels earned. At the same time, it becomes clear about halfway through that the viewer is being treated to a pirate EPIC. Pirates 2 clocks in around 150 minutes, though the film felt much shorter to me. There are a myriad of subplots and complications that keep the viewer engaged from beginning to end. As a sidenote, I recommend rewatching the first Pirates before seeing this one just so you remember what happened to which characters. There are, of course, a few plot holes- an epic action film with as many things going on as this one is going to have a couple. It's easy to overlook them, however when the film is as good as it is. Finally (MINOR spoiler), Pirates 2 does what all great middle movies (this is now a trilogy) do- it ends in a cliffhanger and sets up the third movie. Disney is apparently filming the third movie now, and I wish I could see it NOW.Acting/Characters:If you liked Depp in the first one, you'll of course like him again here. He doesn't get many great lines, however. Suprisingly, and to my great pleasure, many of the supporting characters provide some great entertainment. A certain twosome provides a good number of both obvious and subtle humor. Both Bloom and Knightley have more to do in this one as well. And (excuse me for a moment, ladies) Knightley is more attractive and interesting in this movie than she was in the first. A certain scene on a beach won me over entirely. Ultimately, the acting here definitely seems a step up from the first as I cared more for the outcome of each of the characters.Score:Hans Zimmer replaces Klaus Badelt (his protege) as the composer. While this makes little sense to me- the master taking over the work of the student- there is no doubt that the result is impressive. Zimmer can be hit and miss, but it seemed to be all "hit" here. Badelt had composed some impressive themes for the first Pirates, but the rest of the score was mediocre. Zimmer transforms the main themes from the first and adds a couple of his own. The result is a score that is swimming (sorry) with melodies.Special Effects:Clearly, no expense was spared. From the landscaping to the bad guys, everything that could be CG IS CG. Most of the time, however, you really can't tell beyond the fact that what you're being presented with is physically impossible. I was truly impressed with the way human expressions from real actors were melded with CG to create fictional but seemingly realistic creatures. Pirates borrow a number of effects and ideas from other movies, but it uses them well. The result is a movie that is almost entirely unencumbered by technological constrainsts and, thus, entirely free to tell the story as intended.There are a number of surprises and displays of ingenuity within this film that I won't dare ruin. So in summation, I'll say just this: As good as Superman was, Pirates 2 deserves to rule the summer.
summary: A Successful Pirate Epic (Spoiler Free Review)

reviewText: I loved this movie just as much as I loved the first one. It has a fast pace, lots of action, many funny one liners and a great cast. It's a long movie but doesn't seem long because there is so much going on. I was not bored once. Depp was HOT, Knightly was hot and the ending left me hoping that part 3 will come out soon! True, it's not a realistic movie and the fight scenes are really far fetched but it's a fun movie and I was entertained. There are some gross scenes and it's slightly scary but for kids who can handle it, it's a really a great family movie and also a great date movie with something for guys and gals alike. Some might find this movie childish but if you are looking for something light-hearted and funny that will be good for all ages, this is the movie for you!
